Dialogue:
doctor: hello, can you please tell me about your past medical history?
patient: hi, i dont have any past medical history.
doctor: okay. what brings you in today?
patient: ive been experiencing painless blurry vision in my right eye for a week now. ive also had intermittent fevers, headache, body aches, and a nonpruritic maculopapular rash on my lower legs for the past 6 months.
doctor: thank you for sharing that. have you had any other symptoms such as neck stiffness, nausea, vomiting, raynauds phenomenon, oral ulcerations, chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, or photosensitivity?
patient: no, only an isolated episode of left knee swelling and testicular swelling in the past.
doctor: do you work with any toxic substances or have any habits like smoking, drinking, or illicit drug use?
patient: no, i work as a flooring installer and i dont have any toxic habits.
doctor: alright. we checked your vital signs and they were normal. during the physical exam, we found bilateral papilledema and optic nerve erythema in your right eye, which was greater than in your left eye. you also have a right inferior nasal quadrant visual field defect and a right afferent pupillary defect. your muscle strength and reflexes were normal, and your sensation to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception was intact. we also noticed the maculopapular rash on your bilateral lower extremities.
patient: oh, i see.
doctor: your admitting labs showed some abnormal results. you have microcytic anemia with a hemoglobin of 11.6 gmdl, hematocrit of 35.3, and mean corpuscular volume of 76.9 fl. you also have hyponatremia with a sodium level of 133 mmoll. your erythrocyte sedimentation rate esr is elevated at 33 mmhr, and your c-reactive protein crp is also elevated at 13.3 mgl. your urinalysis did not show any protein or blood.
patient: okay. what does that mean?
doctor: these results could indicate an underlying inflammatory or infectious process. we also performed a lumbar puncture, which showed clear and colorless fluid, 2 red blood cells per microliter, and 56 white blood cells per microliter.
patient: so, whats the next step?
doctor: we need to investigate further to determine the cause of your symptoms. well run additional tests and consult with a specialist to get a clearer understanding of your condition. in the meantime, well monitor your symptoms and provide supportive care. well keep you informed about any new findings and discuss the best course of treatment.
patient: alright, thank you, doctor.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient, a flooring installer with no significant past medical history, presents with painless blurry vision in the right eye for one week, intermittent fevers, headaches, body aches, and a nonpruritic maculopapular rash on the lower legs for six months. the patient also reports an isolated episode of left knee and testicular swelling in the past but denies any neck stiffness, nausea, vomiting, raynauds phenomenon, oral ulcerations, chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, or photosensitivity. no history of exposure to toxic substances or habits related to smoking, drinking, or illicit drug use.
o: vital signs are normal. physical examination reveals bilateral papilledema, greater optic nerve erythema in the right eye, a right inferior nasal quadrant visual field defect, and a right afferent pupillary defect. muscle strength, reflexes, and sensation to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception are intact. a maculopapular rash is noted on bilateral lower extremities. lab findings include microcytic anemia hemoglobin: 11.6 gmdl, hematocrit: 35.3, mcv: 76.9 fl, hyponatremia sodium: 133 mmoll, elevated esr 33 mmhr, and crp 13.3 mgl. urinalysis is normal. lumbar puncture shows clear fluid, 2 rbcsl, and 56 wbcsl.
a: the patients symptoms and findings suggest a possible inflammatory or infectious process affecting multiple systems, including the central nervous system, as indicated by papilledema and abnormal lumbar puncture results. differential diagnoses could include autoimmune conditions, infectious diseases, or other systemic inflammatory disorders. the presence of optic nerve involvement and systemic symptoms necessitates further investigation to narrow down the causes.
p: plan to conduct additional diagnostic tests to explore underlying causes, including imaging studies and specific serological tests. consultation with a neurologist and possibly a rheumatologist or infectious disease specialist is recommended. monitor the patients symptoms closely and provide supportive care as needed. educate the patient about the findings and the importance of follow-up for further evaluation and management. ensure the patient understands the potential seriousness of the symptoms and the need for thorough investigation and possibly long-term management.

s: the patient reports experiencing painless blurry vision in the right eye for a week, intermittent fevers, headache, body aches, and a nonpruritic maculopapular rash on the lower legs for the past 6 months. the patient denies any toxic substances, smoking, drinking, or illicit drug use. no history of neck stiffness, nausea, vomiting, raynauds phenomenon, oral ulcerations, chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, or photosensitivity.
o: vital signs were within normal limits. physical examination revealed bilateral papilledema, optic nerve erythema, right inferior nasal quadrant visual field defect, and right afferent pupillary defect. laboratory tests indicated microcytic anemia hemoglobin 11.6 gmdl, hematocrit 35.3, and mean corpuscular volume 76.3 mgl. lumbar puncture showed clear and colorless fluid, 2 red blood cells per microliter, and 56 white blood cells. urinalysis did not show protein or blood. c-reactive protein crp was elevated at 13.9 fl normal range: 0-33 mmhr, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate esr at 33 mmhr

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i understand that youre a 7-year-old boy with congenital bilateral sensorineural deafness, and youve had a failed right cochlear implant. is that correct?
patient: yes, doctor.
doctor: we recently conducted a magnetic resonance imaging mri before transferring you to the operating theatre for an abi insertion. during the mri, your airway was secured with a size 5.5 mm internal-diameter uncuffed ett. did you experience any discomfort during the mri?
patient: no, it was okay.
doctor: great. now, during the surgery, we will be performing intraoperative neurophysiology monitoring, which includes brainstem auditory sensory evoked potentials, brainstem mapping of cn ix, x, xi, xii and their motor nuclei, and corticobulbar tract motor-evoked potential mep. this will help us monitor your nerves during the procedure.
patient: okay, doctor.
doctor: our anesthesia team will be responsible for the lead placement for cn ix, x, xi, xii. we will use a 32 mm by 29 mm laryngeal electrode for cn x monitoring fig.. to ensure optimal electrode placement on the tracheal tube, we positioned you as intended for surgery right lateral and identified the depth of ett corresponding to the laryngeal inlet using a c-mac laryngoscope.
patient: hmm, alright.
doctor: this corresponded to 6 cm at vocal cords 15 cm at lips. we then prepared a new 5.5 uncuffed ett with the laryngeal electrodes fig. and re-intubated you, in keeping with the measurements. 
patient: okay, got it.
doctor: for cn ix placement, we put a pin electrode on the ipsilateral soft palate. for cn xii, we placed electrodes on the anterior tongue. 
patient: i see.
doctor: to stabilize the tracheal tube, we used rolled up gauzes on either side of it fig., which also acted as a bite block.
patient: alright, doctor.
doctor: during the surgery, we will administer total intravenous anesthesia tiva which includes propofol paedsfusor target control infusion, target plasma concentration 3.55.0 mcgml and remifentanil 0.080.3 mcgkgmin.
patient: will i feel any pain during the surgery?
doctor: no, the anesthesia will ensure that you remain comfortable and pain-free throughout the procedure.
patient: thats good to know.
doctor: after the surgery, we will closely monitor your recovery and provide any necessary follow-up care. its important that you follow our instructions to ensure the best possible outcome.
patient: yes, doctor. i will.
doctor: great. if you or your family have any questions or concerns, please dont hesitate to reach out to us.
patient: thank you, doctor. we appreciate your help.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient is a 7-year-old boy with congenital bilateral sensorineural deafness, reporting a previously failed right cochlear implant. he denies experiencing discomfort during the recent mri procedure.
o: recent mri with airway secured using a 5.5 mm internal-diameter uncuffed ett. pre-operative preparations for abi insertion include intraoperative neurophysiology monitoring and placement of various electrodes for nerve monitoring. the anesthesia plan includes total intravenous anesthesia tiva with propofol targeted at a plasma concentration of 3.55.0 mcgml and remifentanil dosed at 0.080.3 mcgkgmin.
a: primary diagnosis is congenital bilateral sensorineural deafness with a failed right cochlear implant. the patient is scheduled for abi insertion with comprehensive intraoperative monitoring to ensure nerve integrity and anesthesia efficacy.
p: proceed with abi insertion under tiva. monitor intraoperative neurophysiology closely. post-operative care will include close monitoring of recovery and necessary follow-up care. educate the patient and family on post-operative care and encourage them to reach out with any concerns or questions.
Generated SOAP:
s: the patient is a 7-year-old boy with congenital bilateral sensorineural deafness, presented with a failed right cochlear implant. he reports no discomfort during the mri.
o: mri revealed airway secured with a size 5.5 mm internal-diameter uncuffed ett with a 32 mm by 29 mm laryngeal electrode on the tracheal tube. mri showed a depth of 6 cm at vocal cords 15 cm at lips, with a c-mac laryngoscope measuring 6.55. post-mri, the patient experienced discomfort but was able to continue with the procedure.
a: the primary diagnosis is a failure of the cochlea. differential diagnoses could include other causes of failure, but these are less likely given the successful implant.
p: the management plan includes intraoperative neurophysiology monitoring for cn ix, x, xi, xii, and corticobulbar tract motor-evoked potential mep. the procedure will involve total intravenous anesthesia tiva with propofol paedsfusor target control infusion, target plasma concentration 3.0 mcgml and remifentanil 0.3 mcgkg

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, weve received your results from the ultrasound we performed in april 2017. it seems that there is a single thyroid nodule present in your left lobe, measuring 1 cm in its largest diameter. we also performed a complete biochemical screening, including tests for tsh, autoantibodies, and calcitonin.
patient: hmm, what did the screening results show, doctor?
doctor: your calcitonin level was found to be slightly elevated at 40 ngml, which is above the normal range of 1-4.8 ngml. to further investigate, we performed a stimulation test with intravenous calcium.
patient: and what did the stimulation test show?
doctor: after the stimulation, your calcitonin levels peaked at 1420 ngml, which indicates that surgical treatment is necessary. as a result, you underwent a total thyroidectomy and central neck dissection on the side of the tumor.
patient: yes, i remember that. how was my recovery after the surgery?
doctor: your postoperative course was uneventful, with only a slight hypocalcemia recorded in the first day. however, it completely recovered 48 hours after the surgery, and you were discharged.
patient: thats good to hear. what did the tests on the removed tissue show?
doctor: immunohistochemistry performed on the thyroid nodule revealed the presence of a medullary thyroid cancer mtc measuring 1 cm. it is composed of cells with an eosinophilic cytoplasm and has a predominantly expansive growth pattern. a histological examination showed that the tumor cells were positive for calcitonin, cromogranin a, synaptofisin, and ttf-1, but negative for the presence of amyloid.
patient: what about the other surrounding tissue?
doctor: focal foci of c-cells hyperplasia were spread throughout the entire gland. however, none of the lymph nodes in the central compartment showed any signs of metastases.
patient: thats a relief. what other tests were done on the tissue?
doctor: to perform a more detailed analysis, we treated formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded sections with antigen retrieval using citrate buffer at high ph. they were then immunolabeled with a rabbit monoclonal anti-calcitonin antibody and incubated with appropriate fluorescent secondary antibodies.
patient: so, what does this all mean for my condition?
doctor: overall, these results confirm the presence of medullary thyroid cancer. fortunately, none of the lymph nodes showed signs of metastases, which is a positive sign. its important to continue with regular follow-up appointments and monitoring to ensure proper management of your condition.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient reported undergoing an ultrasound in april 2017, which identified a thyroid nodule in the left lobe. the patient underwent biochemical screening, including tsh, autoantibodies, and calcitonin levels, which showed elevated calcitonin. a stimulation test with intravenous calcium indicated significantly elevated calcitonin levels, leading to a total thyroidectomy and central neck dissection. post-surgery, the patient experienced transient hypocalcemia but recovered within 48 hours. the patient inquired about the recovery and results of the tissue tests post-surgery.
o: ultrasound revealed a 1 cm thyroid nodule in the left lobe. initial calcitonin level was 40 ngml normal range 1-4.8 ngml. post-stimulation, calcitonin levels peaked at 1420 ngml. postoperative recovery included slight hypocalcemia, resolving in 48 hours. immunohistochemistry of the thyroid nodule confirmed medullary thyroid cancer mtc, 1 cm in size, with cells positive for calcitonin, cromogranin a, synaptofisin, and ttf-1, and negative for amyloid. no lymph node metastases were found. additional tissue analysis involved antigen retrieval and immunolabeling confirming mtc.
a: the primary diagnosis is medullary thyroid cancer, confirmed by histological and immunohistochemical analysis of the thyroid nodule and absence of metastasis in lymph nodes. the patients elevated calcitonin levels and the results of the stimulation test supported the need for surgical intervention, which was successfully performed without complications.
p: the patient will continue with regular follow-up appointments to monitor for any recurrence or progression of medullary thyroid cancer. monitoring will include periodic calcitonin levels and ultrasound imaging of the neck. the patient will be educated on the signs of recurrence and the importance of adherence to follow-up schedules. further genetic counseling may be considered to evaluate for familial mtc.
Generated SOAP:
s: the patient, a male with a history of medullary thyroid cancer mtc diagnosed in april 2017, presented with a chief complaint of hypocalcemia following a total thyroidectomy and central neck dissection.
o: physical examination revealed a single thyroid nodule in the left lobe, measuring 1 cm in its largest diameter. laboratory tests showed elevated calcitonin levels at 40 ngml normal range: 1-4.8 ngml. a histological examination showed no signs of metastases. histological tests showed no evidence of lymph nodes in the central compartment.
a: the primary diagnosis is medulla thyroid carcinoma mtc with a 1 cm nodule. differential diagnoses could include other forms of thyroid cancer, but these are less likely given the nature of the tumor.
p: the management plan includes surgical intervention to manage the condition.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, can you tell me what brought you here today?
patient: hi, ive been having a progressive headache, nausea, and vomiting for about a week. i also noticed some right-side weakness, ptosis, and diplopia.
doctor: i see. lets talk about when you first presented with these symptoms. did you experience any conscious disturbance?
patient: yes, i had an acute onset conscious disturbance, and my glasgow coma scale was e3vam5 at the hospital.
doctor: okay, we performed a brain computed tomography and found an enhanced brain tumor with necrotic cystic changes. the tumor is located in your left temporal lobe with upward extension to the left basal ganglion and periventricular region, causing perifocal edema and midline shift.
patient: oh, that sounds serious.
doctor: yes, its a serious condition. we performed an emergent craniectomy for tumor removal in december 2006. the pathology revealed pleomorphic, hyperchromatic cells with glassy, astrocytic cytoplasm, as well as hypercellularity, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis, consistent with the diagnosis of classic gbm.
patient: what happened after that?
doctor: you underwent radiotherapy a month later, followed by chemotherapy with temozolomide for six months. your performance status improved to a karnofsky grade of 70, and your clinical condition was stable thereafter.
patient: thats good to hear.
doctor: however, a follow-up brain magnetic resonance imaging mri in june 2014 revealed a new enhanced nodular lesion, about 1.1 cm in diameter, at your left temporal base. the brain mri in october 2014 showed a progressive change in lesions, with a maximum of 3.0 cm in diameter.
patient: what did you do about that?
doctor: we performed another surgery for gross tumor removal. histologically, the tumors showed the oligodendroglial component. neoplastic cells also showed isocitrate dehydrogenase 1 idh1 positivity, diffuse p53 positivity, and o6-methylguanine-dna methyltransferase mgmt negativity as revealed by immunostaining.
patient: hmm, i see.
doctor: during your follow-up, we noticed signs of increased intracranial pressure in may 2015. as a result, you received a third debulking surgery.
patient: what did the third pathology reveal?
doctor: the third pathology revealed both gbm- and pnet-like components. in immunohistochemistry, the pnet-like component exhibited positivity for synaptophysin and cd56 and focal weak positivity for glial fibrillary.
patient: whats the next step for my treatment?
doctor: we will continue to monitor your condition closely and provide further treatment options as needed. its important to follow up with us regularly to ensure the best possible care.
patient: thank you, i appreciate your help.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient reports a progressive headache, nausea, vomiting, right-side weakness, ptosis, and diplopia for about a week. the patient also experienced an acute onset of conscious disturbance, with a glasgow coma scale score of e3vam5.
o: initial brain ct revealed an enhanced brain tumor in the left temporal lobe with necrotic cystic changes, upward extension to the left basal ganglion and periventricular region, causing perifocal edema and midline shift. post-operative pathology confirmed a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme gbm. follow-up mri in june 2014 showed a new 1.1 cm nodular lesion at the left temporal base, which progressed to 3.0 cm by october 2014. histology post-second surgery showed oligodendroglial components with idh1 positivity, diffuse p53 positivity, and mgmt negativity. the third surgery pathology revealed gbm- and pnet-like components with positivity for synaptophysin and cd56.
a: the primary diagnosis is recurrent glioblastoma multiforme gbm, with differential diagnosis including primitive neuroectodermal tumor pnet components. the prognosis is guarded due to the aggressive and recurrent nature of the tumor.
p: the plan includes close monitoring of the patients condition with regular follow-ups to assess for further progression or new symptoms. continued treatment options will be considered based on the evolution of the disease and the patients response to previous therapies. education on symptom management and potential side effects of treatments will be provided to ensure the patient remains informed about their care.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i understand that you have been dealing with hepatocellular carcinoma and had a liver transplantation from a living donor about a year ago. how have you been feeling recently?
patient: well, lately i developed some severe abdominal pain that has been really bothersome.
doctor: im sorry to hear that. it seems like you have developed severe acute pancreatitis. when you were admitted to the hospital, we started a continuous intravenous infusion of fentanyl at 1200 gday to control your abdominal pain. over the course of 10 days, we increased the dose according to your pain intensity, reaching 2400 gday med 240 mgday. how has your pain been since then?
patient: its been a little bit better with the fentanyl, but its still quite painful.
doctor: i see. in addition to the fentanyl, we have also administered a pancreatic enzyme inhibitor, antibiotic, and fluid to help alleviate the pancreatitis and your abdominal pain. we have gradually reduced the continuous fentanyl infusion, and it was discontinued after reaching 240 gday 10 of the maximum dose. however, you mentioned experiencing nauseavomiting, elevated blood pressure, and restlessness 12 hours after discontinuation. is that correct?
patient: yes, thats right. it was pretty uncomfortable.
doctor: i apologize for the discomfort. to alleviate these symptoms, we resumed the continuous intravenous fentanyl infusion at 240 gday, and the symptoms disappeared. however, restlessness occurred each time the dose was reduced, so we decided to initiate a transdermal fentanyl patch to taper the opioid more slowly. how has that been working for you?
patient: the patch has been helpful ive noticed a difference.
doctor: good to hear. unfortunately, your pancreatitis with abdominal pain recurred transiently one month later. therefore, we resumed the continuous intravenous fentanyl infusion and titrated it to 600 gday. we have been gradually decreasing the dose daily 600, 300, 240, 180, 120, and 60 gday. as your pancreatitis has improved, we were able to discontinue the fentanyl without causing withdrawal symptoms. the discontinuation was finally completed 64 days after the onset of withdrawal symptoms. how are you feeling now?
patient: im feeling much better now, thank you.
doctor: thats great to hear. make sure to continue monitoring your symptoms and let us know if you experience any discomfort or changes in your condition. we will continue to follow up with you to ensure your recovery goes smoothly.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient, a post-liver transplant recipient, reports severe abdominal pain and has a history of hepatocellular carcinoma. recently diagnosed with severe acute pancreatitis, the patient experienced some relief from pain with fentanyl infusion but still describes the pain as quite painful. symptoms of nausea, vomiting, elevated blood pressure, and restlessness were noted upon opioid discontinuation.
o: the patient was initially managed with a continuous intravenous fentanyl infusion, starting at 1200 gday and increased to 2400 gday based on pain intensity. following the discontinuation of fentanyl, withdrawal symptoms including nausea, vomiting, elevated blood pressure, and restlessness occurred. these symptoms resolved upon resuming fentanyl at 240 gday. a transdermal fentanyl patch was later used to taper the opioid more gradually. the patients pancreatitis recurred transiently, requiring resumption and gradual tapering of fentanyl infusion from 600 gday to 60 gday over several days. the patient reports feeling much better following the complete discontinuation of fentanyl, 64 days after the onset of withdrawal symptoms.
a: the primary diagnosis is severe acute pancreatitis post-liver transplantation, complicated by opioid withdrawal symptoms following fentanyl discontinuation. the patients response to the reintroduction and gradual tapering of fentanyl suggests effective management of withdrawal symptoms.
p: continue monitoring the patients symptoms and recovery post-pancreatitis and post-fentanyl discontinuation. follow-up appointments should be scheduled regularly to assess pain levels, pancreatitis status, and any potential recurrence of symptoms. education on recognizing signs of pancreatitis and opioid withdrawal should be provided. referral to a pain management specialist and a gastroenterologist for ongoing pancreatitis management and to address any complications from liver transplantation may be necessary. ensure compliance with the prescribed pain management and withdrawal tapering protocols.
Generated SOAP:
s: the patient, a male with a history of hepatocellular carcinoma, reports severe abdominal pain that has been managed with a continuous intravenous infusion of fentanyl at 1200 gday for approximately 10 days. he has experienced nausea, elevated blood pressure, and restlessness 12 hours after discontinuation. the patient has been treated with a transdermal fentanyl patch, which has been effective.
o: initial vital signs were stable with a blood pressure of 120 mmhg, and abdominal pain of approximately 240 mgday. a pancreatic enzyme inhibitor, antibiotic, and fluid were administered to alleviate the pancreatitis and the abdominal pain, and the symptoms recurred transiently one month later, leading to the discontinuation of the fentanyl infusion at 240 gday, which was discontinued after 12 hours. a follow-up with the patient was scheduled for one month post-discharge.
a: the primary diagnosis is severe acute pancreatitis with abdominal pain. differential diagnoses could include other causes of pancreatitis, but these were ruled out based on imaging and clinical presentation. the prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the patients response to the fentanyl.
p: continue regular follow-ups to monitor the patients condition and respond to any new symptoms or changes in symptomatology

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, how can i help you today?
patient: hi, ive been experiencing some pain in my right chest lately.
doctor: i see. can you tell me more about your background? are you a smoker?
patient: no, i am a non-smoker. i work as an engineer for a gas company.
doctor: alright. have you had any exposure to asbestos in your workplace?
patient: no, i dont think so.
doctor: lets perform a physical examination to check for any issues in your lungs. after examination i noticed a reduction of lung sounds at the right lung basis, but no clinical sign of autoimmune disease.
patient: hmm, what could be causing the chest pain then?
doctor: we will need to perform a chest x-ray cxr to investigate further. after cxr the results show a considerable reduction in the right lung volume with associated right pleural effusion.
patient: what does that mean?
doctor: it means there is fluid around your right lung. we should perform more tests to determine the cause. after tests all serological, autoimmune, and microbiological tests came back negative. lets do a computed tomography ct scan to get a better view. after ct the ct scan revealed a slight reduction in right lung volume with associated right pleural effusion and pleural thickening.
patient: whats the next step?
doctor: we will conduct a supplemental investigation to rule out any history of trauma, tuberculosis, and pneumothorax. we will also perform an echocardiography to exclude pulmonary hypertension, and a diaphragm dysfunction test through phrenic nerve stimulation. after investigations all tests were negative.
doctor: well proceed with a total body positron emission tomographycomputed tomography pet-ct to check for any abnormalities. after pet-ct there was a low-intensity hyper-accumulation of 18-fdg in the right pleura with increased concentration in the basal, middle, and posterior pleural surface.
patient: whats the next step, then?
doctor: well perform a surgical lung biopsy slb to identify the issue. after slb the biopsy identified non-specific fibrinous pleurisy, but the search for neoplastic or infectious cells was negative.
doctor: unfortunately, your forced vital capacity fvc has dropped significantly over the previous 3 years, and you have developed shortness of breath on exertion. i am going to prescribe a prednisolone course to help with the symptoms.
patient: okay, thank you.
doctor: sadly, your condition has worsened with the onset of restrictive respiratory failure. its important to keep a close eye on your health and report any changes.
2 weeks later
doctor to patients family: i am sorry to inform you that the patient passed away due to a cardiac ischemic attack. the autopsy excluded mesothelioma or other pleural neoplastic diseases but reported the presence of diffuse fibrinous pleurisy.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient, a non-smoker and engineer, reported experiencing right chest pain. he denied any exposure to asbestos and any history of smoking. the patient also mentioned a significant drop in forced vital capacity over the past three years and recent development of shortness of breath on exertion.
o: physical examination revealed reduced lung sounds at the right lung base. chest x-ray indicated a considerable reduction in right lung volume with associated right pleural effusion. ct scan confirmed these findings and also showed pleural thickening. serological, autoimmune, and microbiological tests were negative. pet-ct showed low-intensity hyper-accumulation of 18-fdg in the right pleura. surgical lung biopsy identified non-specific fibrinous pleurisy without neoplastic or infectious cells. the patients condition progressed to restrictive respiratory failure.
a: the primary diagnosis is non-specific fibrinous pleurisy with associated pleural effusion and pleural thickening, leading to restrictive respiratory failure. differential diagnoses such as mesothelioma, tuberculosis, and pneumothorax were ruled out through various investigations. the prognosis became poor as the patient developed restrictive respiratory failure and subsequently suffered a fatal cardiac ischemic attack.
p: management included a course of prednisolone to address inflammation and symptoms. continuous monitoring and regular follow-ups were recommended to manage the progression of respiratory failure. education on symptom management and the importance of reporting any new symptoms was provided. a surgical lung biopsy was performed to further investigate the pleural changes. unfortunately, despite these measures, the patients condition deteriorated, leading to his death. an autopsy confirmed the absence of mesothelioma or other pleural neoplastic diseases, but showed diffuse fibrinous pleurisy.

Dialogue:
doctor: hi there, i see youve presented with body weight loss. can you tell me about any medical history you have?
patient: yes, i have hypertension and diabetes, but both are well-controlled by medication.
doctor: okay, thank you for letting me know. weve done some laboratory tests, and the data shows that your hemoglobin is decreased at 9.1 gdl. however, your tumor markers are within normal limits.
patient: oh, i see.
doctor: we performed a colonoscopy which revealed a circumferential tumor in your sigmoid colon. a histological examination of the biopsy showed that its a ras-mutant adenocarcinoma. the raf mutational status was not investigated.
patient: hmm, that doesnt sound good.
doctor: a contrast-enhanced ct scan showed irregular colonic wall thickening with massive involvement of your urinary bladder. there were enlarged regional lymph nodes suggestive of metastases but no distant metastasis. your pretreatment diagnosis is lacc stage iiic t4bn2m0.
patient: so, whats the treatment plan for me?
doctor: we started with a loop transverse colostomy, similar to some other cases. we then planned 6 courses of chemotherapy with capox plus bevacizumab.
patient: how did that go?
doctor: you eventually received 5 courses of capox plus bevacizumab and the remaining 1 course without oxaliplatin due to grade 2 neurotoxicity. a follow-up ct after the neoadjuvant chemotherapy showed significant tumor shrinkage.
patient: thats good news.
doctor: yes, it is. thereafter, we performed a sigmoid colectomy and partial resection of your bladder. the postoperative course was uneventful, and you did not suffer from neurogenic voiding dysfunction or urinary incontinence.
patient: im relieved to hear that.
doctor: pathological examination revealed that tumor cells or degeneration was present in less than one third of the entire lesion, which was consistent with grade 1a effect according to the japanese classification of colorectal carcinoma.
patient: so, whats the final diagnosis?
doctor: the final diagnosis is ypt4b, ypn0, m0, ypstage iic. you subsequently received 8 courses of adjuvant chemotherapy with capecitabine alone.
patient: and how am i doing now?
doctor: there has been no recurrence at 16 months after the initial diagnosis, which is a very positive outcome.
patient: thats great to hear. thank you for all your help, doctor.
doctor: youre welcome. we will continue to monitor your progress and provide any necessary support.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient presented with body weight loss and has a history of well-controlled hypertension and diabetes. he reported undergoing various treatments and procedures for a diagnosed sigmoid colon adenocarcinoma.
o: laboratory tests showed decreased hemoglobin at 9.1 gdl normal range: 13.8-17.2 gdl for men, 12.1-15.1 gdl for women. tumor markers were within normal limits. colonoscopy revealed a circumferential tumor in the sigmoid colon, confirmed as ras-mutant adenocarcinoma by biopsy. ct scans indicated irregular colonic wall thickening, involvement of the urinary bladder, and enlarged regional lymph nodes suggestive of metastases, but no distant metastasis. the patient was diagnosed as lacc stage iiic t4bn2m0. post-treatment follow-up showed significant tumor shrinkage and no recurrence at 16 months post-diagnosis.
a: the primary diagnosis is locally advanced colorectal cancer lacc stage iiic t4bn2m0, with a post-treatment stage of ypt4b, ypn0, m0, ypstage iic. differential diagnoses were considered based on tumor markers and imaging but were ruled out by biopsy and further pathological examination.
p: the patient underwent a loop transverse colostomy and received 6 courses of capox plus bevacizumab, with modifications due to neurotoxicity. this was followed by sigmoid colectomy and partial bladder resection. postoperative recovery was uneventful. he completed 8 courses of adjuvant chemotherapy with capecitabine. ongoing monitoring and supportive care will continue to manage and prevent potential recurrence.
Generated SOAP:
s: the patient, with a history of hypertension and diabetes, presents with a chief complaint of body weight loss. he reports no history of neurogenic voiding dysfunction or urinary incontinence.
o: colonoscopy revealed a circumferential tumor in the sigmoid colon, classified as lacc stage iiic t4bn2m0. contrast-enhanced ct scan showed irregular colonic wall thickening with massive involvement of the urinary bladder, suggestive of metastases but no distant metastasis. a histological examination of the biopsy indicated a ras-mutant adenocarcinoma. postoperative ct showed significant tumor shrinkage, consistent with grade 1a effect.
a: the primary diagnosis is ypt4b, ypn0, m0, ypstage iic. differential diagnoses could include other forms of colorectal carcinoma, but these are less likely given the imaging findings.
p: the treatment plan includes capox plus bevacizumab, capecitabine, and oxaliplatin due to grade 2 neurotoxicity. the patient underwent a loop transverse colostomy and partial resection of the bladder. the postoperative course was uneventful,

doctor: hello, i heard you have a 6-month history of swelling in the left floor of your mouth, and you were referred to our institution. how can i help you today?
patient: yes, thats right. ive been experiencing some difficulty in swallowing, but i havent had any pain or tongue paralysis.
doctor: i see. lets perform an intraoral examination to better understand the issue. hmm, i can see a well-defined 3.5  3  2 cm-sized solid, spherical submucosal nodule adjacent to the sublingual gland. its covered with light bluish smooth mucus. do you feel any pain when i apply pressure to the tumor?
patient: yes, i feel slight pain when you press on it.
doctor: alright. your tongues mobility and sensory functions seem to be normal, and i dont detect any lymphadenopathy in the submandibular region on palpation. well need to conduct some laboratory tests and an enhanced computed tomography scan to get a clearer picture of the issue.
patient: okay, i understand.
after the tests
doctor: your lab results are all normal, and the enhanced computed tomography scan revealed a 2.8  1.8  2.1 cm-sized well-defined, solid, heterogeneous nodule that doesnt appear to involve the mandible. we also found a nodular lesion occupying the left floor of the mouth with abundant blood flow. no enlarged lymph nodes were detected in the submental or submandibular regions.
patient: so, what does that mean, doctor?
doctor: based on these findings, our initial clinical impression is that this could be a benign salivary gland tumor, dermoid cyst, or benign connective tissue neoplasm. we will need to schedule you for surgery via an intraoral approach to remove the tumor and further examine it.
patient: alright, so what will the surgery involve?
doctor: during the surgery, well make an elliptical incision around the periphery of the sublingual gland, and prepare a full-thickness tissue flap along the lingual aspect of the sublingual gland. after freeing the sublingual gland from its surrounding tissue, well find the well-circumscribed tumor without capsular extension beneath the body of the sublingual gland. well carefully free the submandibular gland duct and lingual nerve from the tumor surface, and completely excise the tumor along with the sublingual gland.
patient: i see. what happens after the surgery?
doctor: after the surgery, well fix the tissue sample with 10 formalin and submit it for histopathological diagnosis to determine the exact nature of the tumor.
patient: okay, thank you for explaining everything to me. im ready to proceed with the surgery and follow-up care.
doctor: youre welcome. well make sure to take good care of you during and after the surgery. if you have any questions or concerns, dont hesitate to reach out to us.

a: the differential diagnosis includes benign salivary gland tumor, dermoid cyst, or benign connective tissue neoplasm. the clinical findings and imaging suggest a benign etiology, but histopathological examination is required for definitive diagnosis.

doctor: hi there, can you please tell me about your past medical history?
patient: well, i had prostate cancer and underwent a prostatectomy.
doctor: i see. and what brings you here today?
patient: ive been experiencing tingling and numbness in my right arm and leg for at least a month. 
doctor: do you smoke, drink alcohol, or use any drugs?
patient: no, i dont smoke, drink alcohol, or use drugs.
doctor: your daughter mentioned that youve had an unsteady gait and needed assistance when moving. is that correct?
patient: yes, thats true. its been really hard for me to walk lately.
doctor: okay, lets review your vital signs from the day of admission. your temperature was 97.9 f, heart rate 68 beatsmin, blood pressure 13784 mmhg, and respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute. you were alert and oriented to person, place, and time. now, lets discuss your neurological examination findings. you showed right-sided hemiparesis and significant leg stiffness. your strength in your right arm was 45, and in your right leg, it was 35. your left side was unremarkable.
patient: yeah, ive been having difficulty moving my right side.
doctor: we also found that your cranial nerves 2-10 were normal, but you had difficulty shrugging your right shoulder and couldnt turn your head to the left. when walking, your gait was unsteady, and you compensated with your non-affected side. the rest of your physical examination was within normal limits.
patient: okay, what about the tests you did on me?
doctor: your laboratory values were within normal limits. we performed a head computed tomography ct and a follow-up magnetic resonance imaging mri, which were both negative for a stroke. however, your cervical spine ct showed marked degenerative changes, including moderate to severe spinal canal stenosis at c4c5.
patient: oh, what does that mean?
doctor: we performed an mri of your cervical spine without contrast, which confirmed the moderate to severe central stenosis with cord compression and mildly increased t2 signal at c4c5 and c5c6. there were degenerative findings between levels c3-c7, along with hypertrophy.
patient: so, whats the next step, doctor?
doctor: based on these findings, well discuss potential treatment options and closely monitor your condition. its important to follow up with your primary care physician and a specialist to address the spinal stenosis and any related symptoms.

a: the primary diagnosis is cervical spinal stenosis with cord compression, likely causing the patients right-sided hemiparesis and sensory disturbances. differential diagnoses could include other causes of neurological deficits such as multiple sclerosis or a neoplastic process, though imaging did not support these.
p: the management plan includes referral to a neurosurgeon for evaluation of surgical options for the cervical spinal stenosis. the patient should continue to monitor symptoms and follow up with his primary care physician. physical therapy is recommended to improve mobility and prevent further deterioration. regular follow-ups to monitor the progression of the spinal stenosis and adjust the treatment plan as necessary are essential. education regarding the condition and its implications will be provided to ensure the patient and his family understand the treatment goals and prognosis.

doctor: hello, how can i help you today?
patient: hi, i am a 76-year-old woman and my chief complaint is backache.
doctor: i see. can you tell me about your medical history?
patient: yes, i have hypertension and lumbar spinal canal stenosis.
doctor: have you been treated with an oral anticoagulant or antiplatelet agent for these conditions?
patient: no, i havent.
doctor: when did you first notice the backache?
patient: the discomfort started about 4 days ago without any obvious cause.
doctor: has your backache worsened since then?
patient: yes, it aggravated suddenly, and i also had vomiting and difficulty with body movement.
doctor: did you seek medical help for these symptoms?
patient: yes, i visited the department of surgery at your hospital and was admitted for examination and treatment.
doctor: were there any abnormal findings on thoracoabdominal ct or endoscopy from a surgical perspective?
patient: they didnt find anything abnormal, so they referred me to your department.
doctor: alright, lets discuss your initial examination. your body temperature was 36.2c, blood pressure was 192109 mmhg, and pulse was 79min. you had a mild disturbance of orientation with a glasgow coma scale gcs of e4, v4, m6. have you experienced a severe headache along with the backache?
patient: no, just the severe backache.
doctor: okay. during your neurological examination, we didnt find any hypesthesia or muscle weakness of the lower limbs. your deep tendon reflexes were normal, and there were no abnormalities in hemorrhage and coagulation test findings. on plain radiography at admission, there were also no abnormal findings in the thoracolumbar vertebrae. we performed a lumbar spinal mri 4 days after the onset, which showed a band-like shadow continuous from the thoracic spinal level, with high intensity on t1-weighted imaging and low intensity on t2-weighted imaging, and stir. to examine the lesion at the upper level more closely, we performed a thoracic spinal mri 7 days after the onset. it revealed a band-like shadow extending from th2 to l3 on the subdural extramedullary ventral side. a mass was present in the shadow at th7, compressing and deforming the spinal cord centered on this region, with changes in intramedullary brightness of th6.
patient: that sounds concerning. what does it mean?
doctor: it indicates that there is a mass compressing your spinal cord which might be causing your backache and other symptoms. we will need to perform further tests and discuss potential treatment options with you.
patient: okay, thank you for explaining everything to me. i appreciate your help.
Reference SOAP:

o: initial examination showed a body temperature of 36.2c, elevated blood pressure at 192109 mmhg, and a pulse of 79min. neurological examination revealed mild disorientation gcs: e4, v4, m6 but no hypesthesia or muscle weakness in the lower limbs, and normal deep tendon reflexes. hemorrhage and coagulation tests were normal. plain radiography of the thoracolumbar vertebrae showed no abnormalities. lumbar and thoracic spinal mri indicated a band-like shadow from th2 to l3 with a mass at th7 compressing the spinal cord, suggesting spinal cord compression.
a: the primary diagnosis is spinal cord compression due to a mass at th7, likely causing the patients backache and associated symptoms. differential diagnoses could include other causes of spinal cord compression or intrinsic spinal pathology. the prognosis depends on the nature of the mass and response to treatment.
p: plan to perform further diagnostic tests to characterize the mass, including possible biopsy if accessible. consultation with neurosurgery for potential surgical intervention to relieve spinal cord compression. manage hypertension aggressively to reduce cardiovascular risks. continue monitoring neurological status and adjust pain management as needed. educate the patient on the signs of worsening neurological function and instruct her to report immediately if symptoms progress. schedule follow-up appointments to reassess condition and treatment efficacy.

doctor: hello, how can i help you today?
patient: hi, doctor. i have a history of seizures and abnormal neurological findings. i was diagnosed with hhh syndrome when i was 4 years old.
doctor: i see. have you experienced any developmental disabilities, such as expressive language or attention problems?
patient: yes, i have had issues with both expressive language and attention.
doctor: okay, have you had any evaluations for these issues?
patient: yes, i had a neuropsychiatric evaluation that determined these problems.
doctor: i understand. do you have any issues with your vision, like myopia?
patient: yes, i have significant myopia.
doctor: alright. were you prescribed a specific diet to help manage your hhh syndrome during your childhood?
patient: yes, i was prescribed a diet with protein restriction to 1.5 gkgd during my childhood.
doctor: how has your weight and height been throughout your life?
patient: my weight has been at the 25th percentile and my height has been less than the 3rd percentile.
doctor: thank you for the information. i see that you have delivered three children. can you tell me about your first pregnancy?
patient: i became pregnant at 18 years old and experienced episodes of nausea and dizziness. i was on a low-protein diet during the first trimester.
doctor: did you experience any issues with mild hyperammonemia during your pregnancy?
patient: yes, mild hyperammonemia was detected during the 11th and 12th week of pregnancy. my protein intake was then restricted to 40 gd.
doctor: were there any complications during your pregnancy, such as seizures?
patient: yes, i developed seizures at 22 weeks gestation and was started on carbamazepine.
doctor: did you have any brain imaging done at that time?
patient: yes, brain imaging showed multiple small calcifications of unreported cause, but normal cerebral angiography.
doctor: how was your childs birth and development?
patient: my baby girl was born at full term via cesarean-section. she had intrauterine growth restriction with a weight less than the 3rd percentile. however, her development was normal at 2 years of age.
doctor: i see. can you tell me about your second and third pregnancies?
patient: very little is described for my second and third pregnancies. both my second and third child were born via caesarian section. 
doctor: were there any issues with your second childs ornithine levels?
patient: yes, a moderately elevated ornithine concentration 302 ml was measured in the cord blood, but it decreased to normal in the newborns blood 24 hours after birth.
doctor: did your blood ammonia levels increase after the birth of your second child?
patient: yes, they increased 24 hours postpartum and i was given a treatment consisting of oral sodium benzoate and intravenous arginine.
doctor: how has your second child been developing?
patient: my second child has had normal growth and development at 10 months of age.
doctor: lastly, did your third child experience any respiratory issues at birth?
patient: yes, my third child had transient respiratory distress.
doctor: thank you for sharing your medical history with me. based on this information, well continue to monitor your condition and your childrens development closely. please maintain your prescribed diet and medication regimen, and reach out if you experience any concerning symptoms.

o: the patients brain imaging during her first pregnancy showed multiple small calcifications with normal cerebral angiography. her first child was born full-term via cesarean-section with intrauterine growth restriction and normal development at 2 years. the second child had moderately elevated ornithine levels at birth which normalized within 24 hours, and normal growth and development at 10 months. the third child experienced transient respiratory distress at birth.
a: primary diagnosis is hhh syndrome with complications including developmental disabilities, myopia, mild hyperammonemia during pregnancy, and seizures managed with carbamazepine. differential diagnoses could include other metabolic disorders influencing growth and neurological status. the prognosis is cautiously optimistic with careful management of diet and medication.
p: continue monitoring the patients metabolic status and neurological condition. maintain protein-restricted diet and current medication regimen. regular follow-ups with neurology and genetics are recommended to manage hhh syndrome and monitor childrens development. education on symptom management and when to seek medical attention is crucial. referral to a dietitian for ongoing dietary management and to ophthalmology for myopia management is advised. compliance with treatment and diet is essential for managing symptoms and preventing complications.

doctor: hello, how can i help you today?
patient: hi, im a 36-year-old gravida 2, para 1 caucasian woman, and im currently 9 weeks pregnant. ive been having headaches lately.
doctor: i see. are you experiencing any visual changes, chest pain, dyspnea, or other neurological symptoms?
patient: no, just the headaches.
doctor: alright. i understand that your previous in vitro fertilization pregnancy was complicated by preeclampsia at 27 weeks of gestation, and you delivered a growth-restricted fetus by cesarean section at 36 weeks, weighing 1900 g. is that correct?
patient: yes, thats correct.
doctor: i also see in your file that you have a past history of infrarenal aortic stenosis, which was diagnosed based on a computed tomographic angiogram. this angiogram was done to investigate your persistent hypertension and intermittent claudication postpartum. it showed 75 stenosis of the infrarenal aorta with hypertrophied internal mammary and epigastric arteries. is that correct?
patient: yes, thats right.
doctor: it seems that your regular medications include aspirin 100 mg and calcium 1.2 g daily. additionally, your family history is significant for paternal ischemic heart disease and maternal hypertension. is that accurate?
patient: yes, youve got it right.
doctor: during your pregnancy, laboratory investigations for preeclampsia revealed low-grade proteinuria with a urine proteincreatinine ratio of 40 mgmmol, as well as normal renal and liver function. your vasculitic screen showed a normal c-reactive protein level of 3.8 mgl, mildly elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 16 mmh, and absence of antinuclear antibodies, antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibodies, anti-double-stranded dna antibodies, and antiphospholipid antibodies. does that sound correct?
patient: yes, thats what the tests showed.
doctor: at 34 weeks, your ultrasound indicated that the estimated fetal weight was in the 94th percentile, and your placental vascular resistance was normal. is that correct?
patient: yes, thats what they told me.
doctor: thank you for the information. the differential diagnoses for your major finding of significant infrarenal aortic stenosis include congenital abdominal coarctation, takayasus arteritis, fibromuscular dysplasia, aortic neurofibromatosis, aortic tuberculosis, and radiation aortitis. in your case, the presence of a well-developed collateral vasculature suggests a chronic aortopathy.
patient: okay, so what does that mean?
doctor: since you dont have any clinical history or signs of neurofibromatosis, tuberculosis, or radiation exposure, and there is little evidence of active inflammation, the diagnosis could be chronic abdominal aortopathy from congenital abdominal aortic coarctation, fibromuscular dysplasia, or an inactive form of takayasus arteritis. we will need to continue monitoring your condition and possibly adjust your treatment plan accordingly.
patient: i understand. what should i do next?
doctor: we will keep a close eye on your pregnancy and monitor your headaches as well as any potential symptoms related to your aortic stenosis. it is important to continue taking your medications and attending regular check-ups. if you notice any changes in your symptoms or have any concerns, please reach out to us immediately.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate your help.
doctor: youre welcome. take care, and dont hesitate to contact us if you need any assistance.

a: the primary diagnosis is significant infrarenal aortic stenosis with differential diagnoses including congenital abdominal coarctation, takayasus arteritis, fibromuscular dysplasia, aortic neurofibromatosis, aortic tuberculosis, and radiation aortitis. the presence of well-developed collateral vasculature suggests a chronic aortopathy, likely due to congenital abdominal aortic coarctation, fibromuscular dysplasia, or an inactive form of takayasus arteritis.

doctor: hello, how can i help you today?
patient: hi, ive been having difficulty walking recently.
doctor: i see. how long has this been going on?
patient: it started about three days ago. i felt some discomfort in the front of my knee and it turned into pain the next day.
doctor: was there any injury or specific event that could have caused this?
patient: no, there was no injury or anything that i can think of.
doctor: alright. have you noticed any swelling of the joint?
patient: no, theres no swelling.
doctor: okay. let me examine your knee. ill check for tenderness at the medial and lateral femorotibial joint, and other tests like the lachman test, pivot-shift test, varusvalgus instability, and mcmurray test, okay?
patient: sure, go ahead.
doctor: performs tests all those tests were negative, which is a good sign. however, i noticed that your range of motion is severely restricted due to the pain. did you receive any treatment so far?
patient: yes, i was given an intra-articular injection of xylocaine, and it helped temporarily, but then i started feeling a catching sensation in my knee when i moved it.
doctor: okay, lets take a look at some imaging tests. examines radiographs and mri the simple radiographs showed no abnormal findings, but the mri revealed a soft tissue mass located near your knee joint. it has an ill-defined border and high signal intensities on both t1- and t2-weighted images. on fat-suppressed images, it has low signal intensity, and theres no contrast enhancement in contrast imaging. your blood examination also showed no abnormal findings.
patient: oh, that doesnt sound good. what do you suggest i do?
doctor: considering your persistent symptoms, i recommend surgery to remove the mass. we can perform a knee arthroscopy to get a better look at it and remove it if necessary.
patient: okay, id like to go ahead with the surgery.
doctor: performs surgery during the surgery, we found a large fat mass with mobility on the anterior surface of the proximal-lateral pf joint. it looked like fat and had an ill-defined border. we removed it piece by piece through a resection. histologically, it was mainly composed of connective tissue and fatty tissue, but we didnt find any signs of lipoma, lipoma arborescens, or pigmented villonodular synovitis.
patient: thats a relief. how are my symptoms now?
doctor: your symptoms have improved since the surgery, and there are no more signs of anterior knee pain or any other issues.
patient: thats great. thank you so much, doctor.
doctor: youre welcome. be sure to follow up with us if you have any concerns or if your symptoms return. take care

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i see you have a history of cholelithiasis. can you tell me more about the pain youre experiencing on your right side?
patient: yeah, ive been having this pain in my right upper abdomen, and its been quite bothersome.
doctor: hmm, it sounds like you may have a positive murphys sign. you were referred to our department for further evaluation and possible surgical treatment. we performed a computed tomography ct scan without contrast media, which revealed a gallstone in your thickened gallbladder wall. there was also a slight increase in the ct value due to surrounding panniculitis, as shown in fig.
patient: oh, i see. so what does that mean for me?
doctor: we also conducted an mrcp, which showed that your cystic duct is connected to an aberrant bile duct. based on these findings, you were diagnosed with chronic calculous cholecystitis with aberrant bile duct flow into the cystic duct.
patient: okay, so whats the next step for treatment?
doctor: we performed a laparoscopic cholecystectomy to address the issue. during the procedure, we placed four ports: a 12-mm camera port in the umbilical area, a 12-mm port in the epigastric area, a 5-mm port in the right subcostal area, and a 5-mm port at the right lateral abdomen.
patient: how did the surgery go?
doctor: due to the inflammatory fibrotic adhesion in calots triangle, the aberrant right hepatic duct arhd was excessively exposed. we used a fundus-first technique to confirm the arhd after exposing the inner layer of the subserosal layer at the dorsal and ventral side of calots triangle. we confirmed that the arhd drained into the cystic duct.
patient: was there any need to preserve the arhd?
doctor: preoperative mrcp suggested that it was not necessary to preserve the arhd, as it seemed to be closed at the hepatic side without communicating with the major right branch of the intrahepatic bile duct.
patient: so, what was done during the surgery?
doctor: we performed intraoperative cholangiography from the cystic duct in the periphery, which revealed that the arhd was not confluent with the major right branch of the intrahepatic bile duct and drained a narrow area. we decided to remove the excessively exposed arhd.
patient: how was the arhd removed?
doctor: we performed removal and ligation of the arhd on both the hepatic side and the cystic duct by clipping it using the aesculap ds titanium lig.
patient: alright, thank you for explaining everything to me. what should i expect during my recovery?
doctor: you will need to follow up with us regularly so we can monitor your progress and ensure proper healing. make sure to follow any post-operative instructions and contact us if you experience any unusual symptoms or concerns.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i received your medical records. youre a 50-year-old african american female, and you presented with a three-week history of intractable headache, confusion, vertical binocular diplopia, photophobia, and difficulty with balance, correct?
patient: yes, thats right. these symptoms have been bothering me for a while now.
doctor: i see. during the examination, your best corrected visual acuities were 2025 in the right eye and 2020 in the left eye. your intraocular pressures were 14 mmhg in both eyes, and no afferent pupillary defect was noted. your extraocular motility and confrontational visual fields were full in both eyes. is that correct?
patient: yes, thats what they told me.
doctor: the anterior segment examination in both eyes was unremarkable. however, the funduscopic examination revealed grade-four optic disc edema, blurring of the optic disc margin, and obscuration of vasculature of the optic nerve. preretinal and intraretinal hemorrhages were present in both eyes, mainly in the peripapillary retina but also extending to the mid-peripheral retina. are you following so far?
patient: yes, i understand.
doctor: optic nerve swelling was confirmed on optical coherence tomography oct of the retinal nerve fiber layer. fluorescein angiography revealed hyperfluorescence of the optic disc in both eyes. 
patient: okay, what does that mean for me?
doctor: we also performed computed tomography of the head, magnetic resonance imaging of the brain, and magnetic resonance venography of the brain. these tests were unremarkable and showed no evidence of intracranial mass, hemorrhage, or ischemia.
patient: thats good news, right?
doctor: yes, its good that we didnt find any of those issues. moving on to the cerebrospinal fluid csf analysis, it revealed an opening pressure of 30 cm h2o, 77 white blood cellsmm3 with 94 lymphocytes, 93 mgdl protein, and 73 mgdl glucose.
patient: what does that mean?
doctor: bacterial and fungal cultures of the csf were negative, as were csf studies for lyme, syphilis, herpes simplex virus, and west nile virus. a limited panel of laboratory studies for enterovirus, syphilis, ana, and p-anca was also negative. lastly, a respiratory viral panel for adenovirus, cytomegalovirus, influenza, parainfluenza, rhinovirus, and respiratory syncytial virus was negative.
patient: so, whats causing my symptoms?
doctor: at this point, weve ruled out many possible causes, but we still need to investigate further to determine the cause of your symptoms. its important for you to have follow-up appointments and additional tests as necessary so we can identify the cause and develop a treatment plan for you.
patient: alright, thank you for explaining everything to me, doctor. ill make sure to schedule those follow-up appointments.
doctor: youre welcome. if you have any questions or concerns, dont hesitate to reach out. well continue working together to find answers and get you feeling better.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i see that you are a 53-year-old woman with a posterior, stage iib nsclc in the left upper lobe. youve received neoadjuvant carboplatin, pemetrexed, and radiotherapy already. can you tell me if youve been experiencing any discomfort or new symptoms recently?
patient: yeah, doctor. ive been having severe left back pain and left axillary numbness and paresthesia.
doctor: i see. based on your symptoms, we conducted some tests and found that the tumor has attached to the t2 and t3 vertebrae and infiltrated the corresponding nerve roots. this is likely the cause of your complaints. we consulted the neurosurgery and thoracic surgery services to discuss the best management for your condition.
patient: what did they recommend, doctor?
doctor: the magnetic resonance imaging mri studies showed that there was no direct tumor invasion of the left brachial plexus or subclavian vessels. after discussing different treatment options, they recommended a posterior approach, image-guided t2 and t3 osteotomy followed by transthoracic en bloc resection of the thoracic tumor.
patient: will that help with the pain and numbness?
doctor: yes, the operation aims to address the issues caused by the tumor attachment and infiltration. youll need to give your informed consent for the procedure.
patient: alright, i agree to the operation.
doctor: great. during the operation, well make an initial incision in the operating room and expose the spinal processes, lamina, and transverse processes from t1 through t5 as well as 5 cm of the ribs from the left costovertebral junction on the side of the tumor. well then take images with the o-arm and register your spine to the stealthstation navigation suite using a stereotactic probe.
patient: what happens next?
doctor: well use spine navigation to place the instrumentation at the level above and below the tumor-infiltrated vertebrae. we wont place screws on the left t2 and t3 vertebrae. the spinous processes and lamina of t2 and t3 will be removed, and the nerve roots will be exposed on the left side.
patient: and then youll remove the tumor?
doctor: yes, during the resection, well notice an infiltration of the ganglia by the primary tumor that is in continuity with the ribs on the left side. well proceed with resection, tying the t2 and t3 nerve roots.
patient: okay, doctor. i hope this will help with my pain and numbness.
doctor: we believe it will help to alleviate your symptoms. well provide you with follow-up care instructions after the operation to ensure a smooth recovery.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient is a 53-year-old woman with a history of stage iib non-small cell lung cancer nsclc in the left upper lobe, previously treated with neoadjuvant carboplatin, pemetrexed, and radiotherapy. she reports severe left back pain and left axillary numbness and paresthesia.
o: examination and imaging revealed that the nsclc has attached to the t2 and t3 vertebrae and infiltrated the corresponding nerve roots, without direct invasion of the left brachial plexus or subclavian vessels. mri studies were utilized to assess the extent of tumor involvement.
a: the primary diagnosis is stage iib nsclc with vertebral and nerve root involvement by the tumor. the symptoms of pain and paresthesia are attributed to this involvement. differential diagnosis would consider other causes of neuropathy and bone pain, but imaging and clinical presentation strongly support the primary diagnosis.
p: the management plan includes a posterior approach, image-guided t2 and t3 osteotomy, and transthoracic en bloc resection of the thoracic tumor to address the tumor attachment and infiltration. the patient has consented to the surgery. post-operative care will involve spine navigation and specific surgical techniques to avoid further nerve damage. follow-up care instructions will be provided post-operation to ensure a smooth recovery. referral to pain management and physical therapy will be considered post-surgery to manage symptoms and improve quality of life.

o: physical examination revealed no direct tumor invasion of the left brachial plexus or subclavian vessels. mri studies indicated an infiltration of the ganglia by the primary tumor, which has attached to the t2 and t3 vertebrae and infiltrated the corresponding nerve roots. neurosurgery and thoracic surgery involved a posterior approach, image-guided t2, t3 osteotomy, and transthoracic en bloc resection.
a: the primary diagnosis is stage ii nscl

Dialogue:
doctor: good morning how can i help you today?
patient: hi, doctor. i am a 70-year-old woman and i was admitted to the cardiovascular department for chest distress for 11 hours. i have been experiencing shortness of breath at rest and difficulty laying in the recumbent position.
doctor: i see. have you had any prior medical conditions?
patient: yes, i was diagnosed with hypertension and diabetes mellitus a few years ago and have been taking oral medication for their treatment.
doctor: okay, let me explain what happened after your initial admission. after your clinical examination, you were diagnosed with coronary atherosclerotic heart disease. you underwent coronary angiography and stent implantation, and during the operation, heparin was administered, which included an arterial intrathecal injection of 2000 units and an intravenous injection of 3500 units.
patient: alright.
doctor: after the angiography, we prescribed you aspirin 100 mg per day, tigraylo 90 mg once every 12 h, and enoxaparin sodium 0.4 ml once every 12 h subcutaneously for 3 days. your chest distress and shortness of breath had relieved. however, on the third day after the operation, you were diagnosed with hematochezia without abdominal pain.
patient: oh, i see.
doctor: during the physical examination, we found mild abdominal tenderness, especially in your left lower quadrant, and some signs indicative of peritoneal irritation. there was also a neoplasm-like mucous clot connected to your bowel in the anus. we conducted some laboratory tests which showed declined levels of hemoglobin 102 gl, prolonged prothrombin time 13.4 s, and an international normalized ratio of 1.2.
patient: what does that mean?
doctor: these results indicate some issues with your blood clotting. moving on, we performed a colonoscopy and found a submucosal mass in your sigmoid colon, covered with a partially ruptured mucous membrane and some clots in the cavity, causing obstruction. an abdominal ct scan showed a submucosal hematoma in the sigmoid colon, and the density of the mass did not significantly change on an enhanced ct scan. the left flexure of the colon was also thick, which could be another hematoma.
patient: so, whats the treatment for this?
doctor: we tried conservative treatment, which included stopping your anticoagulant medications, providing total parenteral nutrition, and monitoring your condition. however, your clinical symptoms did not resolve with this approach. we will continue to evaluate your condition and discuss further treatment options with you.
patient: thank you, doctor, for explaining all this to me. i hope we can find a solution soon.
Reference SOAP:

o: initial examination post-admission led to a diagnosis of coronary atherosclerotic heart disease. treatment included coronary angiography, stent implantation, and administration of heparin 2000 units arterial intrathecal and 3500 units intravenous. post-procedure medications were aspirin 100 mgday, tigraylo 90 mg every 12 hours, and enoxaparin sodium 0.4 ml every 12 hours subcutaneously for 3 days. on the third day post-operation, the patient developed hematochezia. examination revealed mild abdominal tenderness in the left lower quadrant, peritoneal irritation signs, and a neoplasm-like mucous clot in the anus. lab tests showed hemoglobin at 102 gl normal: 120-160 gl, prothrombin time 13.4 s normal: 11-13.5 s, and inr 1.2. colonoscopy identified a submucosal mass in the sigmoid colon with a partially ruptured mucous membrane. abdominal ct scan confirmed a submucosal hematoma in the sigmoid colon and thickening at the left flexure of the colon.
a: the primary diagnosis is coronary atherosclerotic heart disease, complicated by post-operative hematochezia likely due to anticoagulation therapy. differential diagnosis includes gastrointestinal neoplasm versus hematoma secondary to anticoagulation. the prognosis depends on the management of the gastrointestinal complications and the underlying heart disease.
p: the initial management included discontinuation of anticoagulants, administration of total parenteral nutrition, and close monitoring. given the lack of resolution of clinical symptoms with conservative treatment, further evaluation and possible intervention for the sigmoid colon issue are planned. continued cardiovascular management with adjustments to anticoagulation therapy will be necessary, considering the gastrointestinal risks. patient education regarding signs of gastrointestinal bleeding and the importance of follow-up appointments will be emphasized. referral to gastroenterology for further assessment and management of the sigmoid colon condition is indicated.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i understand you are a 64-year-old postmenopausal woman who was referred to our hospital after your first screening colonoscopy revealed an adenocarcinoma. is that correct?
patient: yes, thats correct.
doctor: based on the immunohistochemistry ihc of the colonic lesion, it was positive for ck-7, gata-3, and er, weakly positive for moc-31, and negative for ck-20, cd-x2, pr, pax-8, sox-10, cd45, chromogranin, synaptophysin, and ttf-1. these findings are consistent with a breast primary. were you experiencing any symptoms or palpable masses before the colonoscopy?
patient: no, i was asymptomatic and didnt feel any masses or lymphadenopathy.
doctor: i see. you mentioned having a surgical history of hysterectomy secondary to symptomatic fibroids. is your family history negative for cancers?
patient: yes, no one in my family has had cancer.
doctor: okay. i noticed that you had a screening mammography a month prior, which came back normal. however, a computerized tomography ct of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis in august 2015 showed osteolytic thoracic vertebral and pelvic lesions, as well as bilateral axillary adenopathy measuring up to 1.4 cm on the right and 1.1 cm on the left. a positron emission tomography pet ct in october 2015 revealed metabolic activity in the right axilla and patchy radiotracer uptake involving the vertebral column corresponding to the ct findings. are you following me so far?
patient: yes, i am.
doctor: in november 2015, a fine needle aspiration fna of the right axillary lymph node was performed but came back negative for malignancy. your cea, ca 19-9, and ca-125 levels were all within normal limits 2.08 ngml, 1 uml, and 6.4 uml, respectively. were you aware of these test results?
patient: yes, i knew about those results.
doctor: you started seeing an oncologist in march 2016 and were given anastrozole until further workup was done. a repeat mammography and breast ultrasound showed only bilateral axillary lymphadenopathy. a bone biopsy of a right sacral lesion confirmed metastatic breast invasive ductal carcinoma with ihc positive for ck-7, gata-3, er, and pr but negative for cd45. do you have any questions about your diagnosis?
patient: no, i think i understand everything.
doctor: as a follow-up, we will need to closely monitor your condition and schedule regular appointments with your oncologist. they will discuss further treatment options with you. make sure to report any new symptoms or concerns during your visits.
patient: okay, i will make sure to do that.
doctor: its important to maintain a strong support system during this time, so feel free to include your family in the discussions with your healthcare team. were here to help you through this process.
patient: thank you, i appreciate your support.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient is a 64-year-old postmenopausal woman who was asymptomatic prior to a screening colonoscopy that revealed an adenocarcinoma. she has a surgical history of hysterectomy due to symptomatic fibroids and no family history of cancer. she was unaware of any symptoms or palpable masses before the colonoscopy.
o: immunohistochemistry of the colonic lesion showed positive results for ck-7, gata-3, and er, weakly positive for moc-31, and negative for ck-20, cd-x2, pr, pax-8, sox-10, cd45, chromogranin, synaptophysin, and ttf-1, suggesting a breast primary. screening mammography was normal. ct and pet-ct scans showed osteolytic lesions in thoracic vertebrae and pelvis, and bilateral axillary adenopathy. fine needle aspiration of the right axillary lymph node was negative for malignancy. cea, ca 19-9, and ca-125 levels were within normal limits. a bone biopsy confirmed metastatic breast invasive ductal carcinoma.
a: primary diagnosis is metastatic breast invasive ductal carcinoma, initially presenting as an adenocarcinoma detected during a colonoscopy. the immunohistochemistry and imaging studies support the diagnosis of a breast primary with metastasis to bone and lymph nodes.
p: the patient will continue regular follow-ups with the oncologist to monitor the condition and discuss treatment options. anastrozole therapy will be continued until further assessment. the patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns during her visits and to maintain a strong support system, involving her family in discussions with her healthcare team. regular imaging and lab tests will be scheduled to monitor the progression or regression of the disease.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, how can i help you today?
patient: hi, ive been having pain and swelling in my right submandibular region for about 10 days now.
doctor: i see. have you noticed any particular patterns to the pain and swelling?
patient: yeah, the swelling and pain seems to be intermittent during meals, but it resolves after i finish eating. i also have unpleasant sensations when eating sour or acidic food.
doctor: thank you for providing that information. lets proceed with a clinical examination. 
doctor examines patient
doctor: i can see the swelling on your right submandibular region, extraorally. there doesnt appear to be any discharge associated with the swelling. im going to perform a bimanual palpation now.
doctor performs bimanual palpation
doctor: i can feel a firm swelling in the posterior floor of your mouth. based on my assessment, i believe you have right submandibular salivary gland sialolithiasis. well need a computed tomography ct scan to confirm this diagnosis.
patient: okay, so what happens if the ct scan confirms the diagnosis?
doctor: if the diagnosis is confirmed, well need to surgically remove the gland. the surgery will involve making a risdon incision about 3 to 4 cm below your mandible. well identify and protect your marginal mandibular nerve and remove the submandibular gland from the mylohyoid muscle. then, well divide and ligate the submandibular duct to remove the gland along with the calculi. in your case, we found a 7 mm spherical formation.
patient: will there be any postoperative complications?
doctor: well place a suction drain and close the wound in layers to minimize the risk of complications. its essential to attend your follow-up evaluations to monitor your recovery and ensure there are no postoperative complications. 
patient: alright, thank you for explaining everything. ill go ahead with the ct scan and surgery if necessary.
doctor: youre welcome. ill make sure to provide you with all the information and support you need during the process. dont hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or concerns.
