o: clinical examination revealed visible swelling in the right submandibular region without any discharge. bimanual palpation identified a firm swelling in the posterior floor of the mouth. a preliminary diagnosis of right submandibular salivary gland sialolithiasis was made, pending confirmation via computed tomography ct scan. the suspected calculi measured approximately 7 mm.
a: the primary diagnosis is right submandibular salivary gland sialolithiasis, based on the clinical findings and patients symptoms. differential diagnoses could include other causes of salivary gland swelling such as infections or tumors, but these are less likely given the described symptoms and clinical findings.
p: the management plan includes obtaining a ct scan to confirm the diagnosis. if confirmed, surgical removal of the submandibular gland will be necessary. the procedure will involve a risdon incision, with careful handling of the marginal mandibular nerve and division of the submandibular duct. postoperative care will include placement of a suction drain and layered wound closure to minimize complications. the patient will be scheduled for follow-up evaluations to monitor recovery. education regarding the procedure and postoperative care will be provided to ensure the patients understanding and compliance.

patient: no, i dont. i do use an albuterol inhaler as needed though.
doctor: thats helpful to know. your pah was diagnosed seven years ago, with a reported pulmonary artery pressure of 8039 mmhg, mean pa pressure of 56 mmhg, pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 12 mmhg, and cardiac output by thermodilution of 3.17 lmin. your pulmonary function tests at that time showed a forced vital capacity fvc of 3.06 l 75 predicted and a diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide dlco of 19.61 mlminmm hg 66 predicted. you were treated with dual therapy, tadalafil and macitentan, for pah and were able to wean from oxygen supplementation. how has this treatment been working for you?
patient: it worked well for a while, but recently ive been feeling worse.
doctor: i see. your ild was considered mild, and you didnt require supplemental oxygen at rest or with exertion. you were treated with mycophenolate mofetil for a year after your initial diagnosis. however, you discontinued this medication about 6 years ago due to fear of reactivating remote lyme infection after reading about chronic lyme disease on the internet. is that correct?
patient: yes, thats right.
doctor: your medical records indicate that you had been stable on your regimen of tadalafil and macitentan until 3 months ago when you began to experience rapidly progressive dyspnea and new onset hypoxemia. a recent right heart catheterization rhc revealed that your pah had worsened, with a mean pa pressure of 72 mmhg and a new drop in cardiac index 1.7 lminm2. as a result, you were started on subcutaneous treprostinil. how have you been feeling since starting this new medication?
patient: im still not feeling great. my breathing has been getting worse, and the cough hasnt gone away.

Dialogue:
doctor: good morning what brings you in today?
patient: hi, doctor. ive been feeling sick for the past four days. ive had a fever, muscle pain, and vomiting. ive also noticed ive been drinking a lot of water, peeing a lot, waking up at night to pee, and losing weight for about a month now.
doctor: i see. do you have any prior underlying diseases? 
patient: no, i dont have any underlying diseases.
doctor: what about your family history? is there any history of diabetes mellitus in your family?
patient: no, theres no family history of diabetes.
doctor: okay, and do you use tobacco, alcohol, or any illicit drugs?
patient: no, i dont use any of those.
doctor: alright. lets check your vital signs. your blood pressure is 11578 mm hg, your temperature is 36.6c, and your pulse rate is 96 beats per min. you appear to be mildly dehydrated.
patient: oh, okay.
doctor: weve also performed some tests. your venous plasma glucose was recorded at 467 mgdl, and there are wide anion gap metabolic acidosis and high levels of serum beta-hydroxybutyrate present. based on these findings, you have diabetic ketoacidosis dka.
patient: oh, that doesnt sound good.
doctor: dont worry well start treating you right away. weve already given you 1 liter of isotonic saline over one hour, and well continue to administer it at 500 mlhr. well also replete your potassium levels and give you a bolus of insulin, followed by continuous insulin infusion. weve also done an electrocardiogram that showed sinus tachycardia, and a chest x-ray showed no abnormalities.
patient: okay, thank you.
doctor: additionally, weve found that you have a dengue infection based on your laboratory results. a systemic review revealed that you currently have vaginal bleeding. dengue hemorrhagic fever dhf is evidenced by hemoconcentration, thrombocytopenia, and hemorrhagic manifestation in your case.
patient: oh no, thats concerning.
doctor: after six hours of treatment, you mentioned you had chest discomfort and developed puffy eyelids and mild pitting edema in both legs. upon lung examination, we heard fine crepitation in both lungs. a chest x-ray revealed bilateral hilar congestion. these abnormalities occurred after the administration of 3 l of isotonic saline.
patient: what does that mean?
doctor: we detected leakage syndrome, so weve decreased the rate of intravenous fluid from 140 to 60 mlhr. well closely monitor your urine output every hour and manage your fluid balance to be negative. this will help improve your condition.
patient: alright, thank you, doctor.
doctor: youre welcome. with these adjustments, your clinical status should gradually improve. well continue to monitor your progress and make any necessary changes in your treatment. if you have any concerns or questions, feel free to ask.
patient: thank you for your help, doctor. i appreciate it.

o: vital signs show blood pressure at 11578 mm hg, temperature at 36.6c, and pulse rate at 96 bpm, indicating mild dehydration. laboratory tests reveal a venous plasma glucose level of 467 mgdl, wide anion gap metabolic acidosis, and elevated serum beta-hydroxybutyrate, consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis dka. an electrocardiogram indicates sinus tachycardia, and a chest x-ray is normal. additional tests confirm a dengue infection with features of dengue hemorrhagic fever dhf, including hemoconcentration, thrombocytopenia, and vaginal bleeding. after treatment initiation, the patient developed chest discomfort, puffy eyelids, and mild pitting edema in both legs, with bilateral hilar congestion on a follow-up chest x-ray.
a: the primary diagnosis is diabetic ketoacidosis, complicated by newly diagnosed diabetes mellitus. concurrently, the patient is diagnosed with dengue hemorrhagic fever. the patients symptoms of chest discomfort and edema following fluid administration suggest fluid overload, possibly leading to leakage syndrome.
p: the management plan includes continued administration of isotonic saline at a reduced rate of 60 mlhr, potassium repletion, and insulin therapy with a bolus followed by continuous infusion. fluid balance will be closely monitored to maintain a negative balance, and urine output will be checked hourly. the patient will be educated on the signs and symptoms of diabetes and its management, including dietary recommendations. referral to an endocrinologist for diabetes management and follow-up on dengue treatment with an infectious disease specialist is planned. compliance with the treatment regimen and close monitoring in the hospital setting will be crucial for recovery.

Dialogue:
doctor: hi there i see youve presented with hoarseness and dysphagia for the past three months following an upper respiratory infection. can you tell me more about your symptoms?
patient: yeah, my voice has been really hoarse, and ive had trouble swallowing too.
doctor: i understand. i also noticed in your past medical history that you had invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast, which was er positive, pr negative, and her2 negative. you were treated with a mastectomy two years prior to this presentation. is that correct?
patient: yes, thats right.
doctor: during the clinical examination, we found paralysis of your right vocal cord. we also performed a ct scan of your neck, which revealed an enlarged thyroid gland with multiple bilateral thyroid nodules. have you experienced any other symptoms?
patient: no, not really. just the hoarseness and difficulty swallowing.
doctor: okay. we performed a fine needle aspiration fna of a right-sided 3.5 cm thyroid nodule, which was initially diagnosed as atypia of undetermined significance, falling under bethesda category iii. we did a repeat fna three months later, and it yielded a diagnosis of benign follicular nodule, which is bethesda category ii. 
patient: i see.
doctor: due to your persistent hoarseness and compressive symptoms, as well as the atypical findings on the initial fna, we decided to proceed with a right thyroid lobectomy and a right vocal cord injection. intraoperatively, we observed that your right thyroid lobe was moderately enlarged with multiple nodules but no evidence of extrathyroidal extension.
patient: oh, okay.
doctor: the right lobectomy specimen measured 4.6 cm in greatest dimension and weighed 16 grams. upon further examination, we found multiple variably sized brown gelatinous nodules with focal areas of hemorrhage and cystic change in the thyroid parenchyma.
patient: what does that mean?
doctor: the histologic examination revealed evidence of nodular thyroid hyperplasia. we also found multiple scattered subcentimeter foci of metastatic breast carcinoma, which were present in 7 out of the 16 submitted tissue sections. most of these smaller metastatic foci measured around 1 millimeter each and consisted of irregularly shaped nests of epithelioid tumor cells between thyroid follicles.
patient: oh, no.
doctor: the largest metastatic focus measured 0.6 cm and was comprised of tumor cell nests arranged along the periphery of a sclerotic stroma with cords of tumor cells showing retraction artifact. these areas resembled the dense amyloid-type stroma often seen in medullary thyroid carcinoma mtc. additionally, we observed numerous areas of rimming of the thyroid follicles by the tumor cells, which mimicked the appearance of c cell hyperplasia cch.
patient: what should i do now?
doctor: well need to discuss your treatment options and closely monitor your condition. well work together to determine the best course of action moving forward. its important to stay vigilant and report any new or worsening symptoms to your healthcare team.
patient: alright, thank you for explaining everything to me. ill make sure to keep in touch with my healthcare team.
Reference SOAP:

a: the primary diagnosis is metastatic breast carcinoma to the thyroid, presenting with nodular thyroid hyperplasia and right vocal cord paralysis. differential diagnosis initially included benign thyroid nodules and potential primary thyroid malignancies, which were ruled out by histopathological examination. the presence of metastatic breast carcinoma in the thyroid is a significant finding, indicating systemic spread.
p: the management plan includes close monitoring of the patients condition with regular follow-ups to assess for any progression of metastatic disease or emergence of new symptoms. the patient will be referred to oncology for further evaluation and management of metastatic breast carcinoma. symptomatic treatment for hoarseness and dysphagia, including possible speech therapy, will be considered. the patient is advised to maintain regular communication with the healthcare team and report any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i wanted to discuss your current situation and review your surgical history with you. can you tell me what brought you to our facility initially?
patient: yes, i came in with a strangulated large bowel and ventral hernia, 10 years after my lagb procedure.
doctor: thats correct. at that time, you were still morbidly obese and had been lost to follow-up. we performed an emergency surgical hernia repair, which included resection of the necrotic transverse colon, and created a loop ileostomy. one year later, you presented with a lagb port-site infection. do you remember what we did during that time?
patient: yes, you removed the port and sutured the tubing to my abdominal wall.
doctor: exactly. during both admissions, we observed the lagb tubing in a stable position adjacent to the transverse colon on the ct scans, with no concerns for penetration. six months after the port-site infection, we elected to reverse the ileostomy. however, there were complications in the early post-operative period. can you tell me about those symptoms?
patient: i remember feeling really sick and ended up having abdominal sepsis.
doctor: yes, thats correct. the abdominal ct demonstrated transection of the remaining proximal transverse colon by the lagb tubing. due to this, we had to perform a right hemicolectomy, which involved the removal of the gastric band and tubing, and we created an end ileostomy. 
patient: oh, i see. so, whats the plan moving forward, doctor?
doctor: our main focus now is to ensure proper healing and monitor for any complications. well keep a close eye on your progress and address any issues that may arise.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate all the care youve provided, and ill make sure to follow your instructions and communicate any concerns.
doctor: youre welcome. remember that your health and well-being are our top priorities. dont hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or need assistance. were here to help.

o: past surgical interventions include emergency surgical hernia repair with resection of necrotic transverse colon and creation of a loop ileostomy, removal of an infected lagb port, and a right hemicolectomy with removal of the gastric band and tubing, followed by creation of an end ileostomy. ct scans previously showed lagb tubing in a stable position without penetration concerns. recent complications include abdominal sepsis due to transection of the transverse colon by lagb tubing.
a: the primary diagnosis is complications from lagb, including abdominal sepsis and mechanical bowel obstruction due to transection by the lagb tubing. differential diagnoses previously considered include hernia and infection related to surgical sites and devices.
p: the management plan includes close monitoring for complications and ensuring proper healing post-recent surgeries. the patient is advised to follow post-operative care instructions closely and report any unusual symptoms or concerns. regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and address any arising issues. the patient is encouraged to maintain communication with the healthcare team to facilitate ongoing care and support.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i see youve presented to the retina service today. can you tell me a bit about what brought you here?
patient: hi, doctor. ive been experiencing metamophopsia and reduced visual acuity in both of my eyes. its been gradually worsening over the past four months.
doctor: im sorry to hear that. can you tell me about your past medical history?
patient: well, i suffer from beta thalassemia intermedia and ive been receiving blood transfusions biweekly and chelation therapy for the past 14 years. my chelation therapy includes dfo, which i take 5 times a week by an 8-hourly subcutaneous infusion, and deferiprone, which i take daily. my ferritin level is within normal limits. i also have hypothyroidism and im treated with levothyroxine. i dont have any history of color or peripheral vision changes or hearing impairment.
doctor: thank you for sharing your medical history. lets get to the examination. your best corrected visual acuity is 2025 in your right eye and 2022 in your left eye. slit lamp biomicroscopy did not reveal any pathology in the anterior segment, and your intraocular pressure measured by applanation tonometry is 14 mmhg in both eyes. 
patient: okay, what about my dilated fundus examination?
doctor: your dilated fundus examination showed a yellowish roundish macular lesion surrounded by rpe changes, as well as angioid streaks emanating from the optic disc sparing the macula in both eyes. the retinal vasculature appeared normal.
patient: what did the spectral-domain optical coherence tomography show?
doctor: the sd-oct revealed a subfoveal hyperreflective deposit above the level of the rpe corresponding to the lesion observed fundoscopically. additionally, mild stippling was noticed in the macular area in fundus autofluorescence.
patient: and the fluoroscein angiography?
doctor: fluoroscein angiography revealed staining of the macular lesion in the late phases of the angiogram. based on your history and examination, we need to evaluate for possible dfo retinopathy in your case.
patient: how will you do that?
doctor: we will perform electrophysiology testing, specifically a full-field electroretinogram, to assess your retinal function and determine if dfo retinopathy is present.
patient: alright, doctor. thank you for explaining everything so thoroughly. what should i do for follow-up?
doctor: once we have the results of your electrophysiology testing, we will discuss the findings and determine the appropriate course of treatment and follow-up care. please make sure to schedule a follow-up appointment after the test.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate your help.

o: best corrected visual acuity was 2025 in the right eye and 2022 in the left eye. slit lamp biomicroscopy showed no anterior segment pathology intraocular pressure was 14 mmhg in both eyes. dilated fundus examination revealed a yellowish macular lesion with surrounding rpe changes and angioid streaks, sparing the macula. sd-oct showed a subfoveal hyperreflective deposit and mild stippling in the macular area. fluoroscein angiography indicated staining of the macular lesion in late phases. ferritin levels are within normal limits.
a: the primary assessment is a suspected dfo retinopathy given the patients history of chelation therapy and ocular findings. differential diagnosis could include other causes of macular degeneration, but the specific history and imaging findings point towards dfo retinopathy.
p: plan to perform a full-field electroretinogram to assess retinal function and confirm dfo retinopathy. based on the results, treatment options and follow-up care will be discussed. the patient is advised to schedule a follow-up appointment after the electrophysiology testing to review results and plan further management. continuation of current systemic treatments for beta thalassemia intermedia and hypothyroidism should be maintained.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, how can i help you today?
patient: hi, doc. ive been having this typical chest pain for a week now, and it worsened about 3 hours before i came here. i also have dyspnea, nausea, and sweating.
doctor: i see. let me check your vitals first. your blood pressure is 11080 mmhg, heart rate is 54 beatsminute, respiratory rate is 22 timesminute, and temperature is 37 c. all of these are within normal limits. lets also do a neurological examination. 
patient: sure, doc.
doctor: your neurological examination is unremarkable. do you have any history of medical conditions?
patient: yes, i have a history of dyslipidemia and hypertension. but no diabetes. my father also had hypertension.
doctor: alright. do you smoke or drink alcohol?
patient: i quit smoking 17 months ago, and i dont drink alcohol.
doctor: good to hear. what medications are you currently taking?
patient: im on captopril, bisoprolol, aspirin, clopidogrel, warfarin, isosorbide dinitrate isdn, and atorvastatin.
doctor: have you been compliant with your warfarin regimen?
patient: to be honest, i havent been very compliant, especially a few weeks after hospital discharge and at 7 and 13 months before this admission.
doctor: i understand. we did an electrocardiography and it showed sinus rhythm of 54 beatsminute, left ventricular hypertrophy, horizontal st-segment depression, and t wave inversion at leads i, avl, and v46. a biphasic t wave was observed at lead v23. 
patient: hmm, what does that mean?
doctor: it indicates some abnormalities in your hearts electrical activity. we also checked your laboratory results. your international normalized ratio inr is suboptimal at 1.28. the level of triglycerides is 273 mgdl low-density lipoprotein ldl and high-density lipoprotein hdl levels are within normal limits. the complete blood count and levels of urea, creatinine, aspartate aminotransferase ast, alanine aminotransferase alt, creatine kinasemyocardial band ck-mb, and high-sensitivity troponin hs-troponin t are all normal.
patient: so, whats the plan, doc?
doctor: weve given you a loading dose of aspirin and clopidogrel along with fondaparinux to alleviate your symptoms. we also performed a coronary angiography cag which showed an ectatic and turbulent mid-distal right coronary artery rca and slow flow.
patient: what should i do now?
doctor: its important to continue your medications and be more compliant with your warfarin regimen. well closely monitor your condition and consider further treatment options if necessary. make sure to attend your follow-up appointments.
patient: alright, doc. ill make sure to follow your instructions. thank you.
doctor: youre welcome. take care and dont hesitate to contact us if your symptoms worsen or you have any concerns.

o: vital signs are within normal limits: blood pressure 11080 mmhg, heart rate 54 bpm, respiratory rate 22min, and temperature 37 c. neurological examination is unremarkable. electrocardiography shows sinus rhythm, left ventricular hypertrophy, horizontal st-segment depression, t wave inversion at leads i, avl, v46, and biphasic t waves at v23. laboratory findings reveal a suboptimal inr of 1.28, elevated triglycerides at 273 mgdl, with normal ldl, hdl, complete blood count, urea, creatinine, ast, alt, ck-mb, and hs-troponin t levels. coronary angiography indicates an ectatic and turbulent mid-distal right coronary artery with slow flow.
a: the patient presents with unstable angina, likely secondary to ectatic coronary artery disease, compounded by non-compliance with anticoagulant therapy warfarin. differential diagnoses include acute coronary syndrome and myocardial infarction, although normal hs-troponin t levels are reassuring against acute myocardial injury.
p: management includes a loading dose of aspirin and clopidogrel, administration of fondaparinux, and strict adherence to the existing medication regimen, especially warfarin, with close monitoring of inr levels. the patient is advised to attend regular follow-up appointments for further evaluation and management, including potential adjustments in therapy based on symptomatic response and diagnostic findings. education on the importance of medication compliance and lifestyle modification for cardiovascular risk reduction is emphasized.

Dialogue:
doctor: hi there, i understand you originally had a laparoscopic adjustable gastric band 4 years ago. what brings you to the bariatric surgery clinic today?
patient: yeah, thats right. lately, ive had trouble tolerating solid foods.
doctor: i see. we did a work-up and found that your gastric band is still in good position, but you have oesophagitis and gastritis, causing swelling of the mucosa at the band site. we removed the fluid from the reservoir and treated you conservatively with anti-reflux medication and a full liquid diet. how have your symptoms been after 2 weeks of treatment?
patient: theyve improved a lot, thanks
doctor: im glad to hear that. after careful consideration, you decided to undergo revisional surgery to convert the laparoscopic adjustable gastric band to a laparoscopic vertical sleeve gastrectomy. you went through the appropriate multidisciplinary team and were found to be a suitable candidate for surgery. the surgery went well, and there were no complications. you were discharged on post-operative day 3. how have you been feeling since then?
patient: ive been okay, but on post-operative day 12, i started feeling lightheaded and short of breath, so i went to the hospital.
doctor: yes, you were readmitted to an outside tertiary care hospital and found to have leukocytosis, with a high white blood cell count of 18,000 cells l1. a ct scan with intravenous contrast was performed, and you were diagnosed with a pulmonary embolism. you were immediately transferred to our center for definitive care.
patient: thats right, and when i arrived here, you all reviewed my ct films.
doctor: yes, our radiologists noticed there was air and a faint suggestion of oral contrast outside of the suture line. given this finding, we ordered an upper gastrointestinal ugi evaluation. during the early phase, no leak was observed, partly due to the slow passage of 30 ml oral non-ionic contrast.
patient: oh, i see.
doctor: some residual contrast from the outside hospital ct was present in the transverse and descending colon. only after delayed imaging and administration of additional non-ionic contrast were we able to determine the situation more accurately.
patient: so, whats the next step, then?
doctor: we will continue to monitor your condition closely and provide appropriate treatment. be sure to follow up with us regularly and report any new or worsening symptoms.
patient: okay, thank you for keeping me informed and taking care of me.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient, who previously underwent laparoscopic adjustable gastric band surgery 4 years ago, presented with difficulty tolerating solid foods. after initial conservative treatment for oesophagitis and gastritis, symptoms improved. the patient then underwent conversion to laparoscopic vertical sleeve gastrectomy. post-operative day 12, the patient experienced lightheadedness and shortness of breath.
o: post-surgery, the patient was readmitted with leukocytosis wbc 18,000 cells l1 and diagnosed with a pulmonary embolism. ct scan revealed air and possible oral contrast outside the suture line, but initial ugi evaluation showed no leak. delayed imaging confirmed the diagnosis after additional contrast administration.
a: primary diagnosis is post-operative complications following bariatric surgery, including pulmonary embolism and potential gastrointestinal leak. differential diagnosis included surgical site infection or inflammation due to initial findings of leukocytosis and imaging results.
p: the patient will continue to be closely monitored with regular follow-ups to assess and manage post-operative complications. treatment includes anticoagulation therapy for pulmonary embolism and potential intervention for gastrointestinal leak if confirmed. patient education on symptom monitoring and adherence to follow-up appointments is crucial for effective management.

Dialogue:
doctor: congratulations on your newborn baby girl she was delivered via vaginal delivery at 40 weeks and 5 days gestational age, right?
mother: yes, thats correct.
doctor: i understand that you, the 29-year-old mother, had an uncomplicated pregnancy. is that correct?
mother: yes, everything went smoothly.
doctor: good to hear. the physical exam at birth was unremarkable, and all her growth parameters were proportionate and appropriate for her gestational age.
mother: thats a relief. thank you.
doctor: we enrolled your baby in the well-baby cohort of the babyseq project. she was randomized to undergo whole-exome sequencing with analysis limited to genes strongly associated with pediatric-onset disorders.
mother: oh, okay. what does that mean?
doctor: it means we conducted a genetic test to check for any potential health issues that could arise during her childhood. the good news is that there were no major health concerns, surgeries, or hospitalizations between her well-baby nursery discharge and the time genomic results were reported at 2.5 months of age.
mother: thats great to hear.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello pt, how can i help you today?
pt: hey doc, ive been having some issues with memory lately. ive been experiencing recurrent amnesia when i wake up, with disorientation and repetitive questioning, which only lasts for a few minutes.
doctor: i see, any other symptoms youve been experiencing?
pt: yeah, ive also had these 30-second trance-like episodes during the day. my partner reported that sometimes i make repetitive swallowing movements, followed by disorientation and repetitive questioning. these episodes occur in clusters of up to seven per day.
doctor: are you aware of these episodes when they happen?
pt: well, im aware of some of them, but not all. i do have partial recollection of being unable to remember things during those times.
doctor: have you noticed any other changes in your memory?
pt: yes, ive noticed that i lose newly acquired memories over days, and i have difficulty recalling autobiographical events from my adulthood and familiar routes.
doctor: have you experienced any other symptoms along with these memory issues?
pt: ive developed olfactory hallucinations that smell like candy floss, which can last for up to a day and seem to happen independently of the amnestic episodes. i also feel like my sense of smell has become a bit blunted. plus, ive been having headaches with migrainous features, postural arm tremor, tingling in my legs, malaise, and low mood.
doctor: thank you for sharing that information. can you tell me about your medical history?
pt: my medical history is mostly unremarkable, but i did have symptoms of depression last year and a history of heavy alcohol use in the past.
doctor: based on your symptoms, we conducted several tests and investigations. your initial brain mri showed subtly increased t2 signal in the right hippocampus, even in the absence of any recent episodes. your eeg was normal, and the clinical examination revealed no focal neurological signs. we made an initial clinical diagnosis of tea.
doctor: we started treating you with lamotrigine, starting at 25 mg and gradually increasing it up to 100 mg twice a day. this resolved your trance-like and amnestic attacks. however, your other symptoms, such as headaches, tingling sensation in your limbs, and olfactory hallucinations, still persist.
pt: oh, okay. so whats the next step in my treatment plan?
doctor: since the lamotrigine has resolved your amnestic attacks, we will continue monitoring your progress and adjust the treatment as needed. we will also further investigate your other symptoms to find the best course of action. in the meantime, please keep track of your symptoms and report any changes to us.
pt: sounds good, doc. i appreciate your help.
doctor: youre welcome, pt. well work together to manage your symptoms, and dont hesitate to reach out if you have any concerns.
Reference SOAP:
s: patient reports recurrent amnesia upon waking with disorientation and repetitive questioning, lasting a few minutes. additionally, experiences 30-second trance-like episodes during the day, sometimes with repetitive swallowing movements, followed by disorientation and repetitive questioning, occurring in clusters of up to seven per day. patient has partial recollection of these episodes. reports loss of newly acquired memories, difficulty recalling autobiographical events, and familiar routes. also experiences olfactory hallucinations smelling like candy floss, blunted sense of smell, headaches with migrainous features, postural arm tremor, tingling in legs, malaise, and low mood. medical history includes depression and heavy alcohol use.
o: brain mri showed subtly increased t2 signal in the right hippocampus. eeg was normal. clinical examination revealed no focal neurological signs. patient has been on lamotrigine, starting at 25 mg and increased to 100 mg twice a day, which resolved the trance-like and amnestic attacks. other symptoms persist.
a: primary diagnosis of transient epileptic amnesia tea based on clinical presentation and response to lamotrigine. differential diagnoses could include other forms of epilepsy, transient ischemic attacks, or psychological factors contributing to memory loss. the prognosis is generally favorable with appropriate management of epilepsy, but ongoing monitoring is required due to the complexity of symptoms.
p: continue lamotrigine at the current dosage and monitor patients response. further investigate persistent symptoms like headaches, tingling, and olfactory hallucinations to refine treatment. encourage patient to keep a symptom diary for better management and follow-up. schedule regular follow-up appointments to monitor progress and adjust treatment as necessary. educate patient on the importance of medication adherence and reporting new or worsening symptoms.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, how can i help you today?
patient: hi, ive been experiencing constant blurry vision in my left eye for about 6 weeks now.
doctor: i see. can you tell me about your past medical history?
patient: yeah, i have cystic fibrosis, which has led to insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, chronic sinusitis, hypertension, iron deficiency anemia, and obstructive sleep apnea.
doctor: have you had any surgeries in the past?
patient: i had sinus surgery about 7 months ago. it involved bilateral maxillary antrostomies, ethmoidectomies, sphenoidectomies, and frontal sinusotomies.
doctor: thank you for the information. what medications are you currently taking?
patient: im taking albuterol, azithromycin, itraconazole, insulin, lisinopril, pancreatic enzymes, and sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim.
doctor: do you use tobacco or any drugs?
patient: no, i dont.
doctor: alright. at the time of presentation, your visual acuity was 2020 in both eyes, intraocular pressure was 18 od and 16 os, and your pupils were 4 mm and reactive in both eyes. your anterior exam was unremarkable, but your posterior exam in the left eye showed intraretinal hemorrhages along the nerve fiber layer with associated retinal thickening in the inferior macula, consistent with a brvo.
patient: oh, i see.
doctor: we also performed optical coherence tomography which revealed mild intraretinal and trace subfoveal fluid in your left eye. these findings were confirmed with a fluorescein angiogram, which showed delayed venous filling in the inferior venous arcade.
patient: okay, so what does that mean?
doctor: it means there might be an issue with the blood vessels in your eye. your blood pressure readings have been consistently between 110 and 145 systolic over 70-85 diastolic in the past year, and your most recent hemoglobin a1c was 6.9 4 months prior to presentation. we also did a laboratory workup.
patient: what did the lab results show?
doctor: the complete blood cell count, vitamin a and d levels, prothrombin time, thrombin time, antithrombin activity, protein c and s activity, cardiolipins, dilute russells viper venom time, homocysteine level, and a negative prothrombin g20210a mutation were all normal. your complete metabolic panel showed a mild elevation in glucose of 121 mgdl, and your antinuclear antibody was weakly elevated at 2.
patient: what does that mean for me?
doctor: the results indicate that there might be an issue with your blood vessels related to your blurry vision. we will need to monitor your blood pressure and glucose levels closely and consider further testing or treatment options based on your progress.
patient: alright, thank you for the information.
doctor: youre welcome. if you have any further concerns or if your symptoms worsen, please dont hesitate to contact us.

a: primary diagnosis is branch retinal vein occlusion brvo in the left eye, likely exacerbated by underlying hypertension and diabetes mellitus. differential diagnoses could include diabetic retinopathy or other vascular occlusive disorders. the prognosis depends on the management of underlying conditions and response to treatment.
p: plan to monitor blood pressure and glucose levels closely. initiate or adjust antihypertensive and diabetic medications as needed. refer to an ophthalmologist for further evaluation and possible intravitreal injections or laser therapy for brvo. educate patient on the importance of controlling blood pressure and blood sugar levels to prevent progression of ocular and systemic complications. schedule follow-up in 1 month to reassess condition and treatment efficacy. encourage patient to report any worsening of symptoms immediately.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i understand you have a past medical history that includes a two-year history of umbilical hernia, diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, gout, chronic kidney disease with proteinuria, diverticulosis, obesity, and osteoarthritis. what brings you to the clinic today?
patient: hi, doctor. over the past two months, ive developed pain in my umbilical hernia. the pain is localized to the periumbilical region and left lower back. it gets worse with food intake, and sometimes i take a 5 mg hydrocodone tablet to relieve it.
doctor: i see. have you experienced any other symptoms in this period?
patient: yes, i have had nausea and lost fifteen pounds because ive been eating less.
doctor: thank you for the information. during your physical examination, we found a 1 cm tender and irreducible mass superior to the umbilicus. we performed a herniorrhaphy, and the gross examination of the surgical specimen did not reveal any masses or lesions. however, the microscopic evaluation showed diffuse infiltration of the connective tissue by malignant cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm.
patient: oh no, that sounds serious. what does that mean?
doctor: there were also focal areas of gland formation with mucin production, which is consistent with adenocarcinoma. immunohistochemistry showed that the neoplastic cells were strongly positive for pancytokeratin and ck7, and negative for ck20, cdx2, ttf-1, and psa.
patient: what do the laboratory findings show?
doctor: your lab results showed elevated levels of ca 19-9 16,590 uml and cea 14.2 ngml. we performed a subsequent computed tomography scan with intravenous contrast, which revealed a 5.0  2.7 cm ill-defined and hypoattenuating mass located in the pancreatic tail and body, with peripancreatic fat infiltration and vascular involvement of the splenic artery and vein.
patient: are there any other findings from the imaging?
doctor: yes, the imaging also showed peritoneal carcinomatosis, multiple ill-defined hypoattenuating lesions in the liver, and enlarged and hypoattenuating pericecal iliac lymph nodes.
patient: how does my current condition compare to my prior scan?
doctor: your prior noncontrast computed tomography scan from four months ago showed an umbilical hernia with fat, but there were no other lesions in the pancreas and abdomen at that time.
patient: what will be the next steps for my treatment, doctor?
doctor: given the findings, we need to discuss your case with a multidisciplinary team to determine the best course of action for your treatment. this may include chemotherapy, radiation, or surgery. we will keep you informed and involve you in the decision-making process.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate your help and guidance during this difficult time.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient, with a history of multiple chronic conditions including diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease, presents with a two-month history of pain in the umbilical hernia region, exacerbated by food intake. the patient also reports associated symptoms of nausea and significant weight loss 15 pounds due to decreased appetite. the patient occasionally uses 5 mg hydrocodone for pain relief.
o: physical examination revealed a 1 cm tender, irreducible mass superior to the umbilicus. surgical intervention herniorrhaphy was performed, and histopathological analysis identified malignant cells consistent with adenocarcinoma. immunohistochemistry results were positive for pancytokeratin and ck7, negative for ck20, cdx2, ttf-1, and psa. lab tests showed elevated ca 19-9 16,590 uml, normal 37 uml and cea 14.2 ngml, normal 0-5 ngml. ct imaging with contrast highlighted a 5.0  2.7 cm mass in the pancreatic tail and body, with vascular involvement and peritoneal carcinomatosis. comparison with a prior ct scan showed progression from an isolated umbilical hernia to extensive abdominal involvement.
a: the primary diagnosis is pancreatic adenocarcinoma with metastasis, indicated by peritoneal carcinomatosis and liver lesions. the rapid progression from an isolated hernia to extensive malignancy is concerning and suggests an aggressive tumor phenotype.
p: the patients management plan will involve consultation with a multidisciplinary team to discuss potential treatments including chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and possibly surgery. the patient will be closely monitored for symptom management and advised on nutritional support to address weight loss. regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess treatment response and adjust the care plan as necessary. the patient will also be provided with psychological support and counseling to help cope with the diagnosis and treatment process.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, can you please tell me about your obstetric history?
patient: ive been pregnant 6 times, had 3 normal deliveries and 2 induced abortions.
doctor: thank you for sharing that. what brings you to our emergency department today?
patient: ive been having an acute and persistent dull pain in the right lower quadrant of my abdomen for the past few hours, and im really worried about it.
doctor: i see. are there any other symptoms youre experiencing, such as sweating, nausea, or vomiting?
patient: yes, ive been having rebound pain, cold sweating, and nausea, but no vomiting. there arent any factors that seem to relieve or aggravate the pain.
doctor: okay. when was your last menstrual cycle?
patient: it was about 7 weeks and 4 days ago.
doctor: do you have a history of pelvic inflammatory disease?
patient: no, i dont.
doctor: can you tell me about your past medical history? have you had any infections or procedures?
patient: i had a human papilloma virus infection, and i received 3 doses of the gardasil vaccination about 7 years ago. i also had an intrauterine device inserted 4 years ago, was diagnosed with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia 3, had a cervical conization procedure 3.5 years ago, and underwent laparoscopic tubal sterilization about 1 year and 4 months ago.
doctor: thank you for sharing that information. during your initial physical examination, we noticed abdominal stiffness and tenderness upon palpation. we also conducted a urine pregnancy test, and it came back positive. a transvaginal ultrasound showed no evidence of intrauterine pregnancy, but we did find a right adnexal mass and minimal ascites. your lab data revealed a serum -hcg level of 15795 million iuml, a white blood cell count of 12300l, and a hemoglobin level of 11.9 gdl.
patient: oh, that doesnt sound good. what does that mean?
doctor: based on your symptoms, clinical signs, imaging, and high level of serum -hcg, we highly suspect an ectopic pregnancy. we will admit you for a surgical intervention tomorrow. however, if you experience any worsening symptoms, such as vomiting, sudden syncope, or hypotension, you need to let us know immediately.
patient: okay, i understand. thank you.
14 hours after admission
patients family member: doctor, my sister just experienced vomiting, sudden syncope, and her blood pressure dropped to 7942 mm hg. whats going on?
doctor: we just received her latest lab test results, and her hemoglobin level has dropped to 8.9 gdl. this, combined with her symptoms, leads us to suspect that her ectopic pregnancy may have ruptured and caused hypovolemic shock. we will need to take her for an immediate surgical intervention to manage this critical situation.
patients family member: thank you for your prompt action, doctor. please do everything you can to help her.

o: physical examination revealed abdominal stiffness and tenderness upon palpation. urine pregnancy test was positive. transvaginal ultrasound showed no intrauterine pregnancy but revealed a right adnexal mass and minimal ascites. lab results indicated a serum -hcg level of 15795 million iuml, white blood cell count of 12300l, and an initial hemoglobin level of 11.9 gdl, which later dropped to 8.9 gdl. the patient experienced vomiting, sudden syncope, and hypotension with a blood pressure of 7942 mm hg.
a: the primary diagnosis is a suspected ruptured ectopic pregnancy, indicated by the clinical signs, imaging results, and lab findings, particularly the elevated -hcg and the presence of a right adnexal mass. differential diagnosis includes other causes of acute abdomen in females, but these are less likely given the imaging and lab results.
p: immediate surgical intervention is planned to manage the suspected ruptured ectopic pregnancy and address the critical situation of hypovolemic shock. the patient will be monitored closely for any further deterioration in her condition. post-operative care will include monitoring of hemoglobin levels and vital signs, pain management, and psychological support due to the traumatic nature of the event. follow-up appointments will be scheduled to ensure proper recovery and to discuss further reproductive health management.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i understand you have a history of asd, developmental delay, and hypotonia. can you tell me about your birth?
patient: yeah, i was born to non-consanguineous caucasian parents at term by caesarean section. i weighed 6 lb, 14 oz at birth.
doctor: thank you. i see that your mother was on citalopram during her pregnancy for the treatment of depression. now, lets discuss your medical history. you were diagnosed with grade five vesicoureteral reflux in infancy with a dysplastic kidney on the left, correct?
patient: yes, thats right.
doctor: you also experienced absence seizures at 3 months of age and again at 9 years. can you tell me more about that?
patient: yeah, i had those seizures, but an eeg at 9 months of age was normal. they did a computed tomography scan of my brain at three months, and it showed delayed myelination.
doctor: i see. your brain mri at two and a half years showed hypoplastic olfactory nerves, a klippel-feil anomaly, and incomplete myelin maturation in the inferior frontal lobes and temporal tips. is that correct?
patient: yes, thats what they told me.
doctor: throughout your childhood, your growth parameters were at or below the third percentile. you were hypotonic, and there was a history of severe constipation. is that accurate?
patient: yes, ive always had trouble with constipation and didnt grow as fast as other kids.
doctor: i also see that you had delayed developmental milestones and were diagnosed with asd at about two and a half years. at around 11 years of age, you experienced symptoms of anxiety and oppositional defiant disorder odd, although no official diagnosis was given. have you tried any medications for these symptoms?
patient: yeah, i tried several anti-anxiety medications, but none of them worked. im currently on resperidone.
doctor: have you received any behavioural therapy for these issues?
patient: yes, ive been in therapy since my asd diagnosis.
doctor: your clinical genetic assessments at 3 and 5 years of age did not identify a specific genetic diagnosis. clinical cma, fragile x testing, and metabolic testing were reported to be normal. however, we have identified a de novo kmt2a frameshift variant, c.6169del p.val2057tyrfs18 supplementary fig. via wgs.
patient: oh, okay.
doctor: based on this information and your clinical features fig., such as microcephaly, hypertrichosis, and your history of growth and developmental delay, hypotonia, constipation, and asd, you have been diagnosed with wiedemann-steiner syndrome wss at the age of 13.
patient: i see. so, what does that mean for me?
doctor: this diagnosis helps us understand your symptoms and challenges better. we will continue to monitor your condition, and its important to maintain your current treatments, such as behavioral therapy and medication. well also discuss any new recommendations or changes to your treatment plan as needed.
patient: okay, thank you for explaining everything.

o: physical examination and historical records indicate microcephaly, hypertrichosis, and a history of growth and developmental delays. clinical genetic assessments, including cma and fragile x testing, were normal. recent whole genome sequencing identified a de novo kmt2a frameshift variant. the patients mother took citalopram during pregnancy.
a: the patient is diagnosed with wiedemann-steiner syndrome wss, characterized by the clinical features and genetic findings. the differential diagnosis includes other genetic syndromes with overlapping features, but the genetic testing supports wss. the patients history of developmental challenges and neurological issues are consistent with this diagnosis.
p: continue current medications, including risperidone, and behavioral therapy. monitor growth and developmental progress regularly. consider consultation with a gastroenterologist for severe constipation management and a neurologist for ongoing neurological assessment. educate the patient and family about wiedemann-steiner syndrome and discuss potential complications and management strategies. regular follow-ups to reassess the treatment efficacy and make adjustments as necessary.

doctor: furthermore, your plasma haptoglobin was undetectable, lactate dehydrogenase ldh was elevated, and the direct coombs test was negative. your anti-streptolysin titers were only marginally elevated.

patient: oh, wow.
doctor: we also conducted a urinalysis, which revealed microscopic erythrocyturia and mild proteinuria. on day 2 of your stay, you received transfusions of red blood cells and platelets.

doctor: despite the transfusions, your hemoglobin hb continued to fall to 48 gl, and your platelet count dropped to 5  109l within 2 days.

doctor: well continue to monitor your condition and adjust your treatment plan as needed. its important to follow up with your healthcare team to ensure the best possible outcome.
patient: alright, thank you, doctor.

Dialogue:
doctor: hi there, how can i help you today?
patient: hi, im 12 years old and ive had a fever, abdominal pain, and painful urination since yesterday.
doctor: i see. have you had any recent illnesses or tested positive for anything?
patient: yeah, i tested positive for covid-19 eight days ago.
doctor: alright, thank you for letting me know. i will need to perform an abdominal examination to better understand your symptoms. is that okay with you?
patient: yes, thats fine.
doctor performs the examination
doctor: your examination findings show that you have superficial and deep tenderness in your right lower abdominal quadrant when i palpate, and localized tenderness when i use percussion. im going to order an abdominal ultrasound to get a clearer picture of whats going on.
ultrasound results come in
doctor: your ultrasound results show findings consistent with acute complicated appendicitis. because of this, we will start you on intravenous antimicrobial treatment, which includes cefotaxime and metronidazole. well also need to take you to the operating room for a laparoscopic appendectomy.
patient: oh, okay. what does the surgery involve?
doctor: a laparoscopic appendectomy is a minimally invasive surgery to remove your inflamed appendix. well make a few small incisions in your abdomen, insert a laparoscope to view the area, and then remove the appendix.
patient: will you test the fluid in my abdomen too?
doctor: yes, we will take a fluid culture during the surgery to identify any bacteria that may be present.
after the surgery
doctor: the surgery went well, and we were able to remove your inflamed appendix. the fluid culture revealed the presence of p. aeruginosa, str. viridans, and gemella morbillorum bacteria. we will continue your antibiotic treatment to ensure a full recovery.
patient: thank you, doctor.
doctor: youre welcome. we will monitor your progress closely, and if you have any concerns or questions, please dont hesitate to ask.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i see youve been admitted to the emergency department with dyspnea and swelling on your hands and face for at least three days. can you tell me more about your symptoms?
patient: yes, ive been having trouble breathing and the swelling has been getting worse. im a nonsmoker and dont have any chronic diseases.
doctor: i understand. due to the worsening dyspnea and hypoxemia, you were initially treated with noninvasive mechanical ventilation. however, since your condition worsened, you were intubated and invasive mechanical ventilation was used. on your physical examination, we auscultated mild crackles bilateral on the lower lung zones. your chest x-ray showed bilateral nonhomogenous infiltration at the middle and lower zones.
patient: oh, that sounds serious.
doctor: at first, your fraction of inhaled oxygenation fio2 was 80 on mechanical ventilation, but your pao2 was 65 mmhg. we applied lung protective mechanical ventilation strategies, fluid replacement, antibiotics, and other medical treatments. over time, your fio2 level decreased, and you were weaned from mechanical ventilation on your fifth day in the icu.
patient: thats good to hear.
doctor: after weaning, we noticed that your oral secretions increased and your left nasolabial sulcus wiped out. on your neurological examination, no abnormal findings were found except for left facial paralysis. we didnt find any pathological issues on your cranial computed tomography ct or cranial magnetic resonance imaging mri.
patient: so, whats causing the facial paralysis?
doctor: you were diagnosed with peripheral facial paralysis pfp and prescribed intravenous steroid treatment of 1 milligram per kilogram methylprednisolone by a neurologist. around the same time, a dermatological lesion occurred. on your dermatologic examination, we detected oedema on your face, pustular lesions on your skin, and a fissure on your tongue. a labium mucosal biopsy was taken, and mucositis was reported.
patient: i see.
doctor: when we talked about your symptoms, you informed us that you had recurrent and spontaneous facial paralysis in previous years. based on your medical history, signs of orofacial oedema, fissure on the tongue, and pfp, you were diagnosed with mrs.
patient: i remember having those symptoms before.
doctor: given your diagnosis, you were transferred from the icu to the department of neurology for further care and treatment. we will continue to monitor your progress and adjust your treatment plan as needed.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate your help.
Reference SOAP:

a: the patient was diagnosed with peripheral facial paralysis pfp and melkersson-rosenthal syndrome mrs, indicated by orofacial oedema, fissure on the tongue, and recurrent facial paralysis. the differential diagnosis initially included other causes of facial swelling and paralysis, but these were ruled out by imaging and clinical findings.
p: the patient was prescribed intravenous methylprednisolone 1 mgkg for pfp and transferred to the neurology department for ongoing management of mrs. the treatment plan includes monitoring, adjustment of therapies as needed, and supportive care for symptoms of mucositis and respiratory distress. further consultations with dermatology and possibly rheumatology are recommended to manage the complex presentation of mrs. education regarding the chronic nature of mrs and strategies for managing exacerbations will be provided.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i see that youre a 50-year-old chinese man with no prior illnesses. can you tell me what brought you here today?
patient: hi, doctor. ive been having a fever, headache, and vomiting for about a month now.
doctor: i see. we performed a magnetic resonance imaging mri of your brain and it showed multiple varying sizes of ring-enhancing lesions scattered in both cerebral and cerebellar hemispheres. this suggests either a metastatic brain tumour or an infection. we also did a computer tomographic ct scan of your thorax and found a 6.5 cm x 4.5 cm mass in the right upper lobe, which is suspicious for primary lung malignancy.
patient: oh no, that sounds serious.
doctor: yes, we needed to investigate further. your blood tests showed mild leucocytosis of 11.7 x 103ul and a normal c-reactive protein of 1.5 mgl. we also performed a lumbar puncture to check your cerebrospinal fluid csf. it demonstrated raised intracranial pressure of 26 cm h2o, elevated cell count of 260 cellsmm3 with 90 lymphocyte predominance, low glucose of 1.9 mmoll, and raised protein at 1.15 gl.
patient: what do those numbers mean, doctor?
doctor: these results indicate an infection. initial mucicarmine and india ink staining did not demonstrate organisms, but further tests detected csf cryptococcal antigen, and csf fungal culture grew c. gattii. your blood cryptococcal antigen was also detected at a titre of 1:1280. importantly, your human immunodeficiency virus testing came back negative.
patient: so, its an infection, not a tumor?
doctor: thats correct. we performed a bronchoscopy to further evaluate the right upper lobe mass. the bronchoalveolar lavage showed thick-walled fungal yeast forms with narrow-based budding, consistent with cryptococcus yeasts. these were highlighted by mucicarmine special stain. the bronchoscopic biopsies showed non-specific chronic inflammatory infiltrates in the bronchial wall epithelium and lung parenchyma.
patient: what does this mean for my treatment?
doctor: youve been given induction anti-fungal therapy, which includes four weeks of amphotericin b and two weeks of flucytosine. after that, youll be on maintenance therapy with oral fluconazole.
patient: and what about the raised intracranial pressure?
doctor: weve been performing therapeutic lumbar punctures to help treat the raised intracranial pressure. youll continue to have these procedures during your outpatient follow-up.
patient: okay, thank you for explaining everything to me, doctor.
doctor: youre welcome. well continue to monitor your progress and adjust your treatment as needed. if you have any concerns or questions, dont hesitate to reach out.
Reference SOAP:

o: mri brain reveals multiple ring-enhancing lesions in both cerebral and cerebellar hemispheres. ct thorax shows a 6.5 cm x 4.5 cm mass in the right upper lobe. blood tests indicate mild leucocytosis 11.7 x 103ul, normal c-reactive protein 1.5 mgl. lumbar puncture shows raised intracranial pressure 26 cm h2o, elevated csf cell count 260 cellsmm3, 90 lymphocytes, low glucose 1.9 mmoll, and raised protein 1.15 gl. csf and blood cryptococcal antigen positive, csf fungal culture positive for c. gattii. hiv test negative. bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage identifies cryptococcus yeasts, and biopsies show chronic inflammatory infiltrates.
a: primary diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis secondary to pulmonary cryptococcosis, likely due to c. gattii infection. differential diagnosis initially included metastatic brain tumor. complications include raised intracranial pressure.
p: induction therapy with amphotericin b for four weeks and flucytosine for two weeks, followed by maintenance therapy with oral fluconazole. ongoing therapeutic lumbar punctures to manage raised intracranial pressure. outpatient follow-up for monitoring and adjustment of treatment as necessary.

doctor: hello, i see in your records that youre a 52-year-old female with no past medical or surgical history. what brings you to the emergency room today?
patient: hi, doctor. for the past two days, ive been having abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and obstipation.
doctor: i see. have you noticed any other symptoms or changes, such as a distended abdomen?
patient: yeah, now that you mention it, my abdomen does feel quite bloated and uncomfortable.
doctor: thank you for sharing that. let me do a deep palpation to check for any discomfort or peritoneal signs. performs palpation it seems theres some discomfort on deep palpation, but no peritoneal signs. well need to run some tests to further investigate the issue.
patient: okay, doctor.
doctor: after running tests your white blood cell count is mildly elevated, and you have low potassium, which weve replaced. the computed tomography scan indicates that you might have a small bowel obstruction.
patient: oh, no. what does that mean, and what should i do now?
doctor: well admit you to the hospital for further examination and treatment. well perform a small bowel follow-through to confirm the diagnosis.
the next day
doctor: the small bowel follow-through revealed moderate distention of the stomach, multiple distended small bowel loops, and no evidence of contrast in the cecum at 14 hours. this is consistent with a small bowel obstruction. well need to take you to the operating room for an exploratory laparotomy to address the issue.
patient: i understand. what could have caused this obstruction?
doctor: after surgery during the exploratory laparotomy, we performed a retrieval of a foreign body via an enterotomy. it appears that you ingested a pineapple core the day prior to your symptoms. the pineapple core was acting as a source of fiber, which may have contributed to the obstruction.
patient: oh, i didnt realize that could cause a problem. im glad its been taken care of.
doctor: your surgery went well, and youre recovering nicely. well continue to monitor your progress, and if all goes well, youll be discharged from the hospital soon.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate your help and guidance throughout this process.
Reference SOAP:

o: physical examination revealed discomfort on deep abdominal palpation without peritoneal signs. laboratory tests showed a mildly elevated white blood cell count and low potassium levels, which were corrected. a computed tomography scan and a small bowel follow-through indicated a small bowel obstruction with moderate stomach distention and multiple distended small bowel loops, with no contrast seen in the cecum at 14 hours post ingestion.
a: the primary diagnosis is small bowel obstruction, confirmed by imaging and surgical findings. the obstruction was caused by the ingestion of a pineapple core, which was surgically retrieved. no other differential diagnoses are currently considered.
p: the patient was admitted for surgical intervention, specifically an exploratory laparotomy, which successfully retrieved the obstructing foreign body. post-operatively, the patient is under observation with plans for discharge pending continued recovery and absence of complications. education on dietary habits and potential risks of ingesting indigestible materials was provided to prevent recurrence.

doctor: hello, thank you for coming in today. i understand youve been admitted to our hospital with symptoms of dysphagia and significant body weight loss over the past 3 months. can you tell me more about your symptoms?
patient: yeah, ive had trouble swallowing and i lost around 10 kg in the past 3 months. its been really tough.
doctor: i see. ive noted that your height is 158.0 cm and your current weight is 53.6 kg. upon admission, your body mass index bmi was calculated to be 21.5. besides this, you also have osteoporosis, which causes you to be bent over. you underwent distal gastrectomy due to a submucosal tumor 40 years ago, is that correct?
patient: yes, thats right. i had the surgery a long time ago.
doctor: according to your operative note, the surgery was performed without lymph node dissection. after the retroperitoneal attachments behind the duodenum were dissected, a billroth i reconstruction was performed. the resected mass was determined to be an aberrant pancreas. 
patient: hmm, okay.
doctor: we performed an upper gastrointestinal examination and found the presence of your postoperative stomach in the thoracic cavity via delayed barium passage. endoscopic examination showed that esophagitis and tumor in the upper digestive tract were absent, which is good news.
patient: oh, thats a relief.
doctor: however, enhanced computed tomography ect revealed a large hiatal hernia involving the entire stomach, sliding through the hiatal orifice into the mediastinum. the stomach was expanded with food remaining inside, and it was compressing the heart in the posterior mediastinum. 
patient: that sounds serious.
doctor: it is a concern, but fortunately, you have no symptoms of cardiac failure, and your heart function was normal on echocardiography. preoperative ect also showed that the right and left gastric arteries and the gastroepiploic arteries were preserved, which indicates that the distal gastrectomy was performed without lymph node dissection. 
patient: so whats the next step, doc?
doctor: based on your symptoms and the hiatal hernia diagnosis, your dysphagia is quite severe, so we recommend elective surgical repair of the hiatal hernia to alleviate your symptoms.
patient: alright, if thats whats needed.
doctor: during the surgery, a total of five ports will be placed in your abdomen, and a nathanson liver retractor will be inserted to retract the left liver lobe. a laparoscopic approach will be used to address the slight adhesion of the greater omentum just under the postoperative scar and the little adhesion with the liver and spleen.
patient: okay, i understand. when will the surgery be scheduled?
doctor: well work on scheduling the surgery as soon as possible and inform you of the date. in the meantime, please follow any preoperative instructions provided by our staff, and dont hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or concerns.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate your help.
Reference SOAP:

o: current height is 158.0 cm, weight is 53.6 kg, and bmi is 21.5. upper gastrointestinal examination showed postoperative stomach in the thoracic cavity and absence of esophagitis and tumors in the upper digestive tract. enhanced computed tomography ect revealed a large hiatal hernia with the entire stomach sliding into the mediastinum, compressing the heart, but no symptoms of cardiac failure were observed. heart function is normal as per echocardiography.
a: the primary diagnosis is a large hiatal hernia causing severe dysphagia and weight loss. the patients previous surgical history and current imaging support the diagnosis. differential diagnoses such as esophagitis and tumors in the upper digestive tract have been ruled out.
p: plan to perform elective surgical repair of the hiatal hernia using a laparoscopic approach with five abdominal ports and a nathanson liver retractor. preoperative instructions will be provided, and surgery will be scheduled promptly. the patient is advised to follow preoperative guidelines and reach out with any questions or concerns.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i understand youve been referred to our department due to worsening hoarseness over the last 8 months. can you tell me more about your symptoms?
patient: yeah, along with the hoarseness, i sometimes have trouble swallowing and feel like theres a foreign body in my throat.
doctor: i see. upon referral, it was reported that you have been a heavy smoker for 20 years, smoking about 20 cigarettes per day. is that correct?
patient: yes, thats right.
doctor: and it seems that you also frequently consume alcohol, though not to the point of abuse. is that accurate?
patient: yes, i do drink quite often but never really overdo it.
doctor: in your medical history, it shows that you have arterial hypertension and are currently under treatment with beta blockers. is that correct?
patient: yes, ive been taking them for a while now.
doctor: good to know. your hematological and biochemical tests did not show any significant abnormalities. now, lets discuss your physical examination. we performed a full head and neck examination, along with a flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy. the typical ear, nose, and throat examination didnt reveal any abnormal findings, and neck palpation was negative.
patient: okay, thats good news.
doctor: however, the fiberoptic laryngoscopy did reveal a lesion affecting both vocal cords and the anterior commissure. your vocal cord mobility also appeared impaired. based on these findings, we decided to conduct a cervicothoracic and upper abdomen computed tomography ct scan with intravenous gadolinium and scheduled you for direct microlaryngoscopy and a biopsy of the lesion under general anesthesia.
patient: i see, so what did the imaging show?
doctor: the imaging confirmed the laryngeal lesion, but it also indicated a second lesion about 2 cm below the inferior end of the primary one, between the first and second tracheal ring. the intermediate tissue appeared grossly normal. no signs of enlarged cervical lymph nodes were noted, and laryngeal cartilages showed no abnormal findings.
patient: so, what does that mean?
doctor: the histopathological examination after the biopsy confirmed that you have squamous cell carcinoma. the lesion is a glottic carcinoma affecting the anterior commissure and is strongly correlated with the thyroid cartilage. the lesion has infiltrated the left and the first tertile of the right vocal cord. no subglottic extension was noted. we informed you about these findings and obtained consent for radical surgical therapy.
patient: yes, i remember discussing that with you.
doctor: im glad. so, you underwent a total laryngectomy and wide excision of the trachea, which included the removal of the second tumor within safe limits. how are you feeling now?
patient: im still recovering, but im hopeful that things will get better.
doctor: thats a good attitude. well continue to monitor your progress and provide any necessary follow-up care. if you have any concerns, dont hesitate to reach out.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate your help.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient, a long-term heavy smoker, presented with worsening hoarseness over the last 8 months, accompanied by dysphagia and a sensation of a foreign body in the throat. the patient has a history of arterial hypertension treated with beta blockers.
o: physical examination including a full head and neck exam and flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy revealed a lesion affecting both vocal cords and the anterior commissure with impaired vocal cord mobility. ct scans confirmed the laryngeal lesion and identified a second lesion between the first and second tracheal rings. histopathological examination post-biopsy confirmed squamous cell carcinoma of the glottic region, affecting the anterior commissure and infiltrating the left and part of the right vocal cord. the patient underwent a total laryngectomy and wide excision of the trachea.
a: the primary diagnosis is squamous cell carcinoma of the glottic region, likely related to chronic smoking. the disease was localized without subglottic extension or enlarged cervical lymph nodes, which facilitated surgical management.
p: the patient has undergone radical surgical therapy with total laryngectomy and tracheal excision. postoperative care includes monitoring for complications and recovery progress. regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to assess healing and detect any recurrence early. the patient is advised to cease smoking and reduce alcohol consumption to mitigate further health risks. psychological support and speech therapy will be provided to assist in recovery and adaptation post-laryngectomy.

Dialogue:
doctor: hi there, im the pediatric endocrinologist. i understand that your baby was referred to me because a uterus was detected on ultrasonography. can you please provide some background information about the pregnancy and birth?
mother: yes, i had a difficult pregnancy. the baby was born at 23 weeks of gestation by c-section due to preeclampsia and premature membrane rupture. my husband and i are first cousins, and ive had two abortions in the past.
doctor: i see. what was the birth weight of your baby?
mother: he was very small, only 680 grams at birth.
doctor: that is quite small indeed. i understand that the baby had to be intubated and given surfactant treatment, requiring mechanical ventilation support. is that correct?
mother: yes, thats correct.
doctor: the baby has bilateral cryptorchidism and hypospadias, which are likely associated with the severe prematurity. since the gender assessment at birth was made as male, the baby received a male name and identity card. can you tell me about your maternal history during pregnancy?
mother: i was treated with progesterone for one month between the 16th and 20th gestational weeks and also with salicylic acid throughout the pregnancy. there was no evidence of virilisation, such as acne, hirsutism, deep voice, or clitoral enlargement.
doctor: thank you for the information. during the physical examination of the baby, we found complete labioscrotal fusion and a single urogenital meatus, consistent with prader stage-3. the gonads were not palpable, a chorda was present, and the phallus measured 2x1 cm on the dorsal and 1.6x1 cm on the ventral side. the baby is currently still in the neonatal intensive care unit and requires mechanical respiratory support. on postnatal day 30, we checked the babys hormone levels. the 17-hydroxy progesterone 17ohp was 41 ngml, which is slightly above the normal limits of 35.5 ngml. the dhea sulphate dheaso4 was 1500 gdl, much higher than the normal range of 123-882 gdl. the testosterone level was also elevated, at 2.94 ngml, compared to the normal limits of 0.05-0.16 ngml. the fsh level was 1.3 iul.
mother: oh, i see. what does all this mean for my baby?
doctor: these hormonal imbalances may be related to the babys genital appearance and the presence of a uterus. we will need to continue monitoring the baby closely and provide appropriate treatment as needed. its important to keep a close eye on the babys health and development, and we will need to schedule regular follow-up appointments with the pediatric endocrinology team.

doctor: hello, i see that youre a 72-year old female melanoma patient in disease stage iv pt2a, n3c, m1d ajcc 2017. can you tell me more about your symptoms?
patient: well, i have this bulky ulcerated tumor mass on my right upper leg, and ive been told that i have an asymptomatic singular brain metastasis, and some other suspected tumor lesions in my chest, iliac, inguinal, and lung areas.

patient: oh, okay. what else is planned in terms of treatment?
doctor: were also planning radiotherapy for the brain lesion stereotactic and the bulky mass on your right upper leg. before starting the treatment, we found that you had normal blood leucocytes and a mild c-reactive protein crp elevation.
patient: hmm, got it. but you know, two days after starting the immunotherapy, my leg pain worsened. is that normal?
doctor: its important that you mentioned that. when you came in with the worsened pain on your right upper leg, we ran some blood tests. you were in good condition without a history of chills, fever, weight loss, or malaise. however, the blood tests showed a massive leucocytosis 68,970l normal range: 4,6009,500l with neutrophilia 63,420l normal range: 1,8007,200l. your crp was also elevated at 53 mgl, which is above the normal level of  0.5 mgl.
patient: oh, that doesnt sound good. what does that mean?
doctor: we took wound swabs from the ulcerated tumor on your right upper leg and found staphylococcus aureus. to treat this, we have administered intravenously 600 clindamycine 3 times daily over 10 days.
patient: alright, and what about the blood smears?
doctor: we checked the blood smears, and they do not reveal signs of leukemia, which is good news. well continue to monitor your condition and adjust the treatment plan as needed.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate all the information and care.

doctor: hello i understand that youve been referred to our department from the national organ procurement and transplant network waiting list for a kidney transplant. how have you been feeling lately?
patient: hi, doctor. ive been feeling alright, i guess. just dealing with my hypertension and taking medication for it.
doctor: i see. are you currently married?
patient: no, im not. im an unmarried office worker.
doctor: have you ever had any abdominal surgery?
patient: no, i havent.
doctor: as per your records, you have end-stage renal disease esrd due to autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease adpkd, but youre not currently requiring hemodialysis, correct?
patient: yes, thats correct.
doctor: your pretransplant estimated glomerular filtration rate egfr is 13.7 mlminute per 1.73 m2, and your body mass index is 21.9 kgm2. during your physical examination, we noticed an asymptomatic bilateral flank mass. have you experienced any discomfort or pain from this mass?
patient: no, i havent felt any pain or discomfort.
doctor: we performed an abdominal mri scan, which confirmed the presence of multiple cysts of different diameters within your significantly enlarged native kidneys. their sagittal diameter is greater than 25 cm bilaterally. however, we dont anticipate any space constraints at the putative transplantation site in your right iliac fossa, so theres no need for a nephrectomy before the transplant.
patient: oh, thats good to know.
doctor: the donor for your kidney transplant is a 50-year-old asian male, who unfortunately passed away in a motor vehicle accident. he had no significant comorbidities. a ct scan showed a single renal artery and vein.
patient: i see.
doctor: the surgical technique for abdominal organ procurement followed established principles. the right kidney has been assigned to our institution for your transplant.
patient: alright.
doctor: after a multidisciplinary board discussion and obtaining your informed consent, youll be scheduled for robotic-assisted kidney transplantation rakt.
patient: okay, thank you.
doctor: the rakt will be performed using the da vinci xi robot in a four-arm configuration with a 0 lens. youll be in a 30 trendelenburg position during the procedure. the surgical technique will follow the principles of the vattikutimedanta technique with specific modifications tailored to your anatomy.
patient: got it.
doctor: well make sure to keep you informed and guide you through the entire process. if you have any questions or concerns, please dont hesitate to reach out.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate your help.
