Dialogue:
doctor: hello, how can i help you today?
patient: hi, i came to the emergency department because ive been having severe lower abdominal pain and nausea for the past day.
doctor: im sorry to hear that. can you tell me about your medical history?
patient: i had a pelvic exenteration and a permanent end colostomy for stage iiib cervical cancer. about two years later, i developed a parastomal hernia.
doctor: i see. on this admission, you were diagnosed with an incarcerated parastomal hernia. we performed an emergency laparotomy, resecting more than one-and-a-half meters of gangrenous bowel and re-fashioning the stoma. a surgical mesh was applied with primary closure. the surgery was successful, and you were transferred to the icu for monitoring.
patient: hmm, okay.
doctor: about a week later, you became pyrexial and didnt respond well to treatment. ct imaging showed a five-centimeter collection over the mesh. we then opened and explored the wound in the icu and completed debridement.
patient: oh, i see.
doctor: the wound dimensions were initially 20 cm x 23 cm x 5 cm, exposing the rectus sheath. to ensure healing, we used the veraflo vacuum with instillation dressing at -125 mmhg. we cycled a sterile saline solution for three hours before applying the vacuum.
patient: yes, i remember that.
doctor: we changed the dressing three times a week. before each replacement, we soaked the dressing in saline solution for 20 minutes. after seven weeks, the wound reduced to 9 cm x 5 cm x 1.6 cm.
patient: thats great to hear.
doctor: yes, there was also a significant decrease in the amount of exudate and debris, which resulted in a decreased instillation volume during that time.
patient: okay, good.
doctor: im pleased to report that you mentioned improved pain control compared to the post-operative period. how are you feeling now?
patient: much better, thank you the pain is much more manageable now.
doctor: thats great to hear. well continue to monitor your progress and adjust your treatment as needed. if you have any concerns or questions, please dont hesitate to reach out.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate your help and support.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient, a female with a history of stage iiib cervical cancer treated with pelvic exenteration and permanent end colostomy, presented with severe lower abdominal pain and nausea for the past day. she has a history of a parastomal hernia developed two years post-surgery.
o: on admission, the patient was diagnosed with an incarcerated parastomal hernia. emergency laparotomy was performed, during which more than 1.5 meters of gangrenous bowel was resected, and the stoma was re-fashioned. surgical mesh was applied with primary closure. post-operatively, the patient was transferred to the icu. a week later, she developed a fever and a ct scan revealed a 5 cm collection over the mesh. wound exploration and debridement were performed in the icu. the initial wound dimensions were 20 cm x 23 cm x 5 cm. treatment included the use of veraflo vacuum with instillation dressing at -125 mmhg, cycling a sterile saline solution for three hours before applying the vacuum. the wound dressing was changed three times a week, with each dressing soaked in saline solution for 20 minutes before replacement. over seven weeks, the wound dimensions reduced to 9 cm x 5 cm x 1.6 cm, with a significant decrease in exudate and debris.
a: the primary diagnosis is an incarcerated parastomal hernia with subsequent complications including infection and a large wound requiring complex management. the patients response to the treatment has been positive with significant reduction in wound size and improved pain control.
p: continue monitoring the wound healing progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. maintain the current regimen of wound care with veraflo vacuum and instillation dressing. regularly assess pain and adjust analgesics as needed. schedule follow-up appointments in the outpatient clinic to monitor the stoma and overall recovery. educate the patient on signs of infection or complications to watch for and ensure she understands when to seek immediate medical attention.

patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate your help.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, how can i help you today?
patient: hi, doctor. ive had this swelling on the right side of my cheek for about 6 months now. its been getting bigger over time.
doctor: i see. have you experienced any pain or discomfort in the area?
patient: no, not really. there hasnt been any pain at all.
doctor: what about difficulty swallowing, or dysphagia? have you noticed any issues with that?
patient: no, i havent had any trouble swallowing either.
doctor: alright, lets take a look. after examining the patient i can see a single, cystic swelling in your right cheek, around 2x2 cm2 with ill-defined margins. its nontender and palpable bimanually. the rest of your oropharynx and laryngopharynx appear normal, and there are no palpable neck nodes. your vitals and blood parameters are also stable.
patient: hmm, okay.
doctor: to better understand this swelling, we performed a cytological examination of the mass. it was reported as a chronic granulomatous lesion. we also did a ct scan of your head and neck, which revealed a well-defined cystic lesion measuring 2.6x21x19 mm3 in the right buccal space, arising from the buccinator muscle and displacing the zygomaticus major.
patient: so what does all that mean?
doctor: based on these findings, weve made a provisional diagnosis of a right buccal cyst. we planned for an excision biopsy under general anesthesia and performed surgery with our team of orl head and neck surgeons.
patient: how did the surgery go?
doctor: intraoperatively, we found a well-defined cystic lesion measuring around 3x3 cm2 in the right buccal space. the cyst contained thick mucinous fluid. we sent the specimen for histopathological examination, and the findings were consistent with an oncocytoma.
patient: oh, i see.
doctor: after the surgery, we kept you on intravenous antibiotics. the postoperative period was uneventful, with mild soft tissue swelling over the operated area without any collections. you were then discharged on the 7th postoperative day.
patient: thats good to hear. how has my recovery been going?

Dialogue:
doctor: hi there, can you please tell me what brings you here today?
patient: well, ive had a history of intermittent, severe epigastric pain.
doctor: i see. how long have you been experiencing this pain?
patient: its been happening for the past 5 months. the pain usually comes 15-30 minutes after every meal, but its less severe and goes away on its own.
doctor: okay, lets review your test results. your full blood count, serum biochemistry values, and c-reactive protein level are within normal ranges. your arterial gas analysis is also normal. however, your abdominal plain radiography showed free air between the liver and diaphragm, and pi fig.. additionally, abdominal computed tomography showed severe calcification of the sma origin sma peripheral flow was reserved fig.. computed tomography ct revealed bubble-like intramural gas of the small bowel with the contrasted wall pneumoperitoneum fig..
patient: hmm, that sounds concerning. what does that all mean?
doctor: since you dont have peritonitis, we decided to take a conservative approach. we managed your condition in the intensive care unit due to potential risks of acute mesenteric ischemia from mesenteric artery occlusion or non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia. you were treated for bowel obstruction, which included fasting and intravenous fluid administration. you also received heparin infusion to prevent sma occlusion and maintain collateral flow.
patient: yes, i remember that. i actually felt some relief from my abdominal pain during my stay in the icu.
doctor: thats good to hear. seven days after admission, your abdominal plain radiography showed improvement in pi and pneumoperitoneum. so, we allowed you to start drinking fluids. did you experience any pain after consuming fluids?
patient: no, i didnt have any recurrent abdominal pain after drinking fluids.
doctor: great. since there was no pain, we allowed you to eat solid food as well. now, we had planned an angiography to further investigate and potentially relieve your postprandial abdominal pain. the findings showed severe stenosis of the sma origin with calcification, and the sma had replaced the common hepatic artery fig., . we performed et, namely stenting to the sma and common hepatic artery.
patient: how was the procedure done?
doctor: we engaged the sma trunk with a 6f parent plus 60 guiding catheter medikit, tokyo, japan from your left brachial artery. initially, we infused 8000 units of heparin, and added additional heparin to keep your activated whole blood clotting time over 200 seconds.
patient: i see. so, whats next for me?
doctor: now that the procedure is done, we will continue to monitor your condition closely. its essential to maintain a proper diet and follow up with your appointments regularly. if you notice any recurrence of abdominal pain or any new symptoms, please contact us immediately.
patient: okay, thank you, doctor. i will follow your advice and keep an eye on my condition.

a: the primary diagnosis is acute mesenteric ischemia due to severe stenosis of the sma, complicated by non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia and bowel obstruction. differential diagnosis initially included peritonitis, which was ruled out based on clinical findings.

Dialogue:
doctor: hi, i understand youve been evaluated for persistent hyponatremia, which has been going on for about a month. can you tell me about any symptoms youve experienced during this duration?
patient: yeah, ive been feeling really tired and confused lately. i also noticed some unexplained weight loss.
doctor: your physical exam didnt show any signs of volume overload or depletion, which is good. however, your workup revealed a sodium level of 126 mmoll without other electrolyte abnormalities, serum osmolality of 260 mosmkg, serum uric acid level of 2.0 mgdl, normal cortisol, normal tsh, urine sodium of 45 mmoll, and urine osmolality of 274 mosmkg. these findings are consistent with a condition called siadh. you were taking citalopram, which we thought might have been the cause, so we stopped it. however, your hyponatremia persisted, so we did some more tests, especially considering your extensive smoking history.
patient: yeah, ive been a smoker for a long time.
doctor: we performed a computed tomography ct scan, which showed a right hilar mass with metastasis to the liver, right femur, and ribs. a biopsy revealed that you have small cell lung cancer sclc.
patient: oh no, thats terrible.
doctor: i understand this is difficult news, but its important to address it. ive noticed that youve continued to smoke cigarettes even after the sclc diagnosis. about two weeks later, you were admitted for acute hypoxic and hypercapnic respiratory failure due to postobstructive pneumonia, copd exacerbation, and secondary pneumothorax. we managed these issues, and there was some improvement in your respiratory status.
patient: yeah, my breathing got a bit better after that.
doctor: however, your paco2 and serum bicarbonate levels began to increase, with the bicarbonate level approaching up to 45 meqdl. this was associated with refractory hypokalemia and uncontrolled hypertension. we noticed metabolic alkalosis, which was chloride resistant, as your urine chloride was 20 meqdl. your hyponatremia responded moderately to fluid restriction and gradually normalized after the onset of metabolic alkalosis.
patient: so, what does that mean for me?
doctor: well, with uncontrolled hypertension and the presence of chloride-resistant metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia, we decided to conduct a workup for hyperaldosteronism. your serum aldosterone and plasma renin activity were within normal limits, so we proceeded with a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test.
patient: what did the test show?
doctor: the test revealed elevations of acth 319 pgml and cortisol 131.5 gdl, consistent with acth-dependent hypercortisolism and a condition called same, which is caused by an ectopic nonsuppressible source of acth. furthermore, youve experienced significant weight loss of 28 pounds after your sclc diagnosis and profound muscle wasting.
patient: thats a lot to take in. whats next for me?
doctor: well be working closely with you to create a personalized treatment plan to address both your sclc and the metabolic issues. its important to follow up with your medical team and monitor your symptoms. well do our best to support you through this process.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate your help.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient reports persistent fatigue, confusion, and unexplained weight loss over the past month. he has a significant smoking history and has been previously treated with citalopram, which was discontinued due to ongoing hyponatremia.
o: physical examination showed no signs of volume overload or depletion. laboratory findings indicated hyponatremia with a sodium level of 126 mmoll, serum osmolality of 260 mosmkg, serum uric acid of 2.0 mgdl, normal cortisol and tsh levels, urine sodium of 45 mmoll, and urine osmolality of 274 mosmkg. ct scan revealed a right hilar mass with metastasis to the liver, right femur, and ribs biopsy confirmed small cell lung cancer sclc. recent hospitalization addressed acute hypoxic and hypercapnic respiratory failure, postobstructive pneumonia, copd exacerbation, and secondary pneumothorax. metabolic alkalosis was noted with a bicarbonate level up to 45 meqdl, refractory hypokalemia, and uncontrolled hypertension. high-dose dexamethasone suppression test indicated acth-dependent hypercortisolism with elevated acth 319 pgml and cortisol 131.5 gdl.
a: primary diagnosis is small cell lung cancer with associated siadh, metabolic complications including acth-dependent hypercortisolism same syndrome, metabolic alkalosis, refractory hypokalemia, and uncontrolled hypertension. differential diagnosis includes complications from chronic smoking and potential secondary endocrine disorders.
p: the management plan includes close monitoring and treatment of sclc and metabolic disturbances. fluid restriction and monitoring have been initiated for hyponatremia, which has shown moderate response. further evaluation and management of hypercortisolism and metabolic alkalosis are ongoing. the patient is advised to cease smoking immediately to prevent further complications. regular follow-ups with oncology, pulmonology, and endocrinology are scheduled to adjust treatment plans as needed and to monitor the progression of conditions and response to treatments.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i understand that you were referred to us for management of fetal demise. can you tell me about your antenatal visits and any symptoms youve experienced during your pregnancy?
patient: yes, i attended 3 antenatal visits at a health center. they documented my fundal height at each visit and gave me routine care. i had occasional painful fetal kicks, but i was otherwise well throughout the antenatal period.
doctor: its good that you had regular visits. when did you start to notice reduced fetal movements?
patient: hmm, about three days before i got admitted to your service, i noticed the reduced movements, so i consulted at the health center, and they said it was fetal demise.
doctor: i see. when you were admitted to our unit, we checked your vital parameters and found them to be stable. there was no abdominal tenderness, and your fundal height was 32cm. fetal parts were not easily palpable, and we couldnt perceive fetal heart tones. also, there were no signs of per vaginal bleeding. your cervix was long, posterior, firm, and closed. we requested an emergency ultrasound scan, which confirmed the fetal demise and showed gross cranial deformation. however, it didnt diagnose an intra-abdominal location.
patient: thats really sad. so, what did you do next?
doctor: we started cervical ripening with 50g of misoprostol vaginally every 6 hours. after 4 applications, your cervix remained unchanged. so, we decided to proceed with operative delivery to avoid failed induction and reduce the risk of disseminated intravascular coagulation.
patient: what did you find during the operation?
doctor: the intraoperative findings showed a third-degree macerated female fetus floating freely in the peritoneal cavity, weighing 2650g with a tight cord round her neck, and there was no amniotic sac. the uterus was about 14 weeks, and the fallopian tubes and ovaries were normal. the placenta was implanted on the ascending colon and mesocolon. we decided to leave the placenta in place as there were no intraoperative complications encountered.
patient: what treatment did i receive after the operation?
doctor: postoperatively, you were placed on ampicillin, gentamycin, and metronidazole parenterally for five days to prevent infection. additionally, you received 50mg of methotrexate every other day for 4 doses, along with 5mg of folinic acid each day following the methotrexate treatment.
patient: when can i expect to be discharged?
doctor: you were discharged on day 8 postoperation to continue your recovery at home.
patient: thank you for all the information and the care i received during this difficult time.
doctor: youre welcome. were here to support you. if you have any questions or concerns, please dont hesitate to reach out to us. take care and be well.
Reference SOAP:

o: upon admission, the patients vital signs were stable, with no abdominal tenderness, and a fundal height of 32cm. fetal parts were not palpable, and no fetal heart tones were detected. there was no per vaginal bleeding, and the cervix was long, posterior, firm, and closed. an emergency ultrasound confirmed fetal demise and showed gross cranial deformation without intra-abdominal location. intraoperative findings included a third-degree macerated female fetus weighing 2650g with a tight cord around the neck, floating freely in the peritoneal cavity, and a placenta implanted on the ascending colon and mesocolon. postoperative medications included ampicillin, gentamycin, metronidazole, methotrexate, and folinic acid.
a: the primary diagnosis is fetal demise with complications including gross cranial deformation and abnormal placental implantation. differential diagnosis could include intra-abdominal pregnancy given the unusual findings, although this was not confirmed. the prognosis is guarded due to the potential for infection and the need for ongoing monitoring of placental site and overall recovery.
p: management included cervical ripening with misoprostol, followed by operative delivery due to failed induction. postoperatively, the patient was treated with antibiotics and methotrexate to manage placental implantation and prevent infection. she was discharged on day 8 post-operation with instructions for home recovery and follow-up care. further consultations with obstetrics and possibly mental health services are recommended to address physical and emotional recovery. compliance with medication and follow-up appointments is crucial for recovery and monitoring for potential complications.

a: the primary diagnosis is fetal demise. differential diagnoses could include other causes of fetal demise but these were less likely given the clinical presentation and the absence of intraoperative complications.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, how can i help you today?
patient: hi, im here because i fell from a bunk bed nine days ago and i hurt my left wrist. i got it checked at another facility and they put a splint on it, but i wanted a second opinion.
doctor: i see. do you have a history of any other medical issues or injuries?
patient: hmm, well, ive had some issues with intravenous drug abuse and ive been incarcerated before.
doctor: thank you for sharing that information. lets take a look at your wrist. ill need to remove the splint and take new x-rays to assess the situation.
patient: sure, go ahead.
doctor takes x-rays
doctor: your x-rays show that the fracture is highly comminuted, meaning there are many small, intra-articular fragments. to restore overall radiographic parameters and stability, well use ligamentotaxis with a 2.42.7 mm synthes dorsal bridge plate. well also add percutaneously placed k wires for extra stabilization of the radial styloid and lunate facet.
patient: okay, so what does that involve?
doctor: well make two incisions, one over the index metacarpal and one over the radial shaft. we wont open the third dorsal extensor compartment at the level of the wrist, which is a contrast to others techniques. the plate will be placed deep to the extensor tendons in the proximal, radial shaft incision. well leave the k wire ends outside the skin to allow staged hardware removal without multiple trips to the operating room.
patient: got it. and after the procedure, what will my recovery look like?
doctor: postoperative x-rays will show improved radial inclination and articular congruity, with some residual slight dorsal tilt. youll return for regular follow-up visits, and well remove the two k wires in the clinic about 4 weeks after surgery. at that point, you should be able to extend your thumb at the interphalangeal joint.
patient: that sounds good. is there anything else i should know?
doctor: plate removal will be discussed during your follow-up visits, but its important to keep attending those appointments. in some cases, patients might experience sensations like clicking with wrist motion or difficulty extending their thumb. if that happens, well need to address it.
patient: okay, ill make sure to come to my follow-up visits. thank you for explaining everything to me.
doctor: youre welcome. if you have any questions or concerns during your recovery, or if you experience any new trauma to your wrist or hand, please dont hesitate to reach out.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient, a history of intravenous drug abuse and incarceration, presents nine days post-fall from a bunk bed with a chief complaint of pain in the left wrist. initially treated with a splint at another facility, the patient seeks a second opinion due to persistent discomfort.
o: examination and x-rays of the left wrist reveal a highly comminuted fracture with multiple intra-articular fragments. the fracture affects the radial styloid and lunate facet. planned surgical intervention includes the use of a 2.42.7 mm synthes dorsal bridge plate and percutaneously placed k wires for stabilization.
a: the primary diagnosis is a comminuted intra-articular fracture of the left wrist. the planned surgical approach aims to restore radial inclination, articular congruity, and overall wrist stability, while minimizing the risk of complications such as non-union or malunion due to the patients complex fracture pattern.
p: the patient will undergo surgery involving the placement of a dorsal bridge plate and k wires. postoperative care will include regular follow-up visits to monitor healing and hardware integrity, with k wires removal scheduled approximately 4 weeks post-surgery. the patient is advised to attend all follow-up appointments and report any new symptoms such as clicking or difficulty extending the thumb. plate removal will be evaluated during follow-up. the patient is encouraged to contact healthcare providers if experiencing any new trauma or concerns during recovery.

o: physical examination revealed a highly comminuted fracture of the left wrist, commingled with a 2.7 mm dorsal bridge plate. ligamentotaxis with 2.42.5 mm k wires was used, which was performed under two incisions over the index metacarpal and one over the radial shaft, with two percutaneously placed k wires for extra stabilization of the radial styloid and lunate facet. postoperative x-rays showed improved radial inclination and articular congruity, with residual slight dorsal tilt.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i see that youve been hospitalized for persistent aching pain in your abdomen and lower extremities for nearly 20 days. can you tell me more about that?
patient: yes, its been really bothering me for the past 20 days, and ive also had severe hair loss for the past 10 days.
doctor: i see. let me ask you a few questions to better understand your situation. have you had any significant health issues in the past?
patient: no, ive been healthy and i havent taken any medications.
doctor: alright. and is there any chance you might have been accidentally poisoned?
patient: no, i dont think so.
doctor: okay, lets proceed with a physical examination. hmm, i see that you have diffuse alopecia of the scalp. i also noticed that your liver function is damaged, with alt at 154.8ul and ast at 49.2 ul. weve tested your urine mercury, hair arsenic, and blood lead levels, and theyre all normal. 
patient: oh no, what could be causing this?
doctor: we continued to monitor your condition, and your scalp hair was completely lost within a week. after further investigation, weve determined that you have thallium poisoning. this was confirmed by the elevated levels of thallium ion in your urine, which was 4677.0gl, and in your blood, which was 312.1gl. the normal range for urine is 5gl, and for blood, its 0gl.
patient: thats shocking what can be done to treat this?
doctor: we have started you on ten cycles of hemoperfusion and hemodialysis, each lasting for 5 to 6 hours daily. as these treatments were conducted, your blood and urine thallium levels have decreased.
patient: thats a relief. is there anything else being done for my treatment?
doctor: yes, after the hemoperfusion and hemodialysis, weve seen improvement in your neurological manifestations and liver function parameters. weve also given you prussian blue 2.64 g, q6h, forced diuresis, and 20 mmol potassium chloride twice a day, along with intravenous b complex.
patient: how long will it take for my pain to subside and my hair to grow back?
doctor: your pain should disappear slowly, and your hair regrowth started 10 days later. it should be complete during your 6-month follow-up.
patient: i hope so. do we know what caused the poisoning?
doctor: unfortunately, the reason for the poisoning remains unknown despite an investigation conducted by police authorities.
patient: thats concerning, but i appreciate all the help youve provided in my treatment.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient reports persistent aching pain in the abdomen and lower extremities for 20 days, accompanied by severe hair loss starting 10 days ago. the patient denies any significant past health issues or medication use and does not believe they have been accidentally poisoned.
o: physical examination revealed diffuse alopecia of the scalp. liver function tests showed elevated alt at 154.8 ul and ast at 49.2 ul. tests for urine mercury, hair arsenic, and blood lead levels were normal. elevated thallium levels were detected in the patients urine 4677.0gl and blood 312.1gl, confirming thallium poisoning. hemoperfusion and hemodialysis treatments have been initiated, resulting in decreased thallium levels. prussian blue 2.64 g q6h, forced diuresis, 20 mmol potassium chloride bid, and intravenous b complex have been administered.
a: the primary diagnosis is thallium poisoning, confirmed by significantly elevated thallium levels in urine and blood. the patients liver function is compromised, and neurological symptoms have been noted. the source of the poisoning remains unidentified.
p: continue with the prescribed treatment regimen of prussian blue, forced diuresis, potassium chloride, and intravenous b complex. monitor thallium levels, liver function, and neurological status closely. conduct a follow-up in 6 months to assess hair regrowth and overall recovery. educate the patient on the signs of potential re-exposure to thallium and ensure regular follow-up visits to manage and prevent complications.

doctor: hello, i see youve presented to our department due to a worsening of cognitive functions that have been observed for 2-3 years. can you tell me more about how this has affected you in the past few days?
patient: yeah, its gotten worse over the past three days. i cant do some simple tasks in everyday life and ive lost interest in the things i used to enjoy.
doctor: i understand. are you still able to do things like going to the supermarket and doing housework unsupervised?
patient: yes, i can still do those things independently.
doctor: thats good to hear. ive also reviewed your medical history, and i see that you have dyslipidaemia, arterial hypertension, and you had a stroke at the age of 36 with mild right hemiparesis. have you experienced any episodes of aphasia that could be considered as transient ischemic attacks tias?
patient: yes, ive had several episodes of aphasia.
doctor: i also noticed that you have a history of smoking. regarding your family, are there any hereditary diseases or health problems identified among your parents, siblings, or offspring?
patient: no, my family doesnt have any hereditary diseases or health problems.
doctor: i see. during your neurological examination, we observed mild bilateral dysmetria. our mental examination also revealed executive dysfunction and pronounced cognitive slowing. your mini-mental state examination mmse score was 25, frontal assessment battery fab score was 5, phonemic fluency was 4 in one minute, and semantic fluency was 3 in one minute. 
patient: oh, that doesnt sound too good.
doctor: its not ideal, but we will work on finding the best treatment plan for you. your laboratory blood tests revealed significant dyslipidaemia, with a total cholesterol level of 7.55 mmoll and a low-density lipoprotein level of 5.82 mmoll. your cerebrospinal fluid analysis was unremarkable.
patient: what about any issues with my arteries?
doctor: we detected low-grade bilateral internal and external carotid artery stenosis on your carotid ultrasound.
patient: and what about my brain? did the imaging show anything?
doctor: yes, the brain magnetic resonance imaging mri revealed communicating hydrocephalus, which is most likely due to brain atrophy and secondary brain changes. there was no obvious cause of obstruction in the ventricles. your huckman index was equal to 66, and the width of the third ventricle was equal to 10 mm. we also found extensive leukoencephalopathy with a fazekas scale score of 2-3, and lacunar lesions in the dorsal part of the pons, thalamus bilaterally, and right cerebellar hemisphere.
patient: that sounds concerning. what do we do next?
doctor: we will develop a treatment plan to address your cognitive decline and work on managing your dyslipidaemia and arterial hypertension. its important to follow up with your healthcare team regularly, and we will monitor your progress closely.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate your help.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient reports a worsening of cognitive functions over the past 2-3 years, which has recently intensified over the past three days, affecting daily tasks and interest in usual activities. the patient can still perform some daily activities independently, such as going to the supermarket and doing housework. the patient has a history of dyslipidemia, arterial hypertension, stroke with mild right hemiparesis, and episodes of aphasia suggestive of transient ischemic attacks tias. the patient is a smoker and reports no hereditary diseases in the family.
o: neurological examination showed mild bilateral dysmetria. mental examination indicated executive dysfunction and pronounced cognitive slowing. mini-mental state examination mmse score was 25, frontal assessment battery fab score was 5, phonemic fluency was 4 in one minute, and semantic fluency was 3 in one minute. laboratory tests revealed significant dyslipidemia with total cholesterol of 7.55 mmoll and low-density lipoprotein of 5.82 mmoll. cerebrospinal fluid analysis was unremarkable. carotid ultrasound detected low-grade bilateral internal and external carotid artery stenosis. brain mri showed communicating hydrocephalus, extensive leukoencephalopathy with a fazekas scale score of 2-3, and lacunar lesions in the dorsal part of the pons, thalamus bilaterally, and right cerebellar hemisphere.
a: the primary diagnosis is cognitive decline associated with vascular risk factors and structural brain changes. differential diagnoses include vascular dementia and early-onset alzheimers disease, considering the patients age and cognitive symptoms. the presence of hydrocephalus, extensive leukoencephalopathy, and lacunar lesions further complicates the clinical picture, suggesting multi-factorial etiologies for cognitive impairment.
p: the management plan will focus on addressing cognitive decline, controlling dyslipidemia, and managing arterial hypertension. specific interventions include:
- initiation of statin therapy for dyslipidemia.
- optimization of antihypertensive therapy.
- regular monitoring of cognitive function and adjustment of treatments as necessary.
- referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of cognitive issues and potential hydrocephalus.
- patient education on lifestyle modifications to reduce vascular risk factors, including smoking cessation.
- scheduled follow-up appointments to monitor progress and adjust treatment plans as needed.

doctor: hello, i was informed that you are a primigravid 24-year-old female who was referred to the emergency department from the community health center. can you tell me what happened?
patient: yes, i just gave birth 1.5 hours ago with the help of a midwife. after the baby was born, they tried to remove the placenta by performing placental traction. suddenly, a large mass emerged through my vaginal passage along with the placenta. i started bleeding heavily and lost consciousness.
doctor: i see. when you arrived at the emergency department, you were anemic and unresponsive with active vaginal bleeding. our physical examination revealed hypotension with a blood pressure of 8060 mmhg, tachycardia at 138 beatsmin, and tachypnea at 26 breathsmin. your conjunctiva was anemic, and you had perioral cyanosis, cold  mottled extremities, and prolonged capillary refill time of more than 3 seconds. we also found that you had a total uterine inversion and perineal lacerations.
patient: oh, that sounds terrible. what did you do to help me?
doctor: we immediately performed bloodwork upon your admission, which showed anemia with haemoglobin at 5.9 gdl, hematocrit at 17.4, and erythrocyte count at 2.07 millionul. you also had leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 22,000ul, but your thrombocyte level was normal at 358,000ul.
patient: so what was the treatment?
doctor: we treated you with fluid resuscitation using both colloids and crystalloids, along with blood transfusion and uterotonics. we successfully performed a manual reposition of your uterus and applied internal bimanual compression for 15 minutes. however, you still had profuse hemorrhage due to uterine atony.
patient: how did you manage that?
doctor: we placed a balloon tamponade to stop the hemorrhage and reduce the risk of recurrence. thankfully, your condition stabilized, and we didnt need to perform surgical management or a hysterectomy. we then repaired your perineal lacerations once the bleeding was under control.
patient: im glad to hear that. how am i doing now?
doctor: after transfusing 4 packed red cells, we repeated your bloodwork. your hemoglobin is now at 10 gdl, hematocrit at 29, erythrocyte count at 3.66 millionul, leucocyte count at 20,900ul, and thrombocyte count at 159,000ul. you have shown significant improvement.
patient: thats a relief. whats next for me?
doctor: we will continue to monitor your condition closely. it is important to have follow-up appointments with your healthcare provider to ensure your complete recovery.
Reference SOAP:
s: 24-year-old primigravid female presented to the emergency department after childbirth, reporting heavy vaginal bleeding and loss of consciousness following placental delivery with placental traction. she described a large mass emerging through the vaginal passage alongside the placenta.
o: on examination, the patient was anemic, hypotensive 8060 mmhg, tachycardic 138 beatsmin, and tachypneic 26 breathsmin. physical findings included anemic conjunctiva, perioral cyanosis, cold and mottled extremities, and prolonged capillary refill time 3 seconds. diagnosis of total uterine inversion and perineal lacerations was made. initial labs showed severe anemia hb 5.9 gdl, hct 17.4, rbc 2.07 millionul, leukocytosis wbc 22,000ul, and normal thrombocyte count 358,000ul. post-treatment labs indicated improved anemia hb 10 gdl, hct 29, rbc 3.66 millionul, persistent leukocytosis wbc 20,900ul, and decreased thrombocyte count 159,000ul.
a: the patient suffered from severe postpartum hemorrhage secondary to total uterine inversion and uterine atony, complicated by shock and severe anemia. differential diagnoses included coagulopathies and retained placental fragments, which were ruled out by clinical management and stabilization.
p: immediate management included fluid resuscitation, blood transfusion, uterotonics, manual uterine repositioning, and internal bimanual compression. a balloon tamponade was placed to control hemorrhage. perineal lacerations were surgically repaired. the patient stabilized with these interventions, avoiding the need for further surgical procedures such as hysterectomy. ongoing care includes close monitoring, repeat bloodwork, and follow-up appointments to ensure complete recovery and manage potential complications like infection or anemia.

o: physical examination revealed hypotension with a blood pressure of 8060 mmhg, tachcardia at 138 beatsmin, and prolonged capillary refill time of more than 3 seconds. physical examination showed anemia with haemoglobin at 5.9 gdl, hematocrit at 17.4, and erythrocyte count at 2.07 millionul, with leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 22,000ul, but thrombocyte level was normal. blood transfusion with 4 packed red cells was performed, and the patients condition stabilized after 15 minutes of treatment. uterine inversion and perineal lacerations were repaired with a balloon tamponade.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i am dr. johnson, and i will be taking care of you today. i understand that you were brought to the emergency department of our tertiary care referral hospital with a history of accidentally consuming car coolant and experiencing unsteadiness in your gait about 3 hours later. can you tell me more about that?
patient: yes, doctor. i accidentally drank some car coolant and started feeling unsteady on my feet after about 3 hours.
doctor: thank you for the information. on examination, we observed that you were drowsy but following verbal commands. there was no odor of alcohol in your breath. your gcs score was 1515 e4v5m6. your blood pressure was 14080 mm of hg, and your pulse rate was 68 per minute. oxygen saturation was maintained at room air. we also performed an ecg, which was normal, and no focal neurological deficit was detected. as a first line of treatment, we performed gastric lavage. we also conducted some laboratory investigations. 
patient: okay, doctor. what were the results of those investigations?
doctor: your lab results showed the following: na was 142 meql, k 2.4 meql, cl 101.1 meql, hco3 15.8 meql, ca 5 mgdl, urea 35 mgdl, creatinine 0.7 mgdl, bun 16.35 mgdl, random glucose 141 mgdl, and serum osmolality 323 mosmkg. arterial blood gas analysis showed ph 7.322, pco2 30.7 mmhg, po2 93.8 mmhg, cbasebc 9.1. 
patient: oh, i see. what does all that mean?
doctor: also, your urine examination revealed crystals of calcium oxalate, which is a major indicator of ethylene glycol consumption. your anion gap was 25.1 meql, and the osmolar gap was 17 mosmkgh2o. unfortunately, we could not obtain blood and urine levels of ethylene glycol due to the lack of such analytical facilities in the region.
patient: so, whats the plan for my treatment, doctor?
doctor: based on your lab results, we have confirmed a diagnosis of ethylene glycol poisoning. we have started you on oral ethanol therapy, which involves administering 2.5 mlkg of 40 ethanol through a nasogastric tube. additionally, due to the high anion gap metabolic acidosis, we will be giving you hemodialysis as part of your treatment.
patient: alright, doctor. thank you for explaining everything to me.
doctor: youre welcome. we will continue to monitor your condition and make any necessary adjustments to your treatment. please dont hesitate to ask any questions or share any concerns you may have.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate your help.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient, a male, presented to the emergency department after accidentally ingesting car coolant, reporting unsteadiness in his gait approximately 3 hours post-ingestion. he described feeling drowsy but was able to follow verbal commands.
o: physical examination revealed a glasgow coma scale gcs score of 1515, blood pressure of 14080 mm hg, pulse rate of 68 beats per minute, and normal oxygen saturation on room air. an ecg showed no abnormalities, and no focal neurological deficits were observed. laboratory findings indicated hypokalemia k 2.4 meql, hypocalcemia ca 5 mgdl, metabolic acidosis hco3 15.8 meql, ph 7.322, and high anion gap metabolic acidosis anion gap 25.1 meql. urine examination revealed calcium oxalate crystals. gastric lavage was performed as an initial treatment.
a: the primary diagnosis is ethylene glycol poisoning, evidenced by the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in urine, metabolic acidosis, and an elevated anion gap. the differential diagnosis would consider other causes of high anion gap metabolic acidosis, but clinical presentation and lab results strongly point to ethylene glycol toxicity.
p: the patient has been started on oral ethanol therapy, dosed at 2.5 mlkg of 40 ethanol via a nasogastric tube, to competitively inhibit the metabolism of ethylene glycol. hemodialysis is also initiated to correct metabolic acidosis and remove ethylene glycol from the bloodstream. continuous monitoring of vital signs, electrolytes, and acid-base balance will be necessary. further education on the dangers of toxic substance ingestion will be provided to prevent future incidents.

doctor: hello, i see from your history that youre a 33-year-old japanese woman with a history of igan and diabetes mellitus. youve been admitted to our hospital for the initiation of insulin therapy and evaluation of persistent proteinuria. is that correct?
patient: yes, thats correct.
doctor: i understand that you had a renal biopsy for proteinuria back in 2009 and were diagnosed with igan at our hospital. at your current presentation, you have 0.71.0 gday of urinary protein excretion without significant haematuria. is that right?
patient: yes, thats what ive been told.
doctor: your mean blood pressure is 11060 mmhg, and youve been treated with an angiotensin receptor blocker arb for igan with persistent proteinuria. your urinary protein excretion levels have been about 0.5 gday after the initiation of arb. two years later, you underwent a tonsillectomy for persistent proteinuria. is that all correct?
patient: yes, thats correct.
doctor: in 2012, you were diagnosed with diabetes mellitus based on your fasting plasma glucose levels and haemoglobin a1c hba1c levels during regular visits. you were started on a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 dpp-4 inhibitor and pioglitazone. however, one year later, you discontinued both the regular visits to our hospital and your medication. what was the reason for that?
patient: i wasnt feeling well, and i thought i could manage it on my own.
doctor: i see. seven days prior to your admission at our hospital, you visited a clinic for fatigue. your random blood glucose level was 375 mgdl, and based on this result and persistent proteinuria, you were referred to our hospital. how are you feeling now?
patient: im still feeling tired and a bit weak.
doctor: regarding your family history, your younger sister was diagnosed with impaired glucose tolerance, and your maternal grandmother was diagnosed with diabetes. is that correct?
patient: yes, thats right.
doctor: your physical examination showed that you have a height of 147.0 cm and a weight of 46 kg, with a body mass index bmi of 21.3. we also found several abnormal values in your laboratory testing, including a random blood glucose level of 355 mgdl, hba1c level of 10.8, and lactic acid level of 19.4 mgdl. 
patient: that sounds concerning.
doctor: yes, its important to address these abnormal values. well be initiating insulin therapy to help manage your diabetes and monitoring your proteinuria closely. its crucial to follow your prescribed treatment plan and attend regular visits to keep your diabetes and igan under control. 
patient: okay, i understand. ill make sure to follow the treatment plan and attend regular visits this time.
doctor: thats great to hear. if you have any concerns or questions, please dont hesitate to reach out to us. were here to help you.

p: initiate insulin therapy to manage diabetes and closely monitor blood glucose levels. continue arb for igan management and monitor proteinuria. reinforce the importance of adherence to treatment and regular follow-up visits. provide education on diabetes management and potential complications. schedule follow-up in one month to assess treatment efficacy and adjust as necessary. encourage patient to maintain contact with healthcare providers and report any changes or concerns.

doctor: hello, i see youre here for an evaluation of your new-onset headaches that developed after coitus several weeks ago. can you describe these headaches to me?
patient: yeah, theyre really diffuse and have been bothering me for a while now.
doctor: i see. we performed a fluoroscopic-guided lumbar puncture to help evaluate your condition. the initial pressure was 5 mmhg by fluid-coupled measurements and 11.5 cm of h2o by fluid column method. we removed a total of 10 cc of clear csf. the final pressure was 2 mmhg by fluid-coupled measurements and 3.5 cm of h2o by fluid column method. after the puncture, did you experience any changes in your headache?
patient: yes, actually. i developed a different headache that got worse when i was upright.
doctor: i understand. on a scale of 1 to 10, how severe would you rate this new headache?
patient: id say it was an 8 out of 10. it was really bad, and i also had nausea and vomiting.
doctor: im sorry to hear that. it seems your headache was persistent for 4 days and didnt improve with steroids, caffeine infusion, or hydrocodone-acetaminophen treatment. we conducted a magnetic resonance imaging with gadolinium enhancement to further assess your condition. the results showed cerebellar tonsils descending through the foramen magnum, slit ventricles, and enhancement of the dura. 
patient: oh, that sounds serious.
doctor: its a significant finding, but we proceeded with an epidural injection of whole blood to address your symptoms. how did you feel after the procedure?
patient: i felt much better the headaches completely went away, and id rate them as 0 out of 10 now.
doctor: thats great to hear. were you able to ambulate without any difficulty after the treatment?
patient: yes, i didnt have any trouble walking around.
doctor: thats excellent. it appears that the epidural injection was effective in resolving your headaches. please continue to monitor your symptoms and contact us if you experience any changes or concerns.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate your help.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient presented with new-onset diffuse headaches that began several weeks ago following coitus. the headaches were severe, rated 8 out of 10, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. the patient reported that the headaches worsened when upright and did not improve with steroids, caffeine infusion, or hydrocodone-acetaminophen treatment.
o: a fluoroscopic-guided lumbar puncture showed initial csf pressure of 5 mmhg fluid-coupled and 11.5 cm h2o fluid column, with a final pressure of 2 mmhg fluid-coupled and 3.5 cm h2o fluid column after removing 10 cc of clear csf. mri with gadolinium enhancement revealed cerebellar tonsils descending through the foramen magnum, slit ventricles, and dural enhancement. post-treatment with an epidural injection of whole blood, the patient reported complete resolution of headaches, rating them 0 out of 10, and was able to ambulate without difficulty.
a: the primary diagnosis is a cerebrospinal fluid leak post-coitus, likely exacerbated by intracranial hypotension, as evidenced by imaging findings and symptomatology. differential diagnoses could include migraine or other secondary headaches, but these are less likely given the imaging results and response to treatment.
p: the patient responded well to the epidural blood patch treatment. the plan is to continue monitoring symptoms and advise the patient to return if headaches recur or new symptoms appear. further follow-up with neurology might be necessary to manage potential long-term complications related to the cerebellar tonsil descent. education on recognizing symptoms of csf leaks and the importance of timely treatment will be provided to ensure prompt action in case of recurrence.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i see youve come in for an outpatient consultation regarding painful right upper thoracic radiculopathy. can you tell me how long youve been experiencing this pain?
patient: yeah, ive been dealing with this pain for about 18 months now. its been pretty bad.
doctor: im sorry to hear that. on a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 being the worst pain, how would you rate your pain?
patient: id say its around a 7 or 8 out of 10.
doctor: have you found anything that helps relieve the pain?
patient: yes, ive been taking nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and they seem to help.
doctor: good to know. do you have any muscle contracture or pain when i press on the area?
patient: no, i dont have any contracture, and it doesnt hurt when you press on it.
doctor: can you show me exactly where the pain is located?
patient: its about 3 cm from the thoracic midline on the right side, and i feel some intercostal irradiation too.
doctor: thank you for that information. based on the radiographs we took, we didnt find any osteolysis or deformity. however, the mri showed a t2 hypersignal and a t1 hyposignal at the medial side of your right t1 vertebra, along with inflammation of the right t1 root. the radioisotope bone scanning also revealed lateral hyperfixation on the right side of your t1 vertebra.
patient: oh, i see. what does that mean?
doctor: the ct scan showed an osteolytic lesion surrounded by sclerotic bone at the medial wall of your right t1 pedicle. the lesion is close to the dura mater and t1 spinal nerve, which is causing the inflammation and pain youre experiencing. the aspect of the lesion is compatible with a condition called osteoid osteoma.
patient: what can be done about it?
doctor: our team recommends a surgical resection using a posterior approach with 3d imaging guidance. because the lesion is so close to the dura mater, we cannot perform radiofrequency ablation, which would require thermal ablation. the surgery should be safe and complete, with no risk of recurrence. well also make sure to preserve the vertebral stability without needing screw fixation.
patient: what should i expect during the surgery?
doctor: youll be in a prone position under general anesthesia. well use a new all-in-one imaging device called surgivisio to control the vertebral level in two-dimensional 2d mode. this machine is a 2d3d c-arm designed to be combined with surgical navigation. well perform a mini-open posterior approach at the c7-t2 levels.
patient: thank you for explaining all of this to me. i feel more comfortable knowing what to expect.
doctor: youre welcome. well do our best to make the procedure as smooth and successful as possible. if you have any questions or concerns, dont hesitate to reach out.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient reports experiencing painful right upper thoracic radiculopathy for approximately 18 months, rating the pain as 7-8 out of 10. the pain is partially relieved by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. the patient denies muscle contracture and pain upon palpation. pain location is described as approximately 3 cm from the thoracic midline on the right side with some intercostal irradiation.
o: physical examination did not reveal any muscle contracture or tenderness on palpation. radiographs showed no osteolysis or deformity. mri findings included a t2 hypersignal and a t1 hyposignal at the medial side of the right t1 vertebra, with inflammation of the right t1 root. radioisotope bone scanning indicated lateral hyperfixation at the right t1 vertebra. ct scan revealed an osteolytic lesion surrounded by sclerotic bone at the medial wall of the right t1 pedicle, close to the dura mater and t1 spinal nerve.
a: the primary diagnosis is osteoid osteoma of the right t1 vertebra, causing radiculopathy and pain due to its proximity to the dura mater and spinal nerve. differential diagnoses were considered but ruled out based on imaging studies.
p: the management plan includes surgical resection of the osteoid osteoma using a posterior approach with 3d imaging guidance, specifically using the surgivisio system for intraoperative navigation. radiofrequency ablation is contraindicated due to the proximity of the lesion to critical structures. the patient will be positioned prone under general anesthesia, and a mini-open posterior approach at the c7-t2 levels will be performed. postoperative care will focus on pain management and monitoring for any signs of complications. the patient has been educated about the procedure and expressed comfort with the planned approach. follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and ensure no recurrence.

s: the patient reports a history of painful right upper thoracic radiculopathy for 18 months, which has been managed with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. the pain has been localized to the right side of the right t1 vertebra, with associated inflammation and pain.
o: radiographs revealed a t2 hypersignal and a t1 hyposignal at the medial side, along with inflammation of t1 root. radioisotope bone scanning showed an osteolytic lesion near the dura mater and t1 spinal nerve. radiofrequency ablation was performed, with thermal ablation using 3d imaging guidance. radiographs indicated lateral hyperfixation on the right, with no risk of recurrence.
a: the primary diagnosis is osteolysis or deformity of the t1 pedicle, likely due to osteoid osteoma. differential diagnoses could include other causes of the pain, but these are less likely given the imaging findings.
p: the management plan includes surgical resection using a posterior approach, with surgical preservation of the vertebral stability. the patient will be educated on the surgical procedure and the importance of surgical preservation.

doctor: hello, i see youre a 67-year-old man with lynch syndrome msh6 mutation and polycythemia vera. what brings you in today?
patient: hi, doctor. ive been diagnosed with mcc and im not sure about my merkel cell polyomavirus status. its been tough lately.
doctor: i understand. your records show that you have histologically-proven mcc metastatic to the liver. we started you on first-line therapy with pembrolizumab for 2 months, but unfortunately, you had progressive disease pd as your best response. fig.
patient: yeah, thats right. i was then treated with something else, i think it was ipilimumab and nivolumab.
doctor: yes, you were treated with four cycles of ipilimumab anti-ctla-4, 3 mgkg and nivolumab anti-pd-1, 1 mgkg every 3 weeks  4. you experienced a partial response per immune-related response criteria, which lasted 30 weeks before your disease progressed again.
patient: i remember that. but those medications were given to me again, right?
doctor: correct. ipilimumab and nivolumab were administered again, but they resulted in pd at 14 weeks. after that, we decided to try a different approach.
patient: thats when i started receiving avelumab and radiotherapy, right?
doctor: yes, you were given avelumab anti-pd-l1 10 mgkg every 2 weeks and 3d conformal radiation therapy, 2500 centigray, to a right iliac mass. this treatment resulted in a partial response pr per recist v1.1.
patient: i remember feeling better after that.
doctor: indeed, there was marked regression in the irradiated tumor fig., and your eastern cooperative oncology group ecog performance status improved from 2 to 0. your partial response lasted 12 months.
patient: thats great to hear. so, whats next for me, doctor?
doctor: we will continue to monitor your condition closely and adjust your treatment plan as needed. its important to maintain regular check-ups and follow our recommendations. were here to support you every step of the way.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate all the help and information.

o: the patient has undergone various treatments for mcc with varying responses. initially treated with pembrolizumab, he showed progressive disease. subsequent treatment with ipilimumab 3 mgkg and nivolumab 1 mgkg every 3 weeks for four cycles resulted in a partial response lasting 30 weeks, followed by disease progression. re-treatment with the same regimen led to progressive disease at 14 weeks. most recent treatment with avelumab 10 mgkg every 2 weeks and 3d conformal radiation therapy 2500 centigray to a right iliac mass resulted in a partial response per recist v1.1, with marked regression in the irradiated tumor. his ecog performance status improved from 2 to 0, and the partial response lasted 12 months.
a: the primary diagnosis is metastatic merkel cell carcinoma with a history of multiple lines of systemic therapy and variable responses. the patients current status post-avelumab and radiotherapy shows a partial response with improved performance status. given the history of lynch syndrome, ongoing surveillance for other malignancies is indicated.
p: continue close monitoring of the patients condition with regular follow-ups to assess the durability of the current response and to detect any new disease progression. maintain current treatment with avelumab and consider additional radiotherapy for new lesions if indicated. provide supportive care and manage side effects of therapy. educate the patient on signs of disease progression and the importance of regular check-ups. discuss potential future treatment options, including clinical trials, if the disease progresses again.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i see youve been admitted to queens hospital center with a complaint of shortness of breath for two days duration. can you tell me more about how youve been feeling lately?
patient: yeah, ive been noticing a decrease in my exercise tolerance for a few weeks now. and two weeks ago, i was admitted here for chest pain, but they ruled out acute coronary syndrome.
doctor: i see. based on your evaluation, you had tachycardia with a heart rate of 120-124min and blood pressure of 11080 mm hg. your lungs were clear to auscultation, and there was no evidence of infection or blood loss. we started you on anticoagulation for pulmonary embolism. do you remember if you had a ct chest done?
patient: no, they didnt do a ct chest initially because my creatinine was elevated at 1.6.
doctor: right, so instead they did a ventilationperfusion scan, or vq scan, which showed intermediate probability for pulmonary thromboembolism. we decided to continue your anticoagulation. however, you still had persistent tachycardia, and blood tests showed hypocalcemia at 6.8-7.9 mgdl and hypokalemia at 3.2-3.4 meql, but your thyroid function was normal.
patient: oh, i didnt know that.
doctor: we also found that your 25-hydroxyvitamin d test was low at 6 ngml, and your intact parathyroid hormone was elevated at 85.1 pgml. as a result, we put you on metoprolol 50 mg twice daily and continued intravenous hydration with electrolyte supplementation. we eventually did a ct chest which confirmed the presence of old embolism and showed a 1.1 cm nodule in your left upper lobe.
patient: so, whats the plan now?
doctor: weve consulted endocrinology for your persistent tachycardia with relatively stable blood pressure. you also had spikes of temperature for two days, so we started you on tamiflu and rocephin while waiting for blood culture results.
patient: okay, i understand. but i really want to be discharged and go home.
doctor: i understand, but we need to monitor your condition closely. unfortunately, you suddenly collapsed and went into cardiorespiratory failure. we had to intubate you and transfer you to the intensive care unit for further management.
patients family: what happened after that?
doctor: we attempted to resuscitate him in the icu, but sadly, our efforts were futile. im very sorry for your loss.
patients family: thank you for trying. we dont want an autopsy to be performed.
doctor: we understand and respect your decision. if you have any questions or concerns, please dont hesitate to ask.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient, a male admitted to queens hospital center, complained of shortness of breath persisting for two days and decreased exercise tolerance over a few weeks. he had a history of chest pain two weeks prior, which was evaluated but did not result in a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome. the patient was unaware of some of his lab results and treatment details until explained by the physician.
o: upon evaluation, the patient exhibited tachycardia with a heart rate of 120-124min and blood pressure of 11080 mm hg. lungs were clear on auscultation, and there was no sign of infection or blood loss. initial tests showed elevated creatinine at 1.6, preventing a ct chest, leading to a vq scan indicating intermediate probability for pulmonary thromboembolism. lab results also indicated hypocalcemia 6.8-7.9 mgdl, hypokalemia 3.2-3.4 meql, low 25-hydroxyvitamin d 6 ngml, and elevated intact parathyroid hormone 85.1 pgml. a subsequent ct chest confirmed old embolism and revealed a 1.1 cm nodule in the left upper lobe. the patient experienced persistent tachycardia, temperature spikes, and ultimately cardiorespiratory failure, leading to intubation and icu transfer.
a: the primary diagnosis was pulmonary embolism with complications including electrolyte imbalances hypocalcemia, hypokalemia and vitamin d deficiency. differential diagnosis included secondary hyperparathyroidism. the patients sudden collapse and cardiorespiratory failure were critical developments, leading to his death despite resuscitative efforts.
p: the patient was managed with anticoagulation therapy for pulmonary embolism and metoprolol 50 mg twice daily for tachycardia. intravenous hydration with electrolyte supplementation was administered to address imbalances. endocrinology was consulted for the management of persistent tachycardia and potential parathyroid issues. antibiotics tamiflu and rocephin were started due to temperature spikes and pending blood culture results. despite intensive care and management efforts, the patient did not survive. the family declined an autopsy. further family support and counseling were offered to address their questions and concerns.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i understand you were admitted to our hospital last month with left quadrant abdominal pain and weight loss for more than 6 months. can you tell me more about your symptoms?
patient: yes, the pain gets worse after eating, and i also experience abdominal distension, belching, and reduced flatus.
doctor: have you tried any treatments for these symptoms before coming here?
patient: i was taking some traditional chinese medicine that temporarily relieved the symptoms.
doctor: i see. do you have any medical history we should know about?
patient: yes, i have a history of hypertension, but my control has been poor.
doctor: thank you for sharing that information. it looks like you underwent a colonoscopy examination in a local hospital. what were the results of that examination?
patient: they verbally reported no pathologic findings.
doctor: alright, during your physical examination here, we found mesogastric tenderness and an enlarged spleen. your blood laboratory examination reported only mild hypokalemia, and your urinary and stool reports were normal. enhanced computerized tomography showed splenomegaly, jejunal wall edema, narrowed lumen, enlarged lymph nodes, mesenteric edema, atrophy of the right liver lobe, hypertrophy of the left and caudate lobes, calcification, and periportal fibrosis. these signs are compatible with hepatic schistosomiasis.
patient: oh, that sounds serious.
doctor: yes, it is a condition that needs attention. during the double balloon enteroscopy, we noticed that your blood pressure was not stable, so we couldnt reexamine the colon. the upper enteroscopy showed an ulcer 150 cm distal to the treitz ligament, measuring 3.0 x 2.0 cm. the ulcer had a white coating and peripheral mucosal hyperemia, occupying 23 of the lumen, making it difficult for the endoscope to pass through. we took four biopsies from the ulcer, and 20 cm proximal from the ulcer, we found many scattered irregular ulcers, from which we took two biopsies.
patient: what did the histopathological examination reveal?
doctor: the examination reported chronic jejunal inflammation with ulcerative changes and old s. japonicum eggs deposition.
patient: what treatment did i receive during my hospitalization?
doctor: you received symptomatic treatment with intravenous fluids, electrolytes, antispasmodic medication, and proton-pump inhibitors.
patient: i remember now. unfortunately, i had to request a voluntary discharge from the hospital and decided to continue my treatment and follow-up at a local hospital.
doctor: its important to continue your treatment and follow-up, even if its at a different hospital. please make sure to keep your appointments and monitor your symptoms closely. if you have any concerns or questions, dont hesitate to reach out to your healthcare provider.

o: physical examination revealed mesogastric tenderness and splenomegaly. laboratory tests showed mild hypokalemia urinary and stool reports were normal. enhanced ct indicated splenomegaly, jejunal wall edema, narrowed lumen, enlarged lymph nodes, mesenteric edema, atrophy of the right liver lobe, hypertrophy of the left and caudate lobes, calcification, and periportal fibrosis, suggesting hepatic schistosomiasis. double balloon enteroscopy was limited due to unstable blood pressure however, upper enteroscopy revealed a significant ulcer in the jejunum and multiple scattered irregular ulcers. histopathology confirmed chronic jejunal inflammation with ulcerative changes and old s. japonicum eggs deposition.
a: the primary diagnosis is hepatic schistosomiasis with associated chronic jejunal inflammation and ulceration. differential diagnoses could include other causes of chronic abdominal pain and malabsorption, but imaging and histopathology strongly support schistosomiasis. the prognosis depends on effective management of the infection and associated complications.
p: the patient received symptomatic treatment with intravenous fluids, electrolytes, antispasmodic medication, and proton-pump inhibitors during hospitalization. the patient opted for voluntary discharge and plans to continue treatment and follow-up at a local hospital. it is crucial to maintain consistent follow-up, monitor symptoms, and adhere to prescribed treatments. referral to an infectious disease specialist for schistosomiasis management and a gastroenterologist for ongoing care of jejunal ulcers is recommended. education on the importance of blood pressure control and compliance with hypertension management should also be provided.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i see that youve been referred to our hospital due to a mass that was incidentally discovered in your right kidney. is that correct?
patient: yes, thats right.
doctor: the mass is 16-mm in size and located in the anterior medial position of your kidney. we performed a renal biopsy, which confirmed that its renal cell carcinoma, a type of kidney cancer.
patient: oh no, thats terrible.
doctor: i understand your concern. we have a treatment plan to address this issue. we placed a hook wire in the tumor with the help of an interventional radiologist and ct guidance.
patient: whats the purpose of that?
doctor: the hook wire helps us localize the tumor during surgery. its a technique we use for nonpalpable breast lesions to facilitate intraoperative localization. we will perform a partial nephrectomy to remove the tumor.
patient: how does the surgery work?
doctor: you will be placed in a modified left lateral decubitus position, and we will establish pneumoperitoneum. trocars will be placed to access your abdomen. we will mobilize your bowel medially and develop the plane between the anterior gerotas fascia and the posterior mesocolon.
patient: okay, and then?
doctor: your kidney will be mobilized within gerotas fascia. we will locate the hook wire and clamp the renal artery with a bulldog. the renal capsule will be resected using scissors under warm ischemia, which will take about 25 minutes.
patient: how will you stop the bleeding?
doctor: hemostasis will be achieved using a combination of cautery, hemostatic agents, and suturing. we will use sutures preloaded with clips to secure a suture line, allowing for lateral compression perpendicular to the renal capsule.
patient: what will the results be like?
doctor: the histopathology report confirmed clear-cell renal carcinoma with negative surgical margins. according to the tnm 2017 classification, its stage pt1a.
patient: what does that mean for me?
doctor: it means that the cancer is in its early stage and we were able to remove it completely. we will continue to monitor your condition, but the prognosis is generally good for stage pt1a kidney cancer.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient reports being referred to the hospital due to an incidentally discovered mass in the right kidney. the patient confirms understanding of the diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma following a renal biopsy.
o: the mass measures 16-mm and is located in the anterior medial position of the right kidney. a hook wire was placed in the tumor for surgical localization. the patient underwent a partial nephrectomy, and histopathology confirmed clear-cell renal carcinoma with negative surgical margins. the cancer is classified as stage pt1a according to the tnm 2017 classification.
a: the primary diagnosis is stage pt1a clear-cell renal carcinoma of the right kidney. the prognosis is generally good due to early-stage detection and complete resection of the tumor.
p: the patient underwent a partial nephrectomy with intraoperative localization using a hook wire. postoperative management will include monitoring for recurrence or complications. regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess kidney function and detect any signs of cancer recurrence. education on symptoms of recurrence and lifestyle modifications to support kidney health will be provided.

s: the patient reports a mass in the right kidney, which has been incidentally discovered in the anterior medial position of the kidney. the patient has a history of renal cell carcinoma, stage pt1a.
o: the patients vital signs are not provided. a ct scan revealed a mass measuring 16-mm in size in the kidney, with negative surgical margins. histopathology confirmed clear-cell renal carcinoma. surgical intervention included hook wire placement, sutures, hemostasis, and suturing.
a: the primary diagnosis is stage pt 1a kidney cancer with negative surgery margins. differential diagnoses could include other forms of kidney cancer, but these are less likely given the nature of the tumor.
p: the management plan includes a partial nephrectomy using scissors under warm ischemia, which will take approximately 25 minutes. the patients condition will be monitored closely for any recurrence or recurrence of the disease. the prognosis depends on the surgical intervention and management plan.

Dialogue:
doctor: hi there, i see youre a 37-year-old female indicated for ivf due to bilateral tubal factors. we initiated the ovulation induction on day 2 of your menstrual cycle. how have you been feeling since then?
patient: well, i traveled to so paulo on business with my mother and sister one day after starting the treatment. i took the medications with me, but i noticed some changes in my body.
doctor: can you tell me more about these changes?
patient: sure. i returned and underwent an ultrasound on day 5 of the treatment, and i noticed a skin rash on my trunk, spreading to my limbs. my mother and sister reported the same symptoms too.
doctor: i see. have you experienced any other symptoms, such as fever or pain?
patient: yes, my temperature was 37c, and i had mild low back pain and insignificant joint pain.
doctor: thank you for sharing that. we did a complete blood count and it did not show any changes in your platelets and leukocytes. we also performed a blood test for zikv using a reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction rt-pcr for both you and your husband.
patient: thats good to know. whats next in the treatment?
doctor: we proceeded with the oocyte aspiration at the clinics expense, and we were able to retrieve seven mii stage oocytes. we also collected your follicular fluid and cumulus cells, as well as your husbands semen, for further study.
patient: i see. is there anything else i need to be aware of?
doctor: this is a single-patient case report at our private ivf center. our institutional review board irb does not consider it as human subjects research, so no irb approval was needed. however, we made sure to get informed written consent from both you and your husband.
patient: okay, thank you for explaining that. what are the next steps for us?
doctor: we will continue to monitor your progress and keep you informed of any developments. please continue to take your medications as prescribed and let us know if you experience any further symptoms or side effects.
patient: alright, thank you for keeping us informed and guiding us through this process.
doctor: youre welcome. if you have any questions or concerns at any point, please dont hesitate to reach out. were here to support you and your husband throughout this journey.

o: on day 5 of treatment, an ultrasound was performed. a complete blood count showed no changes in platelets and leukocytes. zikv rt-pcr tests were conducted for the patient and her husband, with results pending. oocyte aspiration yielded seven mii stage oocytes, and samples of follicular fluid, cumulus cells, and semen were collected for further study.
a: the primary concern is the skin rash and other symptoms reported post-travel, which could suggest an infectious cause, possibly related to travel. differential diagnoses could include a reaction to the ivf medications or a viral infection like zikv, pending lab results. the patients ivf process is progressing as expected with successful oocyte retrieval.
p: continue monitoring the patients symptoms and await zikv rt-pcr results. the patient should continue taking prescribed medications and report any new or worsening symptoms. further consultations may be needed depending on the outcome of the pending tests. educate the patient on potential side effects of the medications and ensure she understands the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen.

Dialogue:
doctor: hi there, i understand youve been suffering from hcc with multiple lung metastases for the past 3 months. youre a hepatitis b carrier, correct?
patient: yes, thats right.
doctor: i see that you were admitted complaining of a headache. we performed a brain mri scan to check for any brain metastasis. the results showed a solid mass occupying your left nasal cavity, measuring 3.7  1.8  2.8 cm.
patient: oh, that doesnt sound good.
doctor: yes, the mass showed iso-signal intensity on the t1 weighted image, high signal intensity on the t2 weighted image, and heterogeneous well enhancement on the gd-t1 weighted image. gradient-echo images also showed small foci of low signal, suggesting haemorrhage in the mass.
patient: hmm, what does that mean?
doctor: this means that there might be bleeding within the mass. we didnt find any restricted diffusion in the mass on diffusion-weighted imaging dwi and the apparent diffusion coefficient adc map. metastasis of hcc was suggested, as your nasal cavity was normal on a positron emission tomography ct scan that had been performed 3 months ago.
patient: i see. i have developed some symptoms like left nasal obstruction, clear rhinorrhea, and left facial pain.
doctor: those symptoms are consistent with the mass in your nasal cavity. we performed an excisional biopsy with a ct scan 17 days after the mri scan. it showed that the mass had rapidly increased in size to 6.2  2.2  3.4 cm, with involvement of the ostium of the nasolacrimal duct and the lateral wall of the anterior nasal cavity.
patient: wow, thats a big change.
doctor: yes, it is. there was no calcification in the mass on the pre-contrast ct scan. we conducted a punch biopsy and the histological examination revealed tumor cells with enlarged nucleoli and clear cytoplasm arranged in trabecular cords and glandular arrays, consistent with metastatic hcc.
patient: so, whats the grade of the tumor?
doctor: the tumor is grade 2, which means its moderately differentiated. we were planning for a resection of the tumor, but unfortunately, your general condition has declined.
patient: oh no, whats going to happen now?
doctor: due to your location and your current condition, were going to transfer you to another hospital for further treatment and care.
patient: i understand. thank you for the information and your help, doctor.

a: primary diagnosis is metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma in the nasal cavity, with rapid progression and involvement of critical anatomical structures. differential diagnosis could include other forms of nasal cavity tumors, but histology confirms metastatic hcc. the prognosis is guarded due to the rapid progression of the tumor and the patients declining general condition.
p: the patient was initially planned for surgical resection of the tumor, but due to deterioration in his general health, he will be transferred to another hospital for further treatment and management. this will likely include palliative care and supportive measures to manage symptoms and improve quality of life. further oncological consultation and possibly targeted therapy or chemotherapy may be considered based on his overall health status and response to initial treatments at the new facility.
