Dialogue:
doctor: hi, im dr. smith, the specialist you were referred to by your primary care physician. can you tell me about the problem youve been experiencing?
patient: hello, dr. smith. my primary care doctor noticed that my tonsils were enlarged during an examination of my oral cavity. the right one is slightly larger than the left, but there wasnt any surface abnormality.
doctor: i see. and did your doctor prescribe any medication for it?
patient: yes, they prescribed me two courses of amoxicillin, but it didnt help me improve.
doctor: alright. ive reviewed your medical history and it seems to be unremarkable. we also did not find any cervical lymphadenopathy, significant systemic symptoms, malignancy, or immunocompromise. your laboratory parameters were within normal limits as well.
patient: thats good to hear.
doctor: we conducted a magnetic resonance mr imaging test to look for any mass lesions in your tonsils, but no obvious mass was found. however, the images did show that the right tonsil is larger than the left.
patient: hmm, okay.
doctor: on the axial t2-weighted image and postgadolinium t1-weighted image with fat saturation, we did not find any mass in the right tonsil. the left tonsil showed mucosal crypts with linear enhancement, but on the right side, the crypts were partly obliterated by a large mass and did not display enhancement.
patient: oh, i see.
doctor: due to the possibility of malignancy, we decided to perform a complete surgical resection of the right tonsil.
patient: how did the surgery go?
doctor: the surgery was successful. the histological examination of the specimen revealed diffuse sheets of monomorphous plasmacytoid cells with abundant eosinophilic finely granular cytoplasm and eccentric nuclei. we also observed occasional binucleated and pleomorphic cells with giant nuclei and prominent nucleoli, as well as mitotic figures.
patient: what does that mean?
doctor: these findings indicate that there is no amyloid deposition. immunohistochemically, the plasma cells were diffusely immunoreactive for  light chain and igg. this means that the cells are producing a specific type of antibody, but its not a sign of malignancy.
patient: oh, thats a relief.
doctor: yes, it is. now that the surgery is complete, we will continue to monitor your recovery and ensure that there are no further issues. please follow the post-surgery care instructions and contact us if you have any concerns.
patient: thank you, dr. smith. i appreciate all your help.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient reported that their primary care physician observed enlarged tonsils, with the right tonsil being slightly larger than the left. the patient underwent two courses of amoxicillin without improvement.
o: physical examination showed no cervical lymphadenopathy, systemic symptoms, malignancy, or immunocompromise. laboratory parameters were within normal limits. mr imaging revealed no mass lesions but showed asymmetry in tonsil size and differences in mucosal crypts. histological examination post-surgical resection of the right tonsil showed monomorphous plasmacytoid cells, with no signs of amyloid deposition or malignancy. cells were immunoreactive for  light chain and igg.
a: the primary diagnosis is benign enlargement of the right tonsil, with histological findings suggestive of a reactive plasmacytoid proliferation without evidence of malignancy. differential diagnosis initially included potential malignancy, which was ruled out post-surgery.
p: the patient underwent successful surgical resection of the right tonsil. the plan includes monitoring recovery, adherence to post-surgery care instructions, and regular follow-up to ensure no further complications. the patient is advised to contact healthcare providers if any concerns arise during recovery.

a: the primary diagnosis is a benign tonsil enlargement, likely secondary to malignancy. differential diagnoses could include other forms of throat cancer or cervical lymph

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, how can i help you today?
patient: hi, ive got some redness in my right eye and i saw a worm moving in my left eye.
doctor: i see. have you had any exposure to rural streams during your childhood?
patient: yes, i used to play in them when i was a kid.
doctor: alright, lets perform an ocular examination to check your visual acuity and look for any other findings. 
after examination
doctor: your visual acuity is 65 in both eyes, which is normal. i found a temporal subconjunctival hemorrhage in your right eye, but the worm in your left eye is no longer present.
patient: oh, okay.
doctor: ill reassure you that this is not a major issue. however, if you see the worm again, please come back to the clinic.
patient: sure, thanks.
eleven months later
patient: hi again, i saw the worm in my left eye and ive been experiencing recurrent redness and a feeling of something moving in that eye. i also have generalized body itching, which gets worse at night.
doctor: alright, lets examine your eye again.
after examination
doctor: i found a mobile worm in the temporal subconjunctival area of your left eye, which soon migrated to the superior bulbar conjunctiva.
patient: oh no, what do we do?
doctor: we will perform a conjunctival incision to extract the worm using forceps and repair the wound.
after the procedure
doctor: the worm has been successfully removed. histology confirmed it as an adult loa loa. weve also done a blood work up, which showed negative results for microfilaria but positive eosinophilia at 44.4.
patient: what does that mean?
doctor: it means that theres an elevated level of eosinophils in your blood, which can be associated with a parasitic infection. we will treat you with oral albendazole to address this issue.
patient: alright, thanks for your help.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient reports recurrent redness and a sensation of something moving in the left eye, along with generalized body itching that worsens at night. previously, the patient had seen a worm in the left eye and had a history of playing in rural streams during childhood.
o: visual acuity is 65 in both eyes. examination revealed a mobile worm in the temporal subconjunctival area of the left eye, which migrated to the superior bulbar conjunctiva. post-procedure, the worm was identified as an adult loa loa. blood work showed eosinophilia at 44.4, but was negative for microfilaria.
a: the primary diagnosis is a loa loa infection, evidenced by the presence of the adult worm in the eye and supported by eosinophilia. the absence of microfilaria in the blood suggests either a low-level or localized infection.
p: the patient underwent a successful conjunctival incision to extract the worm. prescribed oral albendazole to address the parasitic infection. advised to monitor for any further symptoms or recurrence and to return for follow-up as needed. educated on the importance of completing the medication course and on potential signs of complications to watch for.

s: the patient reports experiencing redness in the right eye and a feeling of something moving in the left eye, which worsens at night. the patient has a history of playing in rural streams during childhood.
o: visual acuity is 65 in both eyes, which is normal. ocular examination reveals a temporal subconjunctival hemorrhage and a mobile worm in the superior bulbar conjunctiva. blood work indicates elevated eosinophilia at 44.4 normal range: 0-44.4. conjunctival incision was performed using forceps and repair the wound. histology confirmed the worm as an adult loa loa.
a: the primary diagnosis is a parasitic worm, likely a microfilaria. differential diagnoses could include other causes of redness and itching.
p: the management plan includes oral albendazole to address the worm.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i see that youre a 68-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis, newly-diagnosed liver cirrhosis, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypothyroidism, high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion, and cervical intraepithelial neoplasia i. you were admitted to the obstetrics and gynecology service for a planned transvaginal hysterectomy. can you tell me more about your medical history and any current symptoms youre experiencing?
patient: hi, doctor. i dont have any history of significant alcohol use, and my viral hepatitis serologies were negative for hepatitis a, b, and c.
doctor: i noticed that your ferritin level was 319 ngml, which makes hemochromatosis unlikely. your anti-mitochondrial and anti-smooth muscle cell antibodies were also negative. so, primary biliary cirrhosis and primary sclerosing cholangitis are unlikely in the absence of other clinical findings. we also considered wilsons disease, but your serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels were normal, and you did not have any psychiatric symptoms.
patient: yeah, thats right. i also remember that my -1 antitrypsin was within normal limits at 193 mgdl.
doctor: based on your medical history, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease nafld seems to be the most probable explanation for your cirrhosis, given that you have type 2 diabetes mellitus, a body mass index bmi of 29.83, and hyperlipidemia. however, youve been taking methotrexate for more than 10 years for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, which could also be a contributing factor.
patient: hmm, i see. so what happened during my preoperative evaluation?
doctor: during the evaluation, your resting supine oxygen saturation was noted to be 93. at that time, you denied any respiratory or cardiac symptoms, so you underwent the transvaginal hysterectomy, which went smoothly with no complications.
patient: thats good to hear. but i remember feeling short of breath after the surgery.
doctor: yes, on postoperative day two, you became dyspneic while walking to the restroom. we also noted a two-gram drop in your hemoglobin level after surgery, which was promptly corrected with two units of packed red blood cells.
patient: oh, i see. did that help with my shortness of breath?
doctor: unfortunately, despite the administration of packed red blood cell transfusions, you still experienced hypoxemia with an oxygen saturation of 82 while sitting up and during ambulation. when you tried to ambulate further, you developed perioral cyanosis.
patient: oh no, that doesnt sound good. what should i do now, doctor?
doctor: we will continue to closely monitor your condition and provide necessary medical support. its important that you report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. we will work together to ensure your recovery and to manage your various health conditions.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate your help and guidance.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient is a 68-year-old woman with a complex medical history including rheumatoid arthritis, newly-diagnosed liver cirrhosis, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypothyroidism, high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion, and cervical intraepithelial neoplasia i. she denies significant alcohol use and has negative viral hepatitis serologies. she reports shortness of breath postoperatively.
o: the patients ferritin level was 319 ngml, anti-mitochondrial and anti-smooth muscle cell antibodies were negative, serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels were normal, and -1 antitrypsin was within normal limits at 193 mgdl. her bmi is 29.83. preoperative resting supine oxygen saturation was 93. postoperatively, she experienced a drop in hemoglobin by two grams, corrected with two units of packed red blood cells. despite this, she developed hypoxemia with an oxygen saturation of 82 while sitting up and during ambulation, and perioral cyanosis on further ambulation.
a: primary diagnosis is nonalcoholic fatty liver disease nafld secondary to type 2 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia, potentially exacerbated by long-term methotrexate use. postoperative complications include significant hypoxemia and potential anemia. differential diagnoses for her respiratory symptoms could include pulmonary embolism, heart failure, or pneumonia.
p: continue close monitoring of the patients respiratory status and hemoglobin levels. consider further diagnostic workup for postoperative respiratory distress, including chest x-ray and possibly a ct pulmonary angiogram to rule out pulmonary embolism. ensure adequate oxygenation and consider respiratory support if hypoxemia persists. educate the patient on the importance of reporting new or worsening symptoms. manage underlying chronic conditions with appropriate medications and lifestyle modifications. follow up with rheumatology for methotrexate evaluation and gastroenterology for liver disease management.

s: the patient is a 68-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis, newly-diagnosed liver cirrhosis, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypothyroidism, high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion, and cervical intraepidhelial neoplasia i. she reports experiencing shortness of breath post-transvaginal hysterectomy, dyspneic while walking to the restroom, and dyspnea on postoperative day two. she denies any respiratory or cardiac symptoms.
o: preoperative evaluation revealed hemochromatosis, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease nafld, and primary sclerosing cholangitis. serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels were normal, serum -1 antitrypsin were within normal limits at 193 mgdl, and serum anti-mitochondrial and anti-smooth muscle cell antibodies were negative for hepatitis a, b, and c. postoperative evaluation showed a two-gram drop in hemoglobin level after surgery, which corrected with two units of packed red blood cells.
a: the primary diagnosis is liver cir

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i understand you were referred to our veterinary teaching hospital at ceu cardenal herrera university because your french bulldog has a corneal mass on the right eye that has been enlarging over a 2-month period. is that correct?
patient: yes, thats right. hes a 7-year-old male and had a complete excision of the third eyelid gland 5 years ago.
doctor: i see. and did he develop any complications after that surgery?
patient: yes, he developed keratoconjunctivitis sicca, which weve been controlling with cyclosporine eye drops and artificial tears.
doctor: thats good to hear. now, lets proceed with the examination. i noticed an exophytic pink to white gelatinous mass occupying about 70 of the central cornea on his right eye fig. a. his dazzle reflex seems inconsistent, and his menace response is negative. ill perform a fluorescein staining to check for any corneal damage.
patient: alright, what did you find?
doctor: the fluorescein staining was negative. i also conducted a slit lamp biomicroscopy examination, which showed a severe increase in corneal thickness, pigment deposit, and superficial vascularization. the mass seems to be infiltrating the corneal stroma.
patient: oh, that doesnt sound good.
doctor: we also performed a schirmer tear test-1 and measured the intraocular pressure by applanation tonometry. both of these tests were within normal limits. however, we couldnt perform an indirect ophthalmoscopy.
patient: and what about his left eye?
doctor: the ophthalmic exam of the left eye was unremarkable, and no abnormalities were observed on the physical examination.
patient: so, whats the diagnosis for his right eye?
doctor: at this time, we suspect it may be corneal neoplasia. other differential diagnoses include granulation tissue and a chronic inflammatory process. to confirm the diagnosis, we performed an excisional superficial keratectomy under general anesthesia.
patient: what did you find from that procedure?
doctor: the histological findings were consistent with corneal carcinoma. we proceeded with transconjunctival enucleation to remove the mass.
patient: and what happens after that?
doctor: we have fixed the globe, conjunctiva, and nictitant membrane in 10 neutral buffered formalin and submitted it for histopathologic examination. well be able to provide more information once we have the results.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate all your help.

doctor: hello, i see from your history that you have osteoarthritis and hypothyroidism. what brings you in today?
patient: hi, doc. i noticed a rapidly growing lesion near my left eye about 3 weeks ago, and its been growing ever since. my primary care physician referred me to you.
doctor: i see. lets take a look at the lesion. upon examination, it appears to be a medial orbital mass causing ectropion of the lower eyelid and symptomatic epiphora. we should perform a ct scan of the orbits to further investigate this lesion.
patient: alright, doc. what did the ct scan results show?
doctor: the ct scan showed a 2.0  1.6  1.0 cm nonenhancing intraorbital soft tissue lesion abutting the nasal lacrimal duct, lateral and inferior to the globe, without definite osseous remodeling. there is no thickening of the lateral rectus muscle or inflammation. there is a moderate lateral displacement of the intraocular structures, but the globe is intact.
patient: oh, i see. whats the next step, doc?
doctor: we performed an anterior orbitotomy with biopsy 4 days after your presentation. the pathology was initially read as positive for intermediate grade epithelioid carcinoma, but after an outside consultation, the diagnosis was edited to epithelioid sarcoma with rhabdoid features proximal type.
patient: what does that mean, exactly?
doctor: immunohistochemical stains revealed the tumor to be ae1ae3 strong positive, gata3 strong positive, vimentin strong positive, ema focal positive, calponin focal positive, and a series of other markers were negative. this helps us better understand the nature of the tumor.
patient: considering my age and the tumors histology, what are my treatment options?
doctor: due to your age and the tumor histology, chemotherapy is not recommended by medical oncology. we completed your staging workup with a soft tissue neck ct, which showed no evidence of abnormal lymph nodes. additionally, a chestabdomenpelvis ct showed no evidence of metastatic disease in your chest, abdomen, or pelvis. thus, the disease is localized to the left orbit only.
patient: thats somewhat relieving. whats the plan moving forward?
doctor: we will closely monitor the lesion and discuss other treatment options with you as needed. its important to keep an eye on any changes and report them to us immediately.
patient: okay, doc. ill keep a close watch on it and let you know if there are any changes. thank you for your help.
doctor: youre welcome. dont hesitate to reach out if you have any concerns or questions in the meantime. take care.

doctor: hello, i understand you have a history of multiple periprosthetic infections in your left knee. can you tell me more about your past medical history?
patient: yeah, i have diabetes, obstructive sleep apnea, congestive heart failure, and gastroesophageal reflux disease.
doctor: thank you for sharing that information. have you had any surgeries in the past?
patient: yes, i had a lumbar spinal fusion and multiple failed revision two-stage tkas for my knee infection.
doctor: i see. are you currently taking any medications for your conditions?
patient: yes, im taking furosemide, gabapentin, carvedilol, lansoprazole, docusate, and enalapril.
doctor: good to know. do you have any documented history of allergies or complications with anesthesia?
patient: no, i dont.
doctor: on the day of your operation, we administered cephalexin 2 mg. when we opened your left knee, we found cloudy fluid, which was sent for culture and sensitivities. we debrided and irrigated the infected cement spacers on your femur and tibia. a tobramycin and vancomycin cement mixture formed the new spacer. intraoperatively, you had brief episodes of hypotension on induction, requiring 3 pressors.
patient: oh, i didnt know that.
doctor: for the duration of the case, you required intermittent pressure support with a total of phenylephrine 360 mcg, epinephrine 30 mcg, and norepinephrine 36 mcg. after the surgery, you were extubated and transferred to the recovery room in stable condition.
patient: thats good to hear.
doctor: your medications postoperatively included celecoxib 200 mg bid and aspirin 325 mg bid, and we continued you on lansoprazole. we also started you on vancomycin 2 g iv every 12 hours and piperacillin-tazobactam 3.375 g iv every 6 hours.
patient: okay, got it.
doctor: the cultures revealed that your joint was infected with corynebacterium striatum, so we discontinued the iv piperacillin-tazobactam.
patient: i see.
doctor: on postoperative day 2, you developed a nonoliguric aki, and your creatinine levels increased from a baseline of 0.9 mgdl to 1.5 mgdl.
patient: oh, that doesnt sound good.
doctor: we will continue to monitor your kidney function and adjust your medications accordingly. please make sure to attend your follow-up appointments and let us know if you experience any new symptoms or worsening of your condition.
patient: alright, ill make sure to do that. thank you, doctor.

Dialogue:
doctor: hi, i see that you were admitted after experiencing a sudden thunderclap headache, preceded by an acute loss of consciousness at your home. is that correct?
patient: yes, thats right. it happened so suddenly.
doctor: i understand. were there any past history of hypertension, seizures, drug abuse, trauma, or infection before this incident?
patient: no, i never had any of those issues.
doctor: okay. on admission, our initial clinical examination showed you were unconscious with a gcs score of 1015, which corresponds to hunt  hess classification grade iv.
patient: oh, that sounds serious.
doctor: after we stabilized you, we performed a ct scan, which showed diffuse subarachnoid haemorrhage and a cisternal clot at the interpeduncular cistern. this is classified as modified fisher i. we also noticed moderate dilatation of the temporal horns of the lateral ventricle.
patient: what does that mean, exactly?
doctor: it means that you had bleeding in the space around your brain and a clot formed in a specific area. the dilatation of the temporal horns indicates some swelling in your brain. we then performed an angiography to further investigate the cause.
patient: and what did the angiography show?
doctor: the angiography revealed a ruptured saccular aneurysm of less than 3 mm in diameter, with a neck of 1.5 mm at the origin of your left frontopolar artery. considering the small size of the aneurysm and its ruptured nature, we decided to manage it conservatively.
patient: i see. but i heard that it bled again after 2 weeks?
doctor: yes, unfortunately, the aneurysm bled once more. we obtained another ct scan, which showed a superior interhemispheric frontal haematoma that had opened to your ventricular system. this was classified as modified fisher iv.
patient: what did you do then?
doctor: on day 15 after the second haemorrhage, we performed a coiling procedure. after selectively placing a microcatheter in the left frontopolar artery aneurysm, we completely obliterated it with a single coil, maintaining the distal arterial lumen totally permeable.
patient: did the procedure work?
doctor: yes, it did. we performed a follow-up magnetic resonant angiogram 6 months after the coil embolization, and it showed stable occlusion.
patient: thats good to hear. but recently, i had an episode of gtcs. what happened?
doctor: we performed an immediate ct scan, which showed a chronic infarct in your left frontal lobe. we will continue to monitor your condition and provide any necessary treatment.
patient: alright. thank you for explaining everything to me, doctor.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient was admitted after experiencing a sudden thunderclap headache and acute loss of consciousness. the patient denies any past history of hypertension, seizures, drug abuse, trauma, or infection.
o: on admission, the patient was unconscious with a glasgow coma scale gcs score of 1015, indicating a hunt  hess classification grade iv. initial ct scan revealed diffuse subarachnoid hemorrhage and a cisternal clot at the interpeduncular cistern, classified as modified fisher i, with moderate dilatation of the temporal horns of the lateral ventricle. angiography showed a ruptured saccular aneurysm of less than 3 mm in diameter at the origin of the left frontopolar artery. a second ct scan after a rebleed showed a superior interhemispheric frontal hematoma opening to the ventricular system, classified as modified fisher iv. a follow-up magnetic resonant angiogram 6 months post-coil embolization showed stable occlusion. a recent ct scan indicated a chronic infarct in the left frontal lobe.
a: the primary diagnosis is a ruptured saccular aneurysm of the left frontopolar artery with subsequent subarachnoid hemorrhage and chronic infarct in the left frontal lobe. differential diagnoses initially included other causes of sudden loss of consciousness and headache, but imaging confirmed the aneurysm and associated complications.
p: the patient underwent successful coil embolization of the aneurysm. ongoing management includes monitoring neurological status, managing potential complications from the chronic infarct, and addressing any new symptoms such as seizures. regular follow-up with neurology is recommended to assess the stability of the aneurysm occlusion and manage any long-term neurological effects. education on recognizing symptoms of potential complications and when to seek immediate care is crucial for the patient.

Dialogue:
doctor: hi, i understand that youre 32 years old and currently at week 22 of your pregnancy. you were admitted to the haematology department with bilateral supraclavicular swelling, diffuse itching, and right shoulder pain. can you tell me more about your symptoms?
patient: yes, ive been experiencing these swellings on both sides of my neck, and theyve been very itchy. my right shoulder has been hurting a lot too.
doctor: alright, we performed an ultrasound imaging and found pathological bilateral supraclavicular enlarged lymph nodes. after a biopsy, we diagnosed you with nodular sclerosis hodgkins lymphoma hl.
patient: oh, that sounds serious.
doctor: it is a type of cancer, but dont worry. we will do our best to help you. we also performed a fetal ultrasound screening and it showed that your baby is developing normally.
patient: thats a relief. whats the plan for my treatment?
doctor: we decided not to perform a combined fludeoxyglucose positron emission tomography fdg-petct scan before delivery due to the risk of radiation exposure during pregnancy. instead, we used ultrasound and whole-body mri wb-mri to stage the disease. it showed right cervical, bilateral supraclavicular, and mediastinal lymph node involvement without a bulky mass, indicating stage iia disease according to ann arbor classification.
patient: what does that mean?
doctor: it means the cancer is in the early stages and has not spread extensively. the multidisciplinary team, including haematologists, gynaecologists, radiologists, and neonatologists, decided to start chemotherapy only if clinically necessary. we have been following up with ultrasound, wb-mri, haematology consults, and gynaecological examinations. we also started therapy with steroid and paracetamol to slow down the progression of the disease and treat your itching and shoulder pain.
patient: hmm, okay. and hows my condition now?
doctor: at pregnancy week 27, wb-mri demonstrated a slight progression of the disease, seen as an enlargement of the lymph node packages, with the largest in the mediastinum having an axial diameter of 5.4 x 4.5 cm.
patient: oh no, what do we do now?
doctor: unfortunately, at pregnancy week 29, your clinical conditions got worse, and you presented with coughing, night sweating, numbness, and pain radiating across the shoulder down the arm. an ultrasound examination showed enlargement of a right axillary lymph node and internal jugular vein thrombosis. we treated the thrombosis with enoxaparin, which allowed complete recanalization in just a week. due to these symptoms and findings, the team decided to start chemotherapy.
patient: i see. so, whats the next step?
doctor: well perform another wb-mri to monitor the progression of the disease and ensure the chemotherapy is working effectively. well continue with the multidisciplinary follow-up and adjust the treatment plan as necessary to ensure the best possible outcome for both you and your baby.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate all the efforts and care from the team.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient, a 32-year-old female at 22 weeks of pregnancy, reports bilateral supraclavicular swelling, diffuse itching, and right shoulder pain. she expresses concern about her symptoms and the impact on her pregnancy.
o: ultrasound imaging revealed pathological bilateral supraclavicular enlarged lymph nodes. biopsy confirmed nodular sclerosis hodgkins lymphoma hl. fetal ultrasound screening indicates normal development. whole-body mri wb-mri staged the disease as stage iia, showing right cervical, bilateral supraclavicular, and mediastinal lymph node involvement without a bulky mass. at pregnancy week 27, wb-mri showed slight disease progression. at week 29, symptoms worsened with coughing, night sweating, numbness, and pain radiating across the shoulder down the arm. ultrasound examination showed enlargement of a right axillary lymph node and internal jugular vein thrombosis. enoxaparin treatment led to complete recanalization of the thrombosis within a week.
a: the primary diagnosis is nodular sclerosis hodgkins lymphoma, stage iia. the patients condition initially managed conservatively due to pregnancy, has shown progression by week 27 and significant worsening by week 29, necessitating the initiation of chemotherapy. differential diagnoses would consider other types of lymphoma or metastatic cancers, but biopsy results confirm hl.
p: continue current treatment with chemotherapy while monitoring disease progression through wb-mri. maintain multidisciplinary follow-up involving haematologists, gynaecologists, radiologists, and neonatologists to adjust treatment as necessary and ensure optimal outcomes for both patient and fetus. manage symptoms with ongoing steroid and paracetamol therapy and continue anticoagulation therapy with enoxaparin as needed. educate the patient about the signs of potential complications and the importance of reporting new symptoms promptly.

o: ultrasound and whole-body mri wb-mri showed right cervical, and mediastinal lymph node involvement without a bulky mass, indicating stage iia disease according to ann arbor classification. ultrasound imaging and whole body mri indicated a slight progression of the disease, with the largest in the mediastinum having an axial diameter of 5.4 x 4.5 cm. fetal ultrasound screening and fetal ultrasound showed normal fetal development.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, i see youve presented with a one-month history of epigastric discomfort. can you tell me more about your symptoms?
patient: yeah, ive been having this discomfort in my upper stomach area for the past month. its been quite bothersome.
doctor: i understand. we performed a physical examination, and it was unremarkable. however, your laboratory examination showed slightly elevated amylase levels. we conducted an abdominal contrast-enhanced computed tomography ct and found a low-density mass with a diameter of 30 mm at the pancreatic head, with segmental superior mesenteric vein smv attachment. there was neither stenosis nor arteriosclerosis around the celiac axis at that time.
patient: oh, that doesnt sound good.
doctor: we also performed endoscopic ultrasonography, and a fine-needle biopsy sample showed adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.
patient: so, its cancer?
doctor: yes, unfortunately. we proceeded with pancreaticoduodenectomy pd with superior mesenteric vein resection and reconstruction. additionally, a lymphadenectomy including right half dissection of the lymph nodes was performed without the nerve plexus around the celiac trunk. intraoperative exploration ruled out latent peritoneal or liver metastasis and showed normal anatomy of the celiac trunk, mesenteric vessels, and related branches.
patient: how did the surgery go?
doctor: the duration of the surgery was 549 minutes, and the blood loss was 863 ml. blood transfusion was not performed. we had to mobilize the pancreatic body more than usual for the pancreaticojejunostomy because it was a hard pancreas.
patient: what happened after the surgery?
doctor: on postoperative day 3, your liver function tests were still abnormal, and we found bloody fluids in the drain. an abdominal ct showed a characteristic hook-pattern on the anterior proximal celiac axis from compression of the mal, which had not been detected in the preoperative ct. ischemic changes in the remnant pancreas, hepatic lateral segment, and gastrojejunostomy site were also observed.
patient: oh no, what does that mean?
doctor: although all celiac branches were visible, there were almost no pulsations in those branches. we first tried interventional radiology, but the procedure failed due to tight compression against the outside of the celiac axis.
patient: so, what was the next step?
doctor: you underwent an urgent re-laparotomy to address the issue. ill be monitoring your progress closely and provide further instructions based on your recovery.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate your help.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient reports a one-month history of epigastric discomfort, describing it as bothersome. no additional symptoms were mentioned.
o: physical examination was unremarkable. laboratory tests showed slightly elevated amylase levels. abdominal ct revealed a 30 mm low-density mass at the pancreatic head with attachment to the superior mesenteric vein smv, without stenosis or arteriosclerosis around the celiac axis. endoscopic ultrasonography and fine-needle biopsy confirmed adenocarcinoma of the pancreas. postoperative findings included abnormal liver function tests and bloody fluids in the drain on day 3. a follow-up ct indicated ischemic changes in the remnant pancreas, hepatic lateral segment, and gastrojejunostomy site, with a hook-pattern on the anterior proximal celiac axis from compression of the median arcuate ligament mal.
a: the primary diagnosis is pancreatic adenocarcinoma, complicated by postoperative complications including ischemic changes likely due to mal compression. differential diagnosis initially included other causes of epigastric discomfort such as pancreatitis or gastric ulcers, which were ruled out by imaging and biopsy.
p: the patient underwent pancreaticoduodenectomy with smv resection and lymphadenectomy, followed by an urgent re-laparotomy to address ischemic complications from mal compression. ongoing close monitoring and supportive care are necessary. further interventions may include additional surgical or radiological procedures to relieve mal compression if symptoms persist or worsen. education regarding the diagnosis, surgical procedures, potential complications, and recovery expectations has been provided. regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any arising complications.

a: the primary diagnosis is pancreatic cancer, complicated by malignancy. differential diagnoses could include other causes of pancreatic disease, but these are less likely given the imaging findings.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, how can i help you today?
patient: hi, ive had a mass on my anterior abdominal wall for about a year now. its been gradually increasing in size and causing me discomfort.
doctor: i see. have you noticed any changes in the mass or your symptoms during certain times, such as during your menstrual cycle?
patient: yes, it gets worse during my menses. the mass seems to get bigger and the pain becomes more intense.
doctor: okay, thank you for sharing that. have you had any surgeries in the past, specifically in the abdominal area?
patient: i had a caesarean section six years ago, but thats it.
doctor: alright. i would like to perform a physical examination to get a better understanding of the mass. 
patient: sure, go ahead.
doctor: examines the patient i can feel a circumscribed mass measuring approximately 6 cms in diameter in the infraumbilical region to the left of the midline. the mobility of the swelling seems to be restricted when you contract your muscles, which may suggest infiltration of the underlying musculoaponeurotic structures.
patient: what does that mean, exactly?
doctor: it means the mass may be affecting the muscles and tissues beneath the skin. we will need to conduct some laboratory investigations and a ct scan to get a clearer picture. 
patient: okay, lets do it.
after the tests
doctor: the laboratory results are within normal limits, and the ct scan revealed a contrast-enhancing lesion in the subcutaneous tissues, infiltrating the underlying musculoaponeurotic structures. this is highly suggestive of an abdominal wall endometrioma.
patient: so, whats the next step for me?
doctor: the best course of action would be surgical resection. we would remove the endometrioma along with a portion of the underlying aponeurosis and rectus abdominis muscle.
patient: and after that?
doctor: we will place a polypropylene mesh over the defect created by the resection and fix it to the anterior rectus sheath with nonabsorbable sutures. this will help to reinforce the area and promote healing.
patient: what can i expect after the surgery?
doctor: the postoperative course should be uneventful. we will perform a histopathological evaluation of the resected specimen to ensure clear resection margins. following the procedure, there should be no seroma at the operative site, and you should experience complete relief of symptoms.
patient: that sounds great. thank you so much for your help, doctor.
doctor: youre welcome. if you have any questions or concerns, please dont hesitate to reach out. were here to help.
Reference SOAP:

o: physical examination revealed a circumscribed, infraumbilical mass approximately 6 cm in diameter, located to the left of the midline with restricted mobility upon muscle contraction. laboratory tests are within normal limits. ct scan shows a contrast-enhancing lesion in the subcutaneous tissues, infiltrating the underlying musculoaponeurotic structures, suggestive of an abdominal wall endometrioma.
a: primary diagnosis is abdominal wall endometrioma, likely related to previous surgical history caesarean section. differential diagnosis could include other benign or malignant soft tissue tumors, but clinical presentation and imaging are highly suggestive of endometrioma.
p: plan to proceed with surgical resection of the endometrioma, including a portion of the underlying aponeurosis and rectus abdominis muscle. post-surgical repair will involve placement of a polypropylene mesh fixed with nonabsorbable sutures. postoperative care will include histopathological evaluation of the resected specimen to confirm clear margins and ensure no residual disease. the patient is expected to have an uneventful recovery with complete resolution of symptoms. follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor healing and address any complications.

Dialogue:
doctor: hello, can you please tell me about your medical history, especially regarding alcohol and tobacco use?
patient: ive been using alcohol and tobacco extensively for many years.
doctor: i see. what brings you in today?
patient: for the past 2 months, ive had this progressively enlarging, painful ulcerative lesion in the middle of my tongue. its about 5 cm and has even caused an anterior tongue cleft. ive also had unintentional weight loss, left ear pain, and swelling under my jaw.
doctor: hmm, have you noticed any lumps in your neck area?
patient: yes, ive felt some non-tender lumps on both sides of my neck.
doctor: it seems you have bilateral palpable lymphadenopathy in levels i, ii, and iii. now, i understand youve had biopsies done before by an otolaryngologist. what were the results?
patient: they didnt find any cancer, but they saw some reactive inflammatory changes.
doctor: okay. we also conducted a positron emission tomography scan, which revealed hypermetabolic lesions in your anterior tongue and lymph nodes, suggesting malignancy. the assessment was a likely t34n2cm0 tongue squamous cell carcinoma. we performed a panendoscopy with biopsies and a physical examination under anesthesia for surgical planning. however, the biopsy results again did not show carcinoma but rather granulomatous inflammation without organisms present.
patient: so, whats the next step?
doctor: a multidisciplinary tumor board recommended a rheumatologic workup and an excisional lymph node biopsy. the lymph node biopsy results demonstrated noncaseating granulomatous inflammation with no malignancy, while laboratory results showed markedly elevated angiotensin converting enzyme ace levels. these findings suggested an atypical case of sarcoidosis, so we referred you for a pulmonary consultation.
patient: i remember that. i also developed some red spots on my extremities, palms, soles, and trunk.
doctor: yes, your laboratory evaluation demonstrated t pallidum immunoglobulin g antibodies present with a reflex rpr titer of 1:512. we then analyzed the lymph node biopsy sample with immunohistochemistry ihc, which revealed spirochetes. you were diagnosed with tertiary syphilis and started on doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 30 days due to a severe penicillin allergy.
patient: how am i doing after the treatment?
doctor: after receiving treatment, your tongue lesion is healing well, but there is still a persistent anterior tongue cleft. it is important for you to follow up with further laboratory evaluations to monitor your progress.
patient: alright, ill make sure to do that. thank you, doctor.
Reference SOAP:
s: the patient, a long-term user of alcohol and tobacco, presents with a 2-month history of a progressively enlarging, painful ulcerative lesion in the middle of the tongue, measuring approximately 5 cm, associated with an anterior tongue cleft. the patient also reports unintentional weight loss, left ear pain, swelling under the jaw, and bilateral non-tender neck lumps.
o: physical examination revealed bilateral palpable lymphadenopathy in levels i, ii, and iii. positron emission tomography indicated hypermetabolic lesions in the anterior tongue and lymph nodes. initial biopsies suggested granulomatous inflammation without organisms, and further testing showed markedly elevated angiotensin converting enzyme levels. laboratory tests confirmed the presence of t pallidum immunoglobulin g antibodies with a reflex rpr titer of 1:512. immunohistochemistry on lymph node biopsy revealed spirochetes.
a: the primary diagnosis is tertiary syphilis, evidenced by serology and immunohistochemistry findings. differential diagnosis initially included tongue squamous cell carcinoma and sarcoidosis, but these were ruled out through biopsies and additional testing. the prognosis is good with appropriate treatment, though monitoring is necessary due to the persistent anterior tongue cleft and potential for relapse or incomplete resolution of symptoms.
p: the patient has been prescribed doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 30 days due to severe penicillin allergy, with the treatment course already underway. follow-up includes further laboratory evaluations to monitor the resolution of syphilis and assess for any remaining or recurring symptoms. the patient has been referred for a pulmonary consultation to evaluate potential sarcoidosis and will continue to be monitored by a multidisciplinary team. education on the importance of compliance with the treatment regimen and follow-up appointments has been provided.

Dialogue:
patient: hi doctor, ive been having some issues lately and im not sure whats going on.
doctor: im sorry to hear that. can you tell me more about your symptoms?
patient: well, ive been experiencing urinary frequency and nocturia for about a month now.
doctor: i see. lets discuss your medical history to better understand your situation. i know you have multiple psychiatric conditions, including bipolar disorder, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, oppositional defiant disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder, and poor impulse control. what medications are you currently taking?
patient: im taking clonidine 0.1 mg three times daily, guanfacine 4 mg daily, bupropion sustained-release 150 mg daily, quetiapine 200 mg twice daily, and lithium 450 mg three times daily. i started lithium when i was 5 years old.
doctor: thank you for that information. about a year prior to your presentation, your lithium level was in the range of 0.91.1 mmoll and your serum creatinine was 0.78 mgdl, with an estimated glomerular filtration rate egfr of 86 mlmin1.73 m2 based on the bedside schwartz formula. well need to run some tests to identify any issues.
after running tests
doctor: your physical examination was unremarkable. urinalysis revealed a specific gravity of 1.006, a ph of 6.0, but no hematuria or proteinuria. blood tests showed a lithium level of 1.4 mmoll, a tsh of 5.09 uiuml normal 0.554.78 uiuml, a calcium of 11.1 mgdl normal 8.610.6 mgdl, and a creatinine of 1.15 mgdl.
patient: is there anything we should do about it?
doctor: your primary care physician pcp reduced your lithium dose to 450 mg twice daily and initiated levothyroxine for hypothyroidism. one week later, your lithium level reduced to 1.1 mmoll. however, over the next couple of weeks, your creatinine increased to 1.3 mgdl.
patient: oh, that doesnt sound good.
doctor: your pcp decided to discontinue the lithium by tapering the dose over the next 3 weeks. despite a very low lithium level of 0.1 mmoll four weeks after discontinuation, your serum creatinine continued to increase, prompting a nephrology referral.
patient: so, what happens now?
doctor: at your presentation to the nephrology clinic, your physical examination was unremarkable. the nephrologist will further evaluate your condition and determine the best course of action for your treatment.
patient: thank you, doctor. i appreciate your help in figuring this out.

o: physical examination was unremarkable. urinalysis showed specific gravity 1.006, ph 6.0, no hematuria or proteinuria. blood tests revealed lithium level 1.4 mmoll, tsh 5.09 uiuml normal 0.554.78 uiuml, calcium 11.1 mgdl normal 8.610.6 mgdl, and creatinine 1.15 mgdl. previous lithium level was 0.91.1 mmoll, serum creatinine 0.78 mgdl, egfr 86 mlmin1.73 m2. after dose adjustment and initiation of levothyroxine, lithium level reduced to 1.1 mmoll, but creatinine increased to 1.3 mgdl.
